name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the joint debate on: - the report by Dario Tamburrano, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for labeling in relation toenergy efficiency and repealing Directive 2010/30 / EU (COM (2015) 0341 - C8-0189 / 2015 - 2015/0149 (COD)) (A8-0213 / 2016) and - the question for oral answer on compensationfor incorrect labeling of energy products, addressed to the Commission by Martina Werner, on behalf of the S & D Group, Dario Tamburrano, on behalf of the EFDD Group, Michèle Rivasi, on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group, and Neoklis Sylikiotis, on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group (O–000049/2017 - B8–0320 / 2017) (2017/2725 (RSP)).

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: speaker. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am particularly excited today and will tell you a new story, at least in this House. In fact, this regulation brings within the European regulations some concepts relating to the energy efficiency of electrical equipment and their potential dynamic interaction with electrical networks. I was learning these notions ten years ago, when I was practicing dentistry and, out of pure popular passion, I translated essays on environmental sustainability into Italian. I could never have imagined being here one day to represent millions of citizens and to have the honor of translating into European legislation what were at the time some experimental proposals by Lester Brown and others. Smart appliances are appliances, such as dishwashers and washing machines, that can be programmed by the user, so that they come into operation when electricity is available in more abundant and cheaper quantities. The widespread use of smart appliances will be able not only to save users money, but also to provide a not insignificant contribution to the balancing of an electricity system powered by renewable sources in an ever increasing extent. Imagine a citizen producing wind or photovoltaic energy. Some equipment in his house will be able to come into operation and carry out their activity when self-production is more abundant. Imagine the old and antiquated electric water heater, which by its nature is not particularly efficient in purely thermodynamic terms, but if the water heater will heat the water when the electricity is cheaper and more abundant, the accumulated heat will be a form of energy source. low price. Smart appliances mark a new milestone in energy efficiency not only in quantity but also in quality, not only in terms of how much energy is consumed, but also when it is used. That is why I am excited, because behind this text there is a small piece of utopia that is turning into reality for 500 million citizens. The demonstration that one can believe in an idea, however distant it may seem, and piece by piece, with perseverance and determination, get to realize it. This regulation, for the first time, gives manufacturers the possibility to indicate on the label the ability of a device to be energy smart. This little thing allows the new labeling regulation to be in step with the times and to enter fully into the new dynamic, decentralized and renewable energy model, which we want to pursue with the Energy Union. An Energy Union that has among its declared objectives also that of having the citizen at its center. Well, together with the new labels, an open data database will be created to which it will be possible to connect directly through a mobile phone, a QR Code, a link or the like, present on the paper label, and will be able to provide buyers, in the 24 languages ​​of the Union, with only a series of information impossible to cram onto a piece of paper, but it will also allow the development of smartphone applications that will allow citizens and businesses to make immediate comparisons between different models and to choose the one that offers the best result in terms of initial investment and savings over time, not compared to a generic average but in relation to personal usage habits. I have listed two things that I have fought for and that I am proud of, there would be others as well. However, if I have to be intellectually honest, as is my habit, I also feel the duty to share a concern with you. At the beginning of this process, I made a promise that I would be guided by three keywords: smart, paperless and trust. Without a doubt we are facing to a smart regulation in which the use and importance of paper support is reduced in favor of a more fruitful use of digital document technologies and online databases. It is true that this regulation undoubtedly strengthens national market surveillance authorities, but we would have liked more. We would have liked to have provided compensation from the manufacturers in case it is discovered one day that the energy performance of a product is lower than that declared. Parliament wanted it tightly, but unfortunately we found a wall in front of it, the wall of the Council that prevented it. It prevented EU citizens from having the same right as, for example, US citizens defrauded by Volkswagen, who were reimbursed. However, we have obtained from the European Commission, which I thank, a written commitment annexed to this regulation, to study the possibilities of eliminating this absurd legislative gap, which we believe is a real scandal. I am sure that European citizens expect this nonsense to be put to an end as soon as possible.

name: Martina WERNER
text: Author. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The energy label is a European success story. It is present in every household and is known to most consumers in the EU. Over 80% of citizens are familiar with the energy label and use it when they buy a new device. Electrical appliances such as washing machines, refrigerators or dishwashers have become more and more efficient in recent years due to technological progress, so that most of them now have the best, i.e. the A +++ class. In the case of washing machines, that's 73% of all models in this class, so that it is hardly possible to differentiate between the best devices. In addition, we now have an inconsistent classification of the efficiency classes. For vacuum cleaners, A is the best, for washing machines it is the worst efficiency class. And that is totally misleading for consumers. Therefore a reform of the energy label was necessary to end the big mess in the market with misleading energy labels. The new energy label with a uniform scale from A to G for all product groups will enable consumers again to actually save electricity and money. With a meaningful energy label, every household can save up to EUR 500 in energy costs each year, and thanks to the energy label, 19 terawatt hours of electricity can be saved throughout Europe every year. That corresponds roughly to the output of four nuclear power plants. In addition, the regulation also contains measures for stronger market surveillance in the Member States. On the one hand, there will be a publicly accessible information page for consumers in the future. On this website, consumers can find information, compare devices with one another, or look up what the symbols on the energy label are actually actually mean. On the other hand, the regulation also facilitates market surveillance in the Member States. Today it is the case that national market surveillance authorities always have to request technical documents from manufacturers before they can receive them. In the future, all the documents they need to carry out their control tasks, which are so important, will be immediately available on a protected platform. For us Social Democrats, consumer protection was very important. During the negotiations, we also advocated that consumers should actually be compensated for buying electrical appliances with the wrong efficiency class. Unfortunately, however, the Member States have not shown themselves capable of compromising at all. I think that - as my colleague Tamburrano has just mentioned - is very, very unfortunate with regard to the emissions scandals. Now the EU Commission has to answer questions in plenary about this - from my point of view - legal loophole.

name: Claude TURMES
text: Author. - Mister President! We have now negotiated for a long time to reverse a mistake made ten years ago. Remember, under pressure from the Conservatives, here in this house ten years ago we pissed off the industry. At the time, the industry said that instead of having A, B, C - that is, simple energy classes that are easy to understand for the public - move on to A +, A ++, A +++. At the time, we as Greens warned that this would lead to a weakening of information for citizens. And we were right! We were now at a time when the last refrigerator that was still approved was in class A. In other words, the whole labeling regime no longer had any effect. We are improving that today, and that is also the good news. That means, dear citizens out there all over Europe: From now on clear signals again - buy A-devices from refrigerators, freezers and so on. And we have introduced a transparency platform. That means that we will also manage to carry out effective controls at the border of Europe if any junk goods try to get into Europe in order to actually protect the high-class products, which often come from Europe, from inferior quality comes from outside. The whole thing still has one weak point, and that is the question: How do we deal with oil and gas heating in the future? I can see that colleague Reul has just joined us. Herbert fought very successfully to ensure that oil and gas remain in the market forever. I think that if we take climate protection seriously, the moment must come at some point when people in new houses say: We can no longer afford to use fossil fuels in the heating sector. That also has to do with the discussion tomorrow. Tomorrow we'll talk about Trump, about leaving Paris. We can't say “Trump is irresponsible” one day and then not consistently fight for climate protection on the other day in Europe.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Author. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Group of the European United Left has argued from the outset that we need to ensure a consumer-friendly energy labeling system which, however, includes all the necessary information. We therefore welcome the proposals included in the final agreement to remove the misleading symbols and move to a simpler unified labeling system from "A to G". The proposal for the system from "A to G", in combination with the proposal for reclassification of products on the scale based on stricter criteria, in our view will also contribute significantly to the promotion of innovation to increase energy efficiency. Equally important is the decision to create the new digital product database, to which consumers will have free access. This basis should provide as much information as possible about products, but also about consumer rights, in order to enhance transparency and finally put an end to the notoriety and misleading of consumers by large companies. Consumers have a right to have clearer indications of the energy efficiency of a product. Unfortunately, with the schedules set, the positive proposals included in the final agreement will not be promoted in the near future, but after 8-10 years. This is very disappointing and is an important reason to reconsider the agreement. Finally, I would like to emphasize that we demand immediate compensation for consumers who have been deceived into buying products with the wrong energy label. Although this proposal was not included in the final agreement, it needs to be promoted immediately. Commissioner, we welcome the Commission 's statement that the possibility of compensating consumers who have been deceived by energy efficiency labels will be explored. However, we expect from the Commission to clarify immediately further the precise measures it intends to take, including the timetable for these actions, in order to implement its commitments.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by welcoming the excellent agreement reached on the Energy Labelling Regulation between Parliament, the Council and the Commission at the last trilogue in March. We have on our table today a key file from the consumer perspective: the energy label is known and used by over 85% of consumers in Europe when they consider buying new household goods. Energy labelling brings concrete monetary and energy savings. As a result of different measures taken in the context of the European Union’s ecodesign and energy labelling policy, European households can save up to EUR 500 per year on their energy bills. Whilst these measures bring benefits at the level of individual households, they also do so at macroeconomic level by reducing Europe’s energy bill through energy savings and by contributing to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. In this way, they represent a direct contribution to the implementation of the Paris Agreement.  Furthermore, our industries are encouraged to develop increasingly energy efficient products strengthening Europe’s competitiveness and our leading role in driving product energy performance standards at global level. Focusing on energy efficiency first – whether it is for buildings, products or in industry – is more important than ever in order to ensure security of supply and a successful energy transition while promoting investment, growth and jobs. The revision of the framework legislation on energy efficiency for products was one of the first legislative initiatives of the Juncker Commission in the field of energy, adopted already in July 2015.  The agreement reached on the Energy Labelling Regulation represents a good balance between the interests of different parties. Let me briefly highlight what I consider are the key aspects of our agreement.  A pragmatic approach prevailed regarding the use of delegated acts for laying down product-specific labelling requirements. We now have a clear process for re-scaling the existing labels and returning to the more effective A-to-G scale, providing far better information to the consumer. There will be a product registration database that will facilitate the work of national market surveillance authorities and will make it easier for consumers to compare the energy performance of many household appliances. Moreover, we have also succeeded in future-proofing the legislation by introducing provisions on software updates and smart appliances, and explicitly banning the use of defeat devices.  Finally, the label will be able to show information about, for example, durability or reparability, thereby further helping consumers to save money and at the same time contributing to the objectives of the circular economy. With regard to the issue of consumer refunds in the case of non-compliant labels, and in response to the Oral Question tabled by Ms Werner, Ms Rivasi, Mr Tamburrano and Mr Sylikiotis, the Commission fully supports the principle of providing for financial compensation to consumers in the event of wrongly labelled energy-related products.  The Commission made a statement to that effect at the last trilogue in March which will be attached to the Minutes of today’s vote. In this context, it has to be clear that the liability for a non-compliant label, and thus for providing compensation, lies with manufacturers – which are responsible for providing the correct label with their products – and not with retailers.  Therefore, horizontal consumer protection legislation may not provide the right legal framework, given that it generally does not address producers and covers the interaction of customers with their contractual partners. However, the Commission is currently developing legal proposals to strengthen enforcement of European Union harmonisation legislation for products. In this context, possible provisions on consumer compensation should the products they bought not comply with European Union harmonisation legislation, including energy labelling, are under close examination. The Commission aims to come forward with a final legal proposal on this before the end of the year. Now, let me conclude by saying that, in the Commission’s view, today’s agreement will strengthen and future-proof the iconic European energy label. With the newly agreed rules for labelling, this framework will continue to deliver towards our 2030 energy efficiency objectives. On the basis of all these elements, I am confident that the vote in plenary later today will give a strong backing to this important agreement that we have achieved together.

name: Herbert REUL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! It was a painstaking piece of work that we did there, and the project and what the Commission proposed changed quite a bit along the way - Mr Turmes has pointed this out - and I think that was good so that we have also corrected some places. We all want to save energy, and the way to do this by informing citizens that consumers can allow themselves to judge and then decide to buy the device that uses less energy is a very smart and correct way to go . The story has been a success story so far. It wasn't a question of yes or no either. The question was: What should the labeling look like? Do we have to bet on a new picture? Or can we continue to work in the previous picture? We then agreed to make a change, to make it easier, to make it more accessible, because the prevailing view was that the citizens understand this better than these ++ regulations. The second was that we also want to increase the effectiveness and that the citizens, but also the industry and retailers, can deal with it in the implementation, and therefore there have been different timelines. I think that is a wise decision - it is appropriate. We have tried to keep the effort for those who have to relabel and who have to adapt to new situations within a manageable framework. I think that's a pragmatic solution - it's usually a good thing to make such pragmatic suggestions. But in the long term, this will be the right path. When it comes to heating, dear Claude, it makes no sense at all to change this immediately after you've just done such a label. So it's nonsense in the matter, a decision Which device has which efficiency to hit today and to hit again tomorrow, the next day - so you can't handle it that way. The most critical point for me remains the database. I'm not entirely satisfied with that yet. It is a compromise, so I accept it. The point is that data is accessible to consumers, but that data is not accessible to business competitors. Therefore: data protection also applies there, and not only when it suits us, but also for companies that manufacture such products. They have a right to keep their industrial data secret. Thirdly, to this day I have not understood why the Commission needs this data - it does not need it at all! If anything, it is interesting for the citizens and for the control of those - this is the most important thing - who check that the labeling is correct. This is all guaranteed and in this respect a good decision.

name: Dan NICA
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Mr President, Commissioner Cañete, I emphasize the importance of energy-efficient product labeling for consumers, producers and the achievement of the European Union's energy efficiency targets. According to the Commission's assessment, the result of labeling and standards is an energy saving of around 175 million tonnes of oil equivalent by 2020, and a saving of € 465 per year for consumers on household energy bills. In addition, energy efficiency measures will create additional revenues of € 55 billion for European companies. I would like to congratulate the European Parliament's negotiating team, because we need clearer rules on energy labeling to support consumers. One of the main achievements is the return to clearer labeling and the introduction of a public database containing all energy efficiency labels, thus increasing transparency and providing consumers with a better tool for comparing the energy efficiency of household appliances. Unfortunately, the regulation does not reflect, as you rightly pointed out, Commissioner, the protection of consumers who suffer losses due to mislabeling. We therefore, as a political group, support compensation for improperly labeled energy impact products and call for further clarification from the Commission on compensating consumers for non-compliance with the energy class indicated on the label, as well as the timing and possible measures to be taken. the Commission shall take them into account in this respect. I welcome the intention you announced today to come up with some concrete measures by the end of the year.

name: Ashley FOX
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues and the rapporteur for their hard work and cooperation on this energy labelling file. Though discussions were rather slow at times, I am glad we did – at long last – reach an agreement. This new legislation will benefit consumers. They will see an end to the confusing system that includes an A, an A+, an A ++ and an A +++, and revert back to the original system, where A is, in fact, the most efficient product and G is the least. These new labels will prove provide clarity to consumers and will enable them to make more energy efficient and cost efficient choices.  On wrongly labelled products, we prefer to see this addressed as part of a wider review of consumer protection legislation. We have seen that abuses in the motor industry have impacted on consumer confidence, and therefore the introduction of a product database will add much-needed vigour to mass—market surveillance. My Group did have concerns about Mr Tamburrano’s proposals for the product database and the burdens it would place on industry, particularly small manufacturers, but we are satisfied that obligations have been kept to the level where manufacturers only have to submit information necessary for market surveillance. The data will also be open source and allow app developers and retailers to incorporate the information in product searches and filters. This will help consumers to make better choices. Overall, my Group is happy and will support this report.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Energy efficiency is the best and cheapest way to achieve our climate goals. With these revisions, we take the pluses away from the labels, so that consumers get clarity about the performance of their device and we encourage them to choose the most economical product. At the same time it will stimulate producers to develop and produce even more efficient appliances. We opt for an approach that saves companies, from large producers to small traders, unnecessary costs. We share the responsibility for distributing and applying the label, so that everyone knows clearly what their job is. But my focus is mainly on the consumer. Better information leads to better choices. That is why we are creating a database in which app developers and comparison websites can find all the data to provide consumers with a clear overview. At the same time, it is important that we adequately protect consumers. We also saw that this is absolutely necessary in the Volkswagen scandal with the cheating software. For me, that means not only that you give a warranty of at least two years, but also that you can guarantee that cars or devices do not consume or pollute more than indicated. If incorrectly labeled, the consumer should be entitled to appropriate replacements or refunds. I am pleased that the Commission is studying how best to address this in our legislation. Colleagues, with this dossier we show that Europe works for citizens. It is a well-designed and targeted measure that makes every consumer think about their consumption and helps them make the right choices. Consumers will save energy, which is good for our environment, and thus spend less money, which is good for their wallet.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Energy efficiency is a topic that many people talk about, but only in exceptional cases can we find someone who has read at least one of the hundreds of scientific treatises published on this topic in recent years. Because electrical appliances are a number of groups, it is usually very difficult for the general public to compare the products on the market in terms of energy efficiency. Probably the simplest option is to label products that indicate the customer's energy efficiency on a suitably selected scale. The current labeling is somewhat confusing, which is why the latest regulation proposes to shift the whole scale, thus simply distinguishing the different products of a given group. I consider a ten-year cycle in which a similar change can take place to be sufficient. The only disadvantage of this Directive is the postponement of the rescaling for several years after the review date. This provision significantly undermines the possible impact on the public, which is why the GUE / NGL Group will abstain in the final vote on the proposal.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, finally we have an improvement. I have to say that already 10 years ago, when we did the first deal, we warned that a labelling system that goes from A+ to A++++ does not really help consumers understand what is energy efficiency and what is not. But, unfortunately, as happens in Europe sometimes, you need a compromise, you need to see that something is not working well, and then, finally, 10 years later we can improve the system, and that is good.  We have a clearer system now, we do not have the pluses anymore. We have a common database so that we can really check the improvements; so that we know, for sure, that not all the appliances later on will only have ‘A’, meaning there is no real choice for the consumer. But still, and there you see Europe again, we still move slowly sometimes, on boilers and heaters, because now the argument is: well, they just had to adjust to a label and that is why they need until 2030 before they can re-adjust their label.  Really? So now we think that industry needs 15 years to adjust to a label that works for consumers? That is really the lobby of the right. It is not in the interest of the consumers. It is in the interest of the industry, mainly the German industry, in this case. A pretty sad part of this deal, but in the end we are improving. It is a step forward, but please, let us not always fall for the industry’s argument because if we listen to them we will only have labels in 2050.

name: Roger HELMER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, can I say to Mr Eickhout that if we listen to industry perhaps we will have jobs and prosperity. The European Union has hardly covered itself in glory with respect to energy efficiency regulation. Certainly the things we did with kettles and vacuum cleaners attracted ridicule in the UK, and I suspect across the rest of Europe, and tended to bring the European project into considerable disrepute. The problem we face is that we are constantly tinkering with regulations, and the effect of that is to confuse consumers and to create problems for industry. But in my party we reflect on the fact that we shall very soon be out of the European Union and shall be free to make our own rules – and frankly, if the rest of the European Union, the other 27, wish to tie themselves up in absurd red tape, ‘Go for it’ is what I say.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this Europe proves, once again, to be worse than the First Italian Republic. It was not enough for you to destroy the production and jobs of the household appliance sector in recent years. In seven years we have lost 20 million parts produced, we have lost 130,000 jobs, we have lost production of cookers, freezers, air conditioners and washing machines. And the question is: for whom? In favor of the productions of Asian countries? In favor of Korean producers? Today we go even deeper in this direction and we want to persevere in the wrong direction, using the word simplification, using the word "rescaling". In 1998 the European Community established classes A, B, C, D, E, F and G, in 2003 A + and A ++, in 2010 it was not enough and established classes A +, A ++, A +++. Now they say that maybe we were wrong, that we need to go back and then rescaling those classes. Those who have invested today, perhaps to get to an A + will become a G, will become a C. These costs that are poured into the company and production today it is obvious that they will determine a further direction of travel and relocation of our companies. So we will once again relocate our productions. If this Europe really wants to tackle the issue of environmental pollution, it has only one tool: to bring production back to Europe, to bring production back to where there is a culture of respect for the environment. Producing in some countries of the world pollutes more. This is the message. After that we want to reduce costs to the citizen, we need to remove the numerous taxes that are on the kilowatt hour. It is unthinkable that 50% of the cost of a kilowatt hour is determined by taxation of the country, as it is unacceptable to see energy consumption not yet rationed in several halls of Parliament.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: - Sir. Chairman. Congratulations to the rapporteurs who have contributed to this result. The agreement on a new energy labeling scheme is an important step on the way to achieving our climate and energy goals in the future. We know that imports today account for more than 50% of our energy consumption in Europe, and this has been increasing over the last ten years. If we are to get rid of this unpleasant situation, we must, among many measures, make our energy consumption both smarter and more energy efficient. Here we have a place where consumers can play an active role and take part in the green transition if we enable them to make informed choices of white goods and household equipment. Therefore, the agreement on the new energy labeling scheme is a good step in the right direction, and it is even one of the low-hanging fruit we have on our entire agenda. The next step is that in the revision of the Building Directive, we ensure that our homes and our workplaces follow suit in the effort for more energy efficiency, in order to have a more energy efficient Europe. After all, there is no doubt that this is one of the areas where we can really contribute so that we can also take care of our industry in the future.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are all happy and satisfied that finally this revision of the 2010 directive can eliminate that uncertainty and confusion in the face of unclear, often even contradictory, labeling that led the consumer into contradiction. This seems to me the most important element, having brought clarity. I say this, underlining its importance, because I am convinced that making demand, and not supply, protagonist in the energy consumption sector is one of the keys on which we can act to achieve our energy objectives. A more aware consumer is also more informed and, by making things more convenient, is a consumer who goes in the proper sense of saving and efficiency, who chooses the right things even at an appropriate price, but knows what he chooses and what it is. the yield. I insist on this theme of the question. If we really want to achieve an objective of energy rigor, we must take the consumer citizen into consideration. On the one hand this is the lever, on the other hand it is that of technological innovation. I am pleased that there is a review mechanism here which will make the adaptation of labeling to new technological innovations virtually automatic, without having to redo regulations, delegated acts, etc. So simplification, not the things we have heard, the enhancement of the quality of our European industry, not the things we have heard. We are not working against industry, we are working for efficiency, for energy saving, for the enhancement of citizens and also for the benefit of industry.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: - The legislation before us today is an important part of the discussions we have about energy efficiency.With the new measures concerning the energy labels, we can achieve energy savings at European level that are equivalent to the energy consumption of the Baltic states and Italy together, so not to be underestimated.Yet a very important consideration.This is one of the many measures we are taking that could help us achieve the European energy efficiency targets.But what do we see?The proposals for the winter package on energy efficiency make it very clear that the European measures taken in the context of energy efficiency by the Member States cannot be counted towards achieving their objectives.I do have serious questions about that.Because what are we here doing?Then why are we making European rules if they cannot count?

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Mr President, consumers will greatly appreciate the change in product labeling proposed here. The new efficiency scale will put an end to the old model and now, for example, appliances will have a simpler scale, from "A" to "G", eliminating those categories of aes more crossovers, which were quite confusing. We have spoken about it in this House many times. Energy efficiency is, along with saving, one of the central measures to achieve the necessary energy transition and reduce emissions, but it also allows us to reduce our consumption and, therefore, also reduce our bill. Again, what is good for the environment is also good for our pockets. And we believe that this will also be good for the industry, because high efficiency or environmental standards are what make our industry competitive from above and drive innovation, which increases added value and ultimately transforms our productive fabric into a less polluting one. , in line with the weather.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, behind energy efficiency, I fear that once again we are giving Brussels and the European Commission new powers. It is obvious that there is a need for harmonization of labeling as well as a European database for citizens. I've been an absolute fan of energy efficiency since 1980, when I was the leader of energy efficiency among other things here. But, with this proposal for a regulation, we are doing everything to dispossess the States of their prerogatives by moving from the directive to the regulation, by giving the Commission a blank check and by granting it very wide areas to adopt delegated acts, in particular to set the thresholds for the energy performance categories. This logic of disempowering and bureaucratizing our states with national plans to adopt and mandatory reports is not good for Europe. We should be more pragmatic, more decentralized and more subsidiary in our approach, rather than deciding everything from Brussels. Finally, this project is wrong in its approach, by not taking into account the downstream. The consumer must also be informed about the energy performance of the process and the place of manufacture as well as of transport. It is the entire ecological and even, why not, social impact that should be the subject of consumer information. Producing locally also means limiting imports. This is also energy efficiency. Otherwise, we risk doing what we have been doing for decades with our ecological regulations: we export our pollution and we give ourselves a clear conscience in Europe.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, first of all I welcome the proposals here today and again compliment Commissioner Cañete and his team for the good work they are doing in helping us to meet the Paris climate targets. This is one area where a lot can be done in a very easy fashion. Firstly, I am becoming more and more convinced that consumers in general want to reduce their carbon emissions, and all they need is help to do so. This is one area where consumers will embrace what we are trying to do. Simplifying the labelling is absolutely crucial. How could anybody come up with a scheme of A, A+, A++? If you are going to buy an appliance and you see it marked ‘A’, well, you cannot get better than ‘A’ so it does not really make a whole lot of difference whether it is A+ or A++.  But there is a big difference, psychologically, between A and C, and A and G, and also the seven different colours will help consumers. This is the way the European Union needs to move in everything. Make it easier for consumers to understand what it is about and they will comply. One area I have a slight difficulty in understanding is the reference this morning to erroneous labelling. Erroneous labelling would not be possible if there were proper surveillance and proper penalties, because those who would engage in it would actually be put out of business. So I think that that is very important and I think the product database will help to ensure that that does not happen because it will mean proper compatibility of products, proper market surveillance, and will mean that suppliers will try and outbid one another to become more efficient and smarter in the appliances.  So this is actually a great opportunity for us to do something simple, straightforward, that will help us to meet the climate-change targets in Paris. Well done!

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Dario Tamburrano, for his excellent work. What we will vote for tomorrow and after the trialogue is more or less the position of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. I thank the rapporteur, because a few months ago, before renewing the purchase of a washing machine, for example, many people got lost in the labels, without really understanding or knowing the difference in terms of the energy consumption. The system had become illegible, even counterproductive. It was necessary to simplify it. This directive therefore puts itself in the shoes of the citizen consumer. Good news too: the 2.0 label. Thanks to it, the consumer will be able to compare and choose freely in full knowledge of the facts. Each consumer thus becomes a tester. This database will therefore limit fraud. The only downside is that in the case of deception on the label, the Socialists and Democrats would have liked to go further and impose, for example, sanctions, investigations and reimbursements. Let’s remain optimistic, it will come eventually.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, since the beginning of this legislature, the Commission has led the transition of the European economy towards a low-emission, more sustainable economy. Proof of this is the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework, in which 20% of the total budget of the Union is allocated to actions to combat climate change. It was alongside the 2015 summer package that the Commission proposed a labeling review, mainly because with the development of new technologies it was necessary to update the labeling legislation to make it understandable. Mr Eickhout said it: Can anyone tell what the difference is between an A ++ efficiency appliance or an A +++ efficiency appliance? This is what we are talking about. We must clarify the standard so that consumers can, according to their criteria, acquire the products that interest them the most and point out that, thanks to this clarification in the labeling, together with the development of the eco-design package, we can achieve a saving of 500 euros in every European household. And not only that: we can also make our industry more competitive, bringing it a profit of 65 billion euros, according to data from the Commission itself, and savings in energy consumption equivalent to the annual figure for Italy and all the Baltic countries combined. We therefore managed to return to a clarification of the labeling - from "A" to "G", from dark green to deep red - we also introduced a product registration database to ensure that the competent authorities can exercise their supervisory role and we empower citizens, through a public database containing all energy labels, so that they can compare the differences in efficiency between household equipment. For all these reasons, I believe it necessary for us to approve the agreement reached in the trilogue, and I take the opportunity to congratulate once again the rapporteur and to all the shadow speakers for the great job done.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Mister President!Let's say I'm giving a short speech, sort of A ++++.At least that is how it would be classified here according to the previous system of European energy labeling - an absurdity that the Commission has rightly cleared up.No consumer benefits from a label that gives all machines - regardless of whether they are energy-intensive or economical - an A and can only be distinguished by the number of plus signs behind them.In the future there will be recognizable C, D, E sinners again, and that is a good thing.But it is also good that, at the insistence of my group, we were able to avoid excesses of the directive that are hostile to SMEs, such as the subsequent relabeling of devices that have already been delivered.That would have been an unspeakable burden, especially for smaller electrical retailers.Overall, we have achieved a new label that is consumer and seller friendly, and that's a good thing.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Cañete, in Europe we produce very little of the energy we consume and a large part of our energy still comes from fossil sources. We know then how important are actions that favor the energy transition, through a greater use of renewables, but we also know how important it is to reduce energy consumption and therefore increase energy efficiency. With the new regulation on the energy labeling of household appliances and electronic devices, we are taking a step forward in this direction. We have seen that consumers are very careful and, thanks to the labeling system, they choose more advanced appliances that are also able to save them on their bills at the end of the month. On the other hand, thanks to this system, the industry develops increasingly effective models to remain competitive on the market. Experience has shown us that in various cases, such as washing machines and refrigerators, in a few years almost all products have been placed in the highest efficiency classes. Also for this reason, today it is necessary to update the labels, as we have done, by redefining them more clearly, without all those A +, and understandable for consumers.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Tamburrano and Herbert Reul from my Group for an excellent job. What is important in this solution, especially after the discussed and approved corrections, is that the energy enabling framework allows customers to be more aware of the energy efficiency and consumption of household appliances such as dishwashers, televisions and fridges, which will help them to reduce their energy costs. This Regulation also contributes to the moderation of energy demand and the achievement of the Union’s energy efficiency targets, so there are macroeconomic savings and advantages with this solution. It establishes deadlines to replace the current A++ classes with an A to G scale. It also sets out a procedure for rescaling labels based on technological development, thus also providing incentives for innovation and pushing less efficient products out of the market. This will make energy labels more understandable for consumers and help them make better informed purchasing choices. The proposal also contains clearer rules on promotional campaigns and national incentives to promote higher classes of efficiency, and aims to improve enforcement mechanisms and transparency for customers by creating a platform with a database of products covered by energy labelling requirements. The revised energy efficiency label, together with eco-design, can save households close to EUR 500 per year. It has a clear microeconomic advantage. So let us start together, consumers and businesses, the real implementation.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: - I am very pleased that we have agreed with the Council and the Commission on a new energy efficiency label and we have agreed that the current system needs a very significant change. I'm glad to go back to the former measurement scale A to G and move away from that A ++ system. I believe that this is a very good step, because it turns out that the public, perhaps up to 80% of the public, European citizens, look at the energy label when buying an appliance. I firmly believe that this regulation will make it easier for consumers to find their way around energy savings and that they will be better able to differentiate between products. This will also reduce energy consumption and, with it, the amount citizens pay for energy. Among other things, I also consider it essential that the EU reaffirms that energy efficiency is paramount, that it is crucial that we continue to adhere to the motto of efficiency first if we are to achieve the savings and targets of the Clean Energy for All packages. Europeans ’.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the labels indicating the energy efficiency of electrical products such as refrigerators, televisions and washing machines are finally changing, adapting to the digital revolution, by connecting to a database of open and available data through the use of QR Code. it is therefore possible, even in Europe, to efficiently and effectively compare the electricity consumption of different devices at the time of purchase and therefore favor a more conscious and sustainable consumption, calibrated on usage habits and on the price and availability of electricity. It is a small but concrete and important step towards improving the use of resources. However, it is necessary to continue the work, introducing more stringent criteria for the market of electrical appliances and binding producers to the use of smart technologies, capable of adapting to energy consumption and availability. The introduction of transparent and clear labeling, which goes from the confusion of A ++ to a simple scale from A to G is a clear step forward in terms of consumer protection but also industry. However, adequate checks must be ensured to ensure that those labels actually correspond to products with the indicated characteristics.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Tamburrano, on the important report which is really launching interesting developments both for the benefit of consumers and, of course, for the support of European industry. The new labeling process really supports European consumers, because it becomes clearer, because we stop being opaque, we stop being confused. Therefore, this is very important because it enables consumers to make the right choice, a choice with clear criteria. And if this choice is made correctly, it means, of course, a reduction in consumption. Therefore, it also means money in the pocket of the consumer himself. But there must be an arrangement for the compensation of the consumer, who has so far really suffered irreparable damage due to the confusion that has been created. In addition, measures are needed to avoid industries that produce "monkey" products and also create confusion.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - For the current regulation, I was the shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the ENVI Committee. A lot of time has passed since then, and I would almost say that the documentary is coming a little late. In the light of the slowly coming negotiations on the circular economy package, we should rather already be dealing with revisions of ecodesign rules. The link with the energy efficiency directive currently under discussion also remains a major issue. However, more generally, I am relatively satisfied with the outcome of the trilogue negotiations. Changing the range of labels from A to G is a step in the right direction, which will finally shed light on the current confusing and often misleading labeling system for consumers. This could bring new energy savings for households, which will certainly be appreciated not only by them but also by us in further negotiations on energy efficiency. I also very much welcome the publicly available product database. I believe that only a properly informed consumer who has a comparison is able to change his behavior. What has not been completely achieved are the numerous exceptions leading to delays in the process of relabeling certain products. I believe that the whole process is taking an unreasonably long time.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to emphasize that this report is a step forward in terms of labeling. As a member of the IMCO Commission, I support the labeling of any product, and therefore the energy labeling. Let's be fair! Energy labeling leads indirectly to innovation, because there will be competition - who can produce a device that has a lower energy consumption - and one of the objectives of the European Union is energy efficiency. Of course I agree that any consumer who is misled should be compensated. The label must be simple, clear and the consumer has the right to know what he is buying. But I want to point out that it is very important, Commissioner, to see how we label the products entering the internal market in third countries, so as not to create unfair competition for European industry. In a word, I believe that labeling stimulates research, innovation in energy-intensive appliances and fixed assets, and it is necessary to have this labeling system.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I think it is very important for all of us in today's world for the European institutional system to take action that makes the citizens themselves feel that something good is happening to them now. This is the current topic. Incidentally, these labels are much more frequently encountered by the European citizen than any of our other political achievements, but not only with this single type of labeling, but also in the world of food, there is a European Union standardization of labeling. I think that, for the future, it would probably be wisest for the labeling method for food and, for certain industrial products, to become ever closer, to give consumers a glimpse of what is important in almost all important things. hands. Finally, I would like to say that our current efforts are not just about saving energy, but also about consumers making the optimal decision, that is, the issue of prices will have to be taken into account sooner or later, as it is much harder for the poor to turn to more modern but more expensive things. towards.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members for all their contributions to this debate. Allow me to make three remarks. The first is to say that we have the same labelling requirements for imports. It is not only local manufacturers; imports have to be labelled in the same way as products manufactured in the European Union. Many of you expressed concerns about the data, but the best way to ensure data protection is for the Commission to manage the database and also, with the data, we will be able to adjust the labels more efficiently. On heaters, I saw different positions in the House, but I will say that the Commission proposal did not contain a definite requirement to re-scale. We think that it is an improvement that the agreed version contains a timetable and a final date by which the A and B label will only be available for heat pumps, renewables and CHP. We also think that the timetable makes sense and is reasonable because it will provide time and incentives to bring down the cost of these heaters to the benefit of our industry and our consumers.  Finally, I will recall that the energy union is one of the ten priorities of the Juncker Commission and that ‘energy efficiency first’ is one of its leading principles. In this respect, reaching an agreement on one of the key proposals for delivering real energy and monetary savings to European consumers and business is an important step towards the realisation of any union which aims to provide European Union consumers with secure, sustainable, competitive and affordable energy.  This shows that, when there is political commitment and shared objectives, we are able to offer a concrete response to the needs of business and European citizens. Let us keep this positive spirit and dynamic in the ongoing negotiations on the ‘Clean Energy for all Europeans’ package proposals that are now on the table of this House and the Council.  STATEMENTS BY THE COMMISSION - This is word for word what was read out by the Commission at the last trilogue on 21 March 2017: Commission statement on financial compensation for consumers: "In view of its ongoing efforts to strengthen the enforcement of Union harmonisation legislation for products, the Commission - in order to address potential financial loss by consumers due to wrongly labelled products or inferior energy and environmental performance than labelled - should investigate whether compensation for consumers in case of non-compliance with regard to the energy class displayed on the label can be addressed." Can the Commission support the statement on delegated and implementing acts as proposed by the Council? - The statement referred to is the following: Statement by the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on Articles 290 and 291 TFEU: "Recalling the Inter-institutional Agreement on Better Law-Making of 16 April 2016, in particular, its paragraph 26, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission declare that the provisions of this Regulation shall be without prejudice to any future position of the institutions as regards the application of Articles 290 and 291 TFEU in other legislative files." - The Commission can support this statement, as this declaration is in line with the Inter-institutional Agreement, and can be seen as a perpetuation of a similar declaration made at the time of the adoption of previous Energy Labelling Directive in 2010.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: speaker. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I have listened carefully to the various speeches. Of course I appreciate the compliments, but I also appreciate some criticisms, especially those criticisms that have been addressed to the regulation, which are not instrumental criticisms to declare something in the plenary to attack someone, even wrong dates and data, but those criticisms that are objective. There are actually some things that could be done better and label rescaling, particularly for boilers and boilers, is another gripe. It could have been anticipated, but I trust in the Clean Energy Package and we will fight to create an environment at European level so that gas boilers are somehow progressively put out of the market, especially in the new regulations regarding energy efficiency in buildings and active and intelligent buildings. However, I hope that one thing will be resolved as soon as possible - and here I return to the subject of the oral question - and that is that this legislative vacuum in the European Union will be put to an end. European citizens deserve compensation if they are defrauded. This is true for energy labeling, as it is for all EU labeling systems. Without compensation and without supervision, any labeling system risks not receiving the right and necessary trust from consumers.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, 13 June 2017. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - There was no harmonization of the energy efficiency labeling of European household appliances. This dusty observation will soon be classified in the broom cupboard. We therefore propose a unique labeling calibrated from "A to G" to provide clearer information to consumers and reduce their energy consumption. This measure also aims to lower the consumption of European citizens by 200 billion Kw / h: a substantial saving for their wallet. In addition, all new products placed on the EU market will have to be registered in an online database, which will provide increased transparency and facilitate market surveillance by national authorities. 85% of European consumers take the energy index into account when shopping. However, up to 25% of products placed on the market do not comply with energy labeling requirements. It was therefore urgent to rectify the situation and improve the situation of the consumer.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on mandatory annual reductions in greenhouse gas emissionsby the Member States in the period 2021-2030, with a view to achieving a resilient energy union and meeting commitments under the Paris Agreement, and amending Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010.Regulation (EC) No 525/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council on a mechanism for monitoring and reporting greenhouse gas emissions and other information relevant to climate change (COM (2016) 0482 - C8-0331 / 2016 - 2016/0231 (COD)) (A8-0208 / 2017).

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, the most powerful signal that the European Parliament can give is that it is serious about tackling climate change and is taking real action implementing the Paris Agreement by passing the climate action regulation tomorrow. It deals with almost two-thirds of all greenhouse gases emitted across the EU. This law will translate the Paris Agreement into concrete action by the Member States.  However, last week President Trump announced that he would withdraw the United States from the Paris climate change agreement. Even though we know that many US states, cities and businesses are continuing or even scaling-up climate action and green investment. This is sending a dreadful signal to the rest of the world. But, thankfully, China has restated their strong commitment to the Paris Agreement and President Macron has announced that France will do more compared to earlier commitments. So, with or without Trump, climate action and green investment under the Paris Agreement must move ahead.  I applaud that the groups here in the European Parliament have decided to unanimously give a strong signal to the international community that it will support this report in plenary tomorrow. I am also grateful for the strong support the report received in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) and for the further work done ahead of the plenary to build an even stronger compromise.  As a result of this work, ALDE, the EPP and ECR groups agreed to table a set of joint amendments that will do three things: firstly, maintain the strength and emissions trajectory adopted by the ENVI Committee. The trajectory will secure the delivery of our 2030 target under the Paris Agreement.  Secondly, it will increase the optional use of forest credits from 119 million to 280 million tons, which will help build the business case for forest-based climate measures. In the long term, our forests are crucial to build the zero-carbon economy. At the same time, we must maintain a strong driver for energy efficient and clean transport.  Thirdly, we will give better support to lower—income Member States that have reduced their emissions significantly in earlier years. There are 17 Member States that will benefit from these measures. Farming is also covered in this regulation, and we will include special support for climate—efficient farmers. We must recognise the specific situation of the farming sector and ensure that they can continue to produce but protect at the same time.  The compromises reached will represent a balance between delivering on the EU’s commitments on the one hand, and providing fairness for all Member States and regulating the regulated sectors on the other. Because of the politically balanced agreement reached and the strong signal the climate action regulation will give to the international community, I urge you all therefore to back the report in full, which includes the compromise package negotiated ahead of the plenary vote.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to be here today in the plenary for the effort-sharing proposal. This is an important initiative to accelerate the low-carbon transition of key sectors of the economy in Europe, representing around 60% of European Union total emissions. The latest greenhouse gas emissions statistics, which the European Environment Agency released only two weeks ago, clearly point to the challenges. Emissions, in this sector, outside emissions trading, are increasing again, notably in the transport sector.  This debate, and the vote tomorrow, show that the European Union is serious about international climate commitment under the Paris Agreement and that it wants to progress without delay with domestic implementation. At the same time, Parliament is also making swift progress on one of the key legislative priorities of the European Union, and in the joint declaration on the European Union’s legislative priorities for 2017 the three institutions have agreed that the 2030 climate action proposals shall be given priority treatment in 2017.  I very much appreciate the hard work of your rapporteur, Mr Gerbrandy. He would have been happy to be here today but unfortunately he cannot be with us. On this proposal, I want to thank him for the excellent cooperation and I also want to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their efforts in ensuring that Parliament’s report could be presented to the plenary before the summer. Many of the key elements of what you are proposing for the vote in this House tomorrow are in line with the Commission proposals, notably on the national targets and connection between sectors with the use of the flexibilities. This is encouraging for us. As in the Commission proposals, this maintains a careful balance of three central objectives: fairness, cost-efficiency and environmental integrity.  I also note your efforts to better reward early action, which is also a central issue in the discussions in the Council. The LULUCF flexibility proposed by the Commission is of high importance and its extent should be sufficient enough to recognise the lower mitigation potential of agriculture and incentivise actions promoting carbon sequestration in agricultural soils and afforestation. Let me offer a few comments on two key aspects of the rapporteur’s final proposals. Firstly, the report adopted by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) includes a requirement for Member States to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in effort-sharing sectors by 80% by 2050 compared to 2005. It is true that consistent and long-term emission reductions are a cornerstone of European Union climate policy. However, I think it is too early to set national targets and emission trajectories for 2050 now already, without any thorough impact assessments and even before the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has provided its special report.  We must also consider the balance with the ETS and with a policy related to land use, land-use change and forestry. We should not set in stone now partial long-term legislation only covering 60% of total European Union emissions. The Commission will address the long-term issues in the context of developing the European Union mid-century strategy, which, in accordance with the G7 Commission, is to be delivered well ahead of the 2020 deadline. Secondly, I note the proposal for a biennial compliance check instead of every five years. This would significantly increase the misery burden of implementation and would not constitute a good example of better regulation.  The Commission fully supports the efforts of Parliament and the Council to agree on the ETS and non-ETS proposal this year. On the ETS file, we are in trilogue negotiations and I welcome the renewed efforts to make progress there. I look forward to continuing to work with you on the effort-sharing proposal and bringing it to a successful conclusion with your support.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - (FI) Mr President, Commission, ladies and gentlemen, thank you all very much for your very constructive and constructive cooperation. I hope we will always remember that we are not reducing emissions for the EU or for governance, but for the future of humanity and our planet. As we monitor this responsibility, especially from the transport sector, and the implementation of measures in the future, we should remember that, according to subsidiarity, the ball is very much in the hands of the Member States, and especially in their urban areas. Urban areas and Member States have a vital role to play in combating both CO2 emissions and other emissions that are harmful to health. Urban transport accounts for 23% of Europe's CO2 emissions, but unfortunately the EU has no direct competence over urban transport policy and solutions. I therefore hope that, in all its activities, the Commission will promote the duplication and promotion of good practice in good cooperation between the Member States, so that we can focus funding on all projects specifically on reducing emissions.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's proposal on effort sharing is an excellent start to ensure, in the sectors concerned, the goal of reducing emissions by 30% by 2030. However, some changes are needed to better promote the long-term predictability, ensure consistency with other policies, in particular the energy efficiency target, as well as ensure sufficient flexibility and solidarity between Member States. Effort sharing can in fact be an important driver to favor the decarbonisation of the economy and to fulfill the Paris agreement. The agricultural sector is responsible for 10% of greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union and must therefore necessarily play its part. Agriculture is the sector that will suffer the most from the impacts of climate change, but at the same time there are also agricultural practices that can lead to a reduction in emissions and offer additional environmental benefits and additional income for farmers. Flexibility in the LULUCF sectors, in particular the significant mitigation and uptake potential from forests, is key to reducing compliance costs and to ensure additional support for agriculture that must contribute to climate action. However, it is essential to ensure that LULUCF credits ensure real additional and permanent takeovers.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, within the proposals of the climate change package, this refers to the effort that the so-called diffuse sectors have to make: agriculture, transport and construction, buildings, which they will have to reduce by 30% of its emissions compared to 2005. The country targets have been negotiated by the Commission and the Council, and Parliament has respected them and has not wanted to touch them. Our debate has been and has focused - which has not been easy at all, by the way - fundamentally on the date of the beginning of the trajectory and on the flexibilities. The agreements embodied in the compromise amendments that we will vote on tomorrow are acceptable. They are manageable and they are balanced. What my political group likes the least is the start of the trajectory in 2018, but it is a negotiation and we have all had to give in. We are, however, reasonably satisfied with a LULUCF flexibility of 280 million tons of carbon. We would have liked it to have been a floor and not a ceiling, as we have agreed in the end, but it is what we have agreed. An early fulfillment reserve of 90 million tons is very satisfactory, because it can alleviate the effort of some countries that have been less favored in sharing the effort. The flexibility linked to the cancellation of emission rights is also acceptable. As I said, it has not been easy at all. I want to thank Mr. Gerbrandy very warmly for his flexibility and his willingness to settle. We all have the ultimate desire and ambition for everything to be good. Finally, the paper holds everything, the wishes are highly commendable, but in the end this translates into an effort for the economic sectors that are the ones that create jobs and, ultimately, those that sustain our system.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being here with us and also Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy who, as the rapporteur of this effort sharing regulation, worked really hard on bringing the Groups together. Unfortunately, for a long time, we had people who considered climate change to be a fictitious thing – this is happening today as well: if you pretend that it is not real, it will literally disappear. We know today that climate change is affecting every country in every continent. What we face today is a difficult task but an achievable one. The task before us goes beyond the choices that individuals privately make. This is about industries and it is about governments making the right choices and taking concrete measures. This is our moment for action. We had the opportunity to make serious policies with the emissions trading scheme and this is our opportunity now with this regulation. We need to end once and for all the free ride that polluters have been given. This is not a technical debate but I believe that this is a human rights debate because our citizens and our children have a right to a cleaner world. As Socialists and Democrats, we believe that it is our duty to respond properly to our planet’s greatest challenge with determination and honesty. I am proud that this political group was part of a group that stopped the attempts to water down this legislation. This is what we worked hard to achieve in the effort sharing regulation. There are no excuses: our economy will die if our ecosystems collapse. The climate action legislation sets a clear trajectory to 2030, and a longer-term objective up to 2050, to reduce emissions in important sectors including transport, agriculture, buildings and waste. I would say to the Commissioner that we need to think now if we want to ensure our future and we need to have a long-term perspective. This Parliament must have a progressive and ambitious stand on these measures, closing loopholes and making sure that Member States reduce their emissions; ensuring also that all sectors contribute to a proper reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.  We pushed for more compliance checks, yes; every two years. Unlike the Commissioner, we know that this can be done and we want to be ambitious and we want to have something that really works. We aligned the review cycle with the global stocktake of the implementation of the Paris Agreement as well. We believe that we have the means to stop this devastation but we need to have the political will to do so. This is our opportunity to really show that we are ready to stand up to the occasion. It is no longer time for watering down legislation, because we can make a positive impact. If we do not act now, the effects of climate change will become even worse.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! I appreciate the efforts of the rapporteur, who tabled amendments to the plenary, following the vote in the ENVI committee, also taking into account my concerns. It is good that the rapporteur is restoring the flexibility mechanism of 280 million tonnes of carbon dioxide from the LULUCF sector, extending it to forestry. It is a pity, however, that my proposal to increase the flexibility mechanism to 425 million tonnes, so that we promote the development of forests and proper forest management practices, which is in line with the spirit of the Paris Agreement, has not been understood. Good action in the forestry sector offset emissions significantly. Moreover, I find it unfair to allocate units to promote richer countries. Setting a benchmark for 2016-2018 is detrimental to poorer countries. In order to maintain policy continuity, it is necessary to set an emission level starting at the end of the current trading period. I also disagree with raising reduction ambitions by setting a trajectory for lowering them from 2018. As for the proposed reserve for poorer countries, it will minimally compensate for their huge effort. So the position voted by ENVI is unacceptable in this form.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, this is in very many ways a discussion about balances and imbalances. We have a lot of political imbalances, we have a lot of environmental imbalances and we have a lot of economic imbalances, and they all act together. Sometimes in a happy way, usually in a less than happy way. The question about these three files – effort-sharing, emissions trading, and land use, land-use change and forestry – is in the same way a triangle and a very difficult one. It could turn out to be a Bermuda Triangle in which money, hope and environment are those things, or it could show itself to be a functional but very precarious triangle where all the three parts are deeply interconnected. If we are not able to keep up the emissions trading part of it, then things will fall down under effort-sharing and ultimately in the sinks in the forests. So, we need to have a very strong political approach to the problems we are seeing here.  If we do not manage this, if we give in to bad information, bad tweets from the Tweet House – formerly it was called the White House but it has got a new name: the Tweet House – if you do not do this properly, we are doomed. Therefore, the question of how we manage effort-sharing is of utmost importance and I think that Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy has done a terrific job to be able to put the pieces together and be slightly ahead of the curve, because we know that the closer we come to 2040-2050, the harder it will be. So thank you, but now we are in for a fight.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Allow me to thank my colleague Gerbrandy in advance, who I think did not give up, even though it seemed for a while that we would not actually find a consensus. However, we are here today and on the agenda of the plenary session we have the second flagship document for combating climate and greenhouse gas emissions in the EU, which also involves previously much pointlessly neglected sectors such as transport, buildings and, above all, agriculture. In recent years, we have only heard from these sectors how nothing is going on. The Effort Sharing Regulation is the link between the EU ETS and LULUCF documents and other policies. Today, more than ever, in the light of the backward and utterly meaningless steps taken by the current US administration, it is important that we approve this regulation in an ambitious and strong version, passed by the ENVI Committee, before the Environment Council itself. We need to demonstrate our continued commitment to combating climate change. The negotiations have been difficult and I cannot say that I am completely satisfied with everything that has gone through. I am not particularly satisfied with the next newly established allowance reserve or with other interventions in the not yet functioning MSR. However, I believe that we have managed to adopt a sufficiently ambitious document. I am pleased, for example, that we have succeeded in adopting an amendment involving the remaining maritime transport, which we do not address in the ETS amendment. That is why I would not like to see his boning, as happened a few months ago in plenary, for example at the ETS. I would like to ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to give us a strong mandate for the trialogue, so that what we are experiencing in the ETS does not happen to us, and let us really be who we want to be. Those who want to protect EU citizens want to protect the environment and care about it.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Gerbrandy and express my regret that he cannot be here today for personal reasons. I very much regret this because he really put a lot of effort into this file and it is a pity that he cannot be here. Our thoughts are certainly with him. Secondly, I would like to say that it is a bit strange that tomorrow we are going to discuss Trump withdrawing from the Paris Agreement and today we are going to discuss our own actions. I can tell you that the Greens tried to link those two discussions. A strange idea, is it not: that we link criticism of Trump together with what we ourselves are doing within the EU?  But the big parties, especially the Christian Democrats, did not want to link them and we know why: because it is much easier to criticise Trump, for free, while at the same time knowing that in our own actions we are not doing enough to implement the Paris Agreement at all. But of course we are happy to have that debate on another day.  That is really my main criticism, too, in this Parliament. When you criticise Trump tomorrow, remind yourselves at the same time of what we are doing ourselves. First of all – and we really know all this – the current target on the table that the EU is willing to take of minus 40% by 2030 is not enough for the implementation of the Paris Agreement. Stop saying that the EU is implementing the Paris Agreement. We are not on track. Secondly, if you look at the two pieces of legislation on the table, we are watering it down. We are creating loopholes – loopholes in the legislation – so that this minus 40% is not even really minus 40%. That is not at all good. The Commission’s proposal had too many loopholes. We improved the Commission’s proposal. Unfortunately there are a couple of amendments on the table again – in order to get the Christian Democrats on board – to go back to the size of the Commission’s loophole, so we are going backwards again, watering the proposal down again, but okay, that is what the Christian Democrats wanted and I hope that they will acknowledge this tomorrow when they criticise Trump.  But it is an improvement compared to the Commission’s proposal and the big fight will be with the Member States, because they are also criticising Trump but at the same time watering down the proposal even further. So please, ladies and gentlemen, let us vote for this and then we will have our proposal on the table.
