But when we are doing the negotiations, think every time that you criticise Trump that you are only credible in criticising him if you deliver at home.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, over the years I have witnessed in this House the perverse mechanism of the EU continuing to further develop a failing project. In the UK, we would say that this amounted to flogging a dead horse. The EU ETS is an example of this. However, in this instance, the project is one of the biggest threats to European industry and competitiveness. Once again, we are expanding and strengthening its remit. This time the European Commission proposal, Climate Action Regulation implementing the Paris Agreement, covers all sectors that currently fall outside the EU emission trading system, with particular regard to transport, waste, environment and agriculture. The aim of this proposal is to deliver, in the relevant sectors, 30% emissions reductions by 2030 compared to 2005 levels. The Paris Agreement sets out the goal to keep global temperature increases well below 2 °C and to strive for no more than 1.5 °C temperature increase. Consistent with these goals, the Paris Agreement also requires that zero net emissions must be achieved in the second half of this century. In addition, in 2009, the EU adopted its objective of 80—95% greenhouse gas emission reductions by 2050.  The EU’s climate and energy policies keep perpetuating the same misguided path, continuing to be the solo leader in the futile battle against climate change, whereas the USA and others are acting in favour of progress and prosperity. The sole effect that this huge burden of climate regulation is going to have is to exacerbate the crisis already being experienced by European Union industries that are forced to move offshore, taking their emissions and their jobs with them. My party and I oppose the EU climate and energy policy. We reject climate hysteria and believe that the EU should accept that the Paris Agreement is close to its end.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the announced withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement more than ever justifies action within the framework of international organizations of which the United States is still a member. It should be remembered that the vast majority of European states are also part of the United Nations framework convention on climate change or of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) for the aviation sector or of the International Maritime Organization (IMO) in the maritime field? Also, it is not the signing, ratification and application of the Paris Agreements by the European Union that will bring the United States back to the heart of pragmatic, effective and global climate action. Finally, the European Union is not with one contradiction in wanting to reduce emissions on the one hand, while defending, on the other hand, models of free trade which only worsen these emissions. In ecological matters, short circuits, the relocation of companies and economic patriotism, which we have been offering for years, are not the problem, but the solution.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, global warming, depletion of natural resources and waste management are problems that require international cooperation, awareness-raising and the application of innovative technologies without artificial dilemmas and away from selfish private or national interests. Unfortunately, although it took about 25 years since the 1992 Rio de Janeiro Earth Summit and the ratification of the Kyoto Protocol, the Paris Agreement lacks legal commitment, as evidenced by the imminent withdrawal of the United States from the United States. . The protection of the environment concerns man and his survival and should not be the scope of micropolitics or the pursuit of interests between states. As a nationalist, I believe that energy efficiency and security can coexist with the protection and sound management of biodiversity and at the same time reduce consumer bills, through strict compliance with national environmental law.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur Gerbrandy. He worked hard and I think in the end there is now a good compromise. We should send him the right greetings tomorrow, with a good vote, in his difficult situation. But I would also like to thank everyone else who helped, especially Pilar Ayuso, the EPP's shadow rapporteur. Dear colleague Bas Eickhout, we will vote on this result tomorrow immediately after the debate on Trump. I think that is correct, we need a little time to sort it out between today and tomorrow, but if we have a large majority for the Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy report tomorrow, then that is exactly the right sign in the direction of the USA and in the whole world. We are ambitious with this proposal. We agree that the start date will be 2018 - that is more ambitious than the Commission's proposal. We also agree - even if this is a challenge for some countries, but it is internationally important - that no country will have a base year value that is less ambitious than the 2020 target - that is the correct answer. But we are not over-ambitious. Some Member States have challenges: I will mention Ireland, I will mention Spain and Italy, and we are responding to this with the flexibility in the ALDE, EPP and ECR amendments, which are better and more appropriate than what the Environment Committee has decided. That is why I believe: Be ambitious but realistic - that is the right answer to Trump, not overambitious, because then we will not be taken seriously either. That is why I am campaigning for a large majority for the report and the amendments from the EPP, ALDE and ECR. Then we'll give the correct answer to Trump.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the United States President Trump is seriously questioning the need to fight against climate change, while in Great Britain the support of those who deny even the existence of the phenomenon is sought to form the government. Well, here in the European Parliament, with the approval of this regulation for the reduction of CO2 emissions in transport, buildings, agriculture and waste management, we want to send out a clear message: our future and that of the next generations passes by a more sustainable society and economy. Europe is aware of this and also knows that in order to obtain results, action must be global, because CO2 emissions do not stop at the borders of those who produce them. I call this text on effort sharing a good text, an ambitious text, but also an absolutely pragmatic one, which above all provides a good system of flexibility for the Member States, precisely to enable them to achieve the objectives that are envisaged. If managed well, the transition to a low-carbon system is not only beneficial for the environment but also for the thriving economic growth of our societies. It is no coincidence that one of the criteria envisaged by this regulation for establishing reduction targets for individual Member States is precisely the average level of GDP per capita. The efforts made up to now are recognized and the specificity of the various territories can be flexibly enhanced, from those with a more industrial vocation to those with an agricultural or woodland vocation. Nobody is asked to do the impossible, but to contribute best. Effort sharing is effort sharing. We move forward, convinced and I can tell you, returning from a work mission in the United States, that beyond the big claims, millions of Americans also believe in it.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: - Sir. Chairman! I would also like to say thank you to everyone, and this is of course a good day where we can discuss what really happened, why we did not get the climate certification in the agreement, so you can show who it really is. have done something, and recognize these people. We know that there are some countries that pay high taxes, high taxes and of course do a lot in this area. But we must also say that there must be this burden-sharing between rich and poor. We must have the flexibility, we must recognize that we have some technology that must be transferred to some of the countries that could be better contributors to us being able to do more for the climate. So therefore it is our intention that you just get the opportunity to show that you have some proven technology that will help the climate in the future, and we think that is the way we should go, and therefore it is It is good that in this way you can create a burden distribution that can benefit everyone, but also take everyone into account.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: - Dear colleagues, Commissioner, the Paris climate conference recognizes the importance of the agricultural sector for our food supply. Yet the agricultural and horticultural sector is still too often put in the corner, while the agricultural and horticultural sector has a unique characteristic. The agricultural sector is one of the few sectors that can also extract greenhouse gases from the air and convert them into organic matter in the soil. A win-win situation, because this also improves the soil quality of our agricultural land. It is therefore right that captured greenhouse gases are included in the climate objectives. It is now up to the Member States to come up with a model in which farmers and horticulturists are actually rewarded for capturing greenhouse gases. This can be done, for example, with a CO2 trading system or by giving more business space. In addition, Dutch agriculture and horticulture are already at the forefront of innovations that lead to increasingly lower emissions of greenhouse gases per kilogram of food. Unfortunately, European legislation blocks innovations to turn the surplus of animal manure into fertilizer substitutes. According to calculations, this allows us to reduce the consumption of fertilizer by 15%, and thus also the emission of greenhouse gas. In the agricultural sector, this is not the problem, but part of the solution. Flexibility within legislation and regulations is, however, necessary to offer farmers and market gardeners the opportunity to continue to innovate.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Mr. President, in recent days Trump has removed from the Paris Agreement one of the most polluting countries in the world, along with China, while false tools are used here in the fight against climate change. The report is a very small step. Make no mistake: today we already know that we will not achieve the objectives set by the Paris Agreement. Commitments on paper are useless when everything is based on buying bonds to continue sweeping the planet and doing business. In Spain, Rajoy says that a change is needed and, nevertheless, he punishes self-consumption. Here, Cañete opens the doors to energy lobbies, the most polluting on the planet. Because the only thing you guys know how to do is help your friends from the multinationals. And what this planet is crying out for is a radical change in the productive model in our way of life, of consumption, in our relationship with nature; a change that will only come from the hand of a conscious and committed citizenry, because what we are at stake today, in this House, is the future of this land.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Paris Agreement is not dead, if anything the Paris Agreement is forgotten when, as in this amendment to the regulation, we have even changed its title, recalling precisely the actions to be taken in line with the Paris Agreement. In my opinion, we are unfortunately far from embarking on a real road that really looks in the direction of the Paris objectives, also because the results of recent studies tell us that the possibility of reducing and maintaining the global temperature increase within 1.5 C ° will not be reached and could already happen by 2030. This should give us the urgency of our need to act, especially in this regulation which is part of the second pillar of climate policies together with the ETS, another instrument that does not work and which does not favor investments in clean technologies and truly sustainable production and which above all gives us an example of how the proceeds from auctions are not used appropriately, for example, which should and could be used precisely to improve and make investments in the mitigation of emissions in the effort sharing sectors. No Member State has done so to date. Unfortunately, we are facing yet another agreement that actually makes fun of public opinion. They are empty words, without real content. I do not agree with the rapporteur's attempt to keep all the big groups in the boat, especially the conservative groups that have done everything to dismantle this document and dismantle its ambition. We are about to go to a trilogue with the Council and we cannot afford to once again demolish the ambition of one of the pillars of policies to combat the climate.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Before I give the floor to my colleague, Mrs McGuinness, I would like to take this opportunity to wish her a happy birthday. She is speaking on her birthday, but still has just one and a half minutes. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I would like to take ten seconds to thank the visitors to Parliament for wishing me a happy birthday – and no, I am not going to tell you what age I am, but it is all transparent and it is available – and thank you, Mr President.   Now to the subject of this debate, because Mr Liese and Mr Huitema introduced the topic on my agenda: Ireland and agriculture. I know, Commissioner, that you are fully familiar with our problems in Ireland, because we have a strong and large agricultural sector. We are doing a lot of work on climate—smart agriculture, but there is only so far we can go.  I am all for ambition, and, Mr Eickhout, I hope you appreciate that. However, ambition with targets that are unachievable can be distracting, and our 2020 target was unachievable. We know that we have to do more, but what I would ask colleagues to understand is the situation where we do not have heavy industry, we have a large agricultural sector and we need much more flexibility on this issue, because farmers are concerned that the cost of this at the moment – if we look at the calculations – would be over EUR 1.7 billion in terms of purchasing carbon.  I do not want an opt-out here, because we all have duties and responsibilities, but I want an understanding that we are major producers of food – we export it to Europe and beyond – and we need an acknowledgment of that fact in the work, and I hope that in the negotiations it will be acknowledged.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have the heavy responsibility of defining the climate policy of the European Union for the next thirty years. The climate emergency obliges us and calls on us to take measures that meet the expectations and the awareness of our fellow citizens, to face the challenge of our century: the future of our planet. The text we are debating today aims to translate into European legislation the climate commitments that the Union and the Member States have made under the Paris Agreement. It is therefore about moving from speech to action. At a time when Donald Trump has made the decision to leave the Paris Agreement, it is more than ever crucial that the European Union honor its commitments in the fight against global warming. This report, which raises the level of ambition of the European Commission proposal by setting long-term objectives by 2050, by limiting certain flexibilities and by strengthening the control of efforts and the review clause to revise upwards the binding objectives, will send this strong political signal so that the European Union assumes leadership in the implementation of the Paris Agreement. Consequently, I call on MEPs to vote in favor of the whole report adopted by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. We cannot rejoice in the plenary session on the ratification of the Paris Agreement and then, once the texts are on the table, try to lower the level of ambition of the European Union.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Fake news is on the wrong side of history.Today we can show that the European Union is keeping its word and is implementing the Paris Agreement.We owe it to our children and our grandchildren to shoulder that responsibility now.The fight against climate change is a matter of effort, but also of opportunities, and everyone must do their bit.After all, climate is not a responsibility of the government alone.Flanders is on the right track.The 2020 target is within reach.Achieving the 2030 goals will require a lot of additional effort.But Flanders is determined to take up that challenge.The Flemish government, under the leadership of Prime Minister Geert Bourgeois, is working hard on this.Finding a delicate balance between ambition and feasibility remains a challenge, however, and bringing forward the start date remains a concern for us in this sense.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: - Mr President! First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur on a very good job, especially a thought to our colleague Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, who unfortunately cannot be here this week for personal reasons, but who has put in a lot of hard work to ensure that we can deliver a broad compromise in this House that carries climate policy forward in a responsible manner. I also think it is extremely important that we do not let the President of the United States set the agenda for European climate policy. When Donald Trump now chooses to turn away from ambition and from climate responsibility, we actually have a great opening for Europe to do even more that will lead to us getting innovations, that we get new companies and that we can lead a technological development towards a better world, which creates tomorrow's industry and tomorrow's energy supply. The part we are talking about now, effort sharing, is an important part of the climate package, together with the ETS, where we trade, and which more affects the industry. But it is also important that the energy package we have on the table now becomes good and powerful legislation that builds on what we now say we will do through effort sharing. There is also a lot to be done about the Renewable Energy Directive, for example. There is a risk that, with a good will to save the environment, we will be shutting down the renewable fuels, which are in fact the ones that will ensure that we are able to cope with the energy transition and that will create new jobs in rural and European agriculture. Today we are taking a big step forward, but of course there is a lot of work left with the technical legislation.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I am sceptical in many ways towards the European Union, but on this, I think it is a challenge that we should meet. Unlike the drive for a single currency or the current drive for a European army, this project is in our interests. But, if we want it to be in our interests, we have to bring the people along with us. Mairead McGuinness, MEP and Vice-President for Parliament, talked about the challenges to Irish farming. There can be benefits if we meet this challenge; there can be benefits in producing our proteins locally, rather than bringing them thousands of kilometres across an ocean; there can be benefits in recycling the animal manure and reusing the energy and the fertiliser, saving on heavy use of energy in chemical fertilisers. There can be use in reusing water. In many cases in Ireland, we are using treated water. This can all bring benefits to the farming community, and we need to sell it to people by showing that there will be financial benefits locally, because if we produce locally, people can stay locally and everyone is happy and the planet benefits.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Commissioner Cañete, I believe that the subject we are talking about is an important subject because it moves from theory to practice. After the Paris Agreement we try to put it into practice with the relevant regulation. Of course, Trump, with a certainly myopic vision, gave a different line, but there is no denying that American states, big cities and large companies tend to say every day, more and more, that instead on the line of Paris Agreement must continue to operate. Europe must be a leader in this, it must be a leader internationally and globally. The proposal that has been put on the table is an interesting proposal. Parliament has certainly improved it and corrected some errors that there were, Commissioner, because the early movers, i.e. the countries that had already made a great effort and had already moved forward, had difficulties in implementing the proposal and you recognized, from the very first presentation, that there was something to correct. Parliament has today implemented the corrective measures. With the reserve of 90 million tonnes proposed by my colleague Gerbrandy, I believe that we are heading in the right direction. Italy will be able to implement this proposal, which at the beginning was certainly very adverse to our country. On the other hand, Parliament's ambition, that we as EPP have agreed to anticipate the downward curve in the application of the agreements, is in the right direction. I believe we are working well and should vote on the proposed amendments. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Thank you very much, fellow Member, for accepting this question.You also mentioned the procrastination of the American president, or rather I would say his stagnation.I ask how worrying this is, in your opinion, as the business sector in America itself seems to be going far beyond renewable energy sources?

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: answer to a "blue card" question.- I believe that the impact of Trump's choice is a very limited impact for two reasons.First, because many states, large cities and large companies want to continue along the line of the Paris Agreement.On the other hand, the procedure for exiting the Paris Agreement is a complex procedure, which takes some time, and I am sure that in any case the next American government, of whatever color it is, will review its position on the fight against climate change andthey will have to make up for lost time.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: - Mr President, the European Union and other global actors have reacted with force and unity to the decision of the United States to withdraw from the Paris Agreement. We have chosen international cooperation at the expense of isolation and we will continue to play a decisive role in combating the serious threat posed by climate change. The regulation we will vote on is an important component of the EU's climate change policy during the Paris Agreement. It will ensure significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions in sectors that are now responsible for more than half of EU emissions. The legislation must be ambitious. At the same time, however, we must avoid it having disproportionate economic effects on lower-income Member States. By linking emission reduction targets to GDP, this legislation will ensure that countries that have tough targets can even afford to meet them.

name: Norbert LINS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Today we are responding to the American President: We are sticking to the Paris Climate Agreement, and we are implementing it in a balanced way. We are doing this in particular with the three proposals: CO2 reductions in our industry, now today's proposal for greenhouse gas reductions in traffic, buildings, waste and agriculture and in the third proposal the CO2 absorption capacity of our forests, i.e. the so-called LULUCF sector. All sectors are closely related with so-called flexibilities and only make sense as a unit. The role of agriculture and forestry is very important. It is part of the solution, not the problem. In order to be able to exploit the potential of CO2 reduction - in 2012, for example, that was 9% of the total emissions of all sectors - the sector must also be valued and given an incentive to produce CO2 credits and thus produce more intake than tax. And he must not be punished. That is why I am in favor of the compromise negotiated for the 280 million tonnes of flexibility and I believe that this is a very good compromise.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: - Mister President! Climate protection is a moral and a political obligation - today more than ever. With the proposal for a climate protection regulation up to 2030, Parliament may not have presented a perfect compromise, but we have very clear guidelines for a more consistent reduction in CO2 gases, also for a focus on a long-term strategy up to 2050 and also for options such as efforts of the countries are recognized and flexibility is built in so that countries are not overwhelmed. Now we need the Council, we need the Member States, so that this package can be implemented very soon. Because by the climate conference in Bonn, by COP23, the EU should have its package ready: emissions trading, this climate protection regulation and LULUCF. In this way we can show the world that we not only promote climate protection globally, but also take it seriously at home. Our climate protection diplomacy must succeed in creating a global consensus, even if Trump is against it.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - The European Union cannot hesitate on the path it has taken to lead the process of harmonizing and combating climate change. The report being debated today reinforces the European Union's commitment to the goals of the Paris Agreement and gains more importance with the decision taken by the American Administration to withdraw the United States from that agreement. This regulation establishes binding greenhouse gas emission targets for Member States, covering sectors of the economy not regulated by the ETS. These sectors account for almost 60% of total emissions in the EU in 2014 and the definition of national targets was made through an equity process. This is a change that will provide employment, growth and investment opportunities for Europe, while mitigating climate change and requiring changes in behavior, incentives for companies and investments. That is why it is essential that the options in this report can be widely supported in this Parliament. We made a clear choice for leadership in the transition to a sustainable economy and society. Hesitating, in the current global context, could mean losing everything.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Sir.Chairman!Thank you!Unfortunately, the United States and Trump will not help to comply with the Paris Climate Agreement, but we will in Europe!The climate and the people of the planet desperately need us to act on the climate change we see.In the EU, we can and must deliver on our promises, and we must be ambitious.Also when it gets difficult, and also when we have to share the burdens.The Environment Committee has dared to be ambitious.I fully support the report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy.We are ambitious and balanced.It is particularly good that we demand an early start to the effort already in 2018. The sooner we get started, the better.Flexibility is the most debated.Flexibility for the individual member states is basically a good thing, but it must not become so flexible that we do not actually get any new climate agreements made at all.Everyone must deliver, all sectors must be involved, otherwise we will not be able to solve our climate challenges.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the Paris Agreement provides for the parties to take measures to conserve and strengthen, if necessary, sinks and reservoirs of greenhouse gases, in particular forests. This proposal is an integral part of the implementation of the European Union's commitment to the Paris Agreement to reduce emissions across the economy. Dear Colleagues, we are at a time of great uncertainty, of incomprehensible denial of the evident climate change by those who, as is the case in the United States, contribute most to emissions into the atmosphere. The Union's main priority is to create a resilient energy union that favors energy efficiency and provides safe, sustainable energy at affordable prices to citizens, as well as implementing policies to reduce emissions and replace fossil fuels. And that, dear colleagues, is our priority if we are to lead in making the Paris commitments. I believe that it is only through ambitious climate action that we can contribute to the rescue of a planet that is sustainable for life in time. I would like to congratulate Mr Gerbrandy on this excellent compromise document and say that Europe cannot now back down from the commitments it made in Paris. Europe now has a unique opportunity to show the world its leadership in this field.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the mandatory reduction of greenhouse gas emissions is a goal of the European Union and a goal of all Member States. Every time we have considered reducing emissions, environmental issues, we have considered that we need to take into account a broader, global context, so as not to put Europe and its citizens at a disadvantage. We need to fund afforestation, we need to fund afforestation, we don't just have to say we need afforestation. It is normal to want environmental protection. After all, we are talking about life, about people's lives. But what do we do with the poorer countries, which cannot reach these levels? What do we do with the big polluters, the United States and China? What will we do with the TTIP agreement if America does not meet environmental requirements? What will we do with the competition, with the European industry? I believe, Commissioner, that you must take into account that in all trade agreements you must also put these environmental conditions, because the planet must be saved and we can only do so through measures related not only to Europe, but also to the other continents.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, we are talking about the protection of the environment, the reduction of gaseous emissions, the objectives of the Paris Agreement, and all this when now one of the biggest polluters in the world, the United States of America, has stated that it is withdrawing from the Paris Agreement. This US decision turns the tables and de facto puts the debate on another footing, because the US is protecting its own industry and economy at the expense of the world itself. That is why the European Union 's goals must be flexible and realistic and support society and the economy, taking into account the actions of all global players. The European Union, therefore, must reconsider the amendment I have tabled repeatedly, that is, to exempt electricity generation in Greece from paying contributions for emissions allowances, as is the case in Poland and Bulgaria. In addition, the objectives for the intelligent transport system should not disrupt agriculture.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr Chairman! All these goals related to the Paris Agreement are extremely important, but I think we should also be accompanied by some reflection that we should be consistent in our actions, in what we also do within the European Union. For example, the author of the report talks about the acceleration of the reduction trajectory in relation to the Commission's proposals from 2020 to 2018. Question: is this justified? This is not supported by the position of many Member States. On the one hand, we are talking about this report, and on the other hand, there is a very complementary report by Mr Lins, which is yet to be discussed. Perhaps it would be worth discussing these two reports together. Mrs McGuinness also spoke about the burden of certain sectors, for example agriculture. In some countries this can be a serious problem and it also requires some kind of reflection. Finally, it seems to me that we need more coordination so that our decisions in this area are consistent so that the goals set in the Paris Agreement can be achieved.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I am totally in favour of the Paris Climate Accord. I am totally in favour of the European Union approach and especially the 2030 targets and many of the proposals here make sense. They are, however, somewhat discriminatory against agricultural producing countries, including my own. Mr Grzyb mentioned the starting date of 2018 instead of 2020, and the target is also not appropriate. For instance, we now have to start at the target rather than the actual emissions. It is estimated that this will cost us a billion, and the Commission’s proposals took into account the mistakes that were made when the targets were set originally and if we had stuck with the Commission proposals we would have no difficulty. Parliament is now going beyond this and it means that agricultures like Ireland will be hugely burdened. We will have to purchase compliance because we will be starting in a non-compliant area and this is something that will actually totally discriminate against us in view of the economic crisis, in view of Brexit coming down the track, and now this!  It is unnecessary and it should stop and I am tabling a split vote on it.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened carefully to the debate today. I am encouraged by the Members’ engagement with the issues, and I appreciate the commitment to maintain the European Union’s role as a path-breaker in the area of international climate action.  On the two non-ETS proposals, the discussions have progressed well in the Council, the technical work is nearly finalised, and I would like to thank the Members for taking this important step in Parliament, which provides crucial political momentum for this proposal. I am convinced that the Council, under the leadership of the incoming Estonian presidency, will be able to move forward swiftly before the next climate conference in Bonn in November. The European Union, as a driving force behind the high-ambition coalition, cannot come to Bonn empty handed.  I would like to give answers on some other points raised, because it was hinted by someone that the European Union was not implementing the Paris Agreement. We should be clear on two things. The first is that we really are implementing the Paris Agreement. Out of the 140 nationally determined contributions, the European Union has the most ambitious one, namely a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by 40%. This is the biggest, most ambitious target. But we have something that makes us different from the rest – in fact, two things. We have launched all the legislation needed to achieve our targets, and I can assure Mr Eickhout that, in all the legislation the Commission is launching, nothing is being watered down, and incidentally that goes for the decarbonisation study too. We will get there –taking into account also that Paris is not an agreement which stops in 2030, it is a dynamic agreement with a five-year ambition cycle, and I am sure we will work in such a way in the coming years that we will bring on board our international partners, including even the USA. This is one president, but there will come other presidents and other administrations, and we also have to understand that we have seen a movement in the USA in response to Mr Trump’s withdrawal: a massive one from states, big cities and major businesses who have announced that they will do their part to help fulfil the original US commitment of reducing emissions by between 26% and 28% in 2025 as against 2005. So, we are implementing the Paris Agreement. We are serious in the legislation we are introducing, and what we are discussing today is of the utmost importance. Establishing binding targets for Member States was not easy in the discussions with them. Establishing such targets in agriculture, in transport and in the building sector will be a difficult exercise, and this Parliament has improved our proposals. With regard to the agricultural sector, as many of you – Mr Lynch, Mr Caputo, Mr Flanagan, Ms McGuinness and others – have pointed out, agriculture and forestry are part of the solution, and not of the problem. In the discussions, we will have to look further at future reform of the common agricultural policy, to see how we will ensure it contributes to the solution and to maintaining a dynamic and prosperous European agricultural sector. So, my message today is one of optimism because I have just come from Bologna and, with the Environment Ministers of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United Kingdom, the European Commissioners are reaffirming their strong commitment to the swift and effective implementation of the Paris Agreement, which remains the global instrument for activity in tackling climate change and adapting to its effects. We are committed to its implementation, our partners are committed to its implementation, the European Parliament is supporting the Commission in having the most ambitious legislation possible. I would like to thank all of you who took part in this debate, and particularly to thank Mr Gerbrandy, whom I am missing today, for the work he has done and for the good work I am pretty sure we will do in the trilogues.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the speakers for their good wishes to my good friend and colleague, Gerben—Jan Gerbrandy, who is the rapporteur on this report, and who despite doing all the heavy work on this is unable to be with us today because he has a family crisis. I am sure I speak for all this House in wishing Gerben—Jan and his family all the best.  I would like to thank the Commission for its commitment to driving down CO2 emissions. I heard earlier that there are concerns about how we can get to 2050. Well, nobody has ever said that tackling climate change is going to be easy, but it has to be done. Even the Paris Agreement still only brings us back to a level where we know we were emitting too much. The damage continues to be done to the whole planet. Every tonne of CO2 that is emitted today will remain in the atmosphere for over a hundred years.  But there is good news. We can have a green economy. We can drive the innovation and business that can address that. It is tough for farmers to change their farming practices. We understand that. We have been as firm as we can but as amenable as possible to their difficulties in making sure that farmers can associate themselves with this message and this regulation. We have heard from the deniers from – I am ashamed to say – the UK. They deny climate change, they even deny their existence as an effective political party in the UK, and have nearly been wiped out. I think everybody here agrees that climate change is a real issue and one on which action must be effected. A strong vote from this Parliament tomorrow will send a message to businesses, to farmers, to industry, to consumers, and to voters and the young people of Europe that we are serious about climate change. It is a compromise, sure, but it is one that we have to make and the political groups here are committed to it.  Thank you very much for your support everyone, and for the support from the Commission.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 14 June 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - We Spanish socialists are in favor of reducing greenhouse gas emissions as the first urgent measure to mitigate the devastating effects of climate change. Following the announcement of the United States' withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, the European Union must lead the process and redouble its efforts as a reference region. We Socialists want to prevent the increase in the average global temperature of the planet from exceeding 2ºC compared to pre-industrial levels and we will defend the need to carry out additional efforts so that global warming does not exceed 1.5ºC. We defend the need to global emissions to peak as soon as possible, although we are aware that this task will take longer in developing countries. In this sense, we support contributions to the Green Climate Fund, aimed at developing countries with the aim of reducing their emissions and mitigating the consequences of climate change. To do this, we Socialists want to maintain the goal of mobilizing $ 100 billion a year in 2020 and extend this measure until 2025.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - One of the most important tools for fulfilling the European Union's Paris commitment is the Effort Sharing Regulation, which addresses greenhouse gas emissions not covered by the EU Emissions Trading Scheme. In my opinion, the reduction targets set out in the legislative proposal are sufficiently ambitious and adequately reflect the fair level of contribution of each Member State to the joint emission reduction efforts. At the same time, I also consider it important to emphasize that, for some countries, the projected reduction targets could be better aligned with their pre-2020 emissions opportunities. A target setting that is more responsive to early reductions in the pre-2020 system would therefore be acceptable, as high-performing Member States would not be able to compensate for these without the possibility of transferring allowances, while less well-performing Member States could easily desired targets by 2020. It is also important to ensure that the targets reflect the actual level of development of each Member State.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: In written form. - Ladies and gentlemen, the Paris Agreement, as expected, makes the process of decarbonising the world economy irreversible, providing for zero net greenhouse gas emissions by the end of this century. In 2009, the EU adopted its target of reducing these emissions by 80-95% by 2050. The effort sharing regulation or "climate action in implementation of the Paris Agreement" in question today covers 60% of emissions EU greenhouse gas emissions and covers sectors outside the emissions trading scheme, including transport, waste, construction and agriculture. The overall target at European level for reducing carbon emissions by 40% by 2030 becomes mandatory for these sectors at national level. I support the establishment of a trajectory to achieve emissions reductions of at least 80% by 2050, in order to ensure the long-term predictability of policies and the necessary investments. I welcome the serious flexibility given to Member States in achieving the objectives of the regulation. It is particularly important for agriculture and forests, which can also contribute to the overall reduction of emissions through the natural mechanism of carbon dioxide absorption. The call for early action is also acceptable, as it is combined with additional bonuses for the respective countries at a later stage.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, as one of the best known and most popular EU programmes, Erasmus has become a symbol of Europe and of our fundamental values, but it is also much more than a symbol. Since its inception in 1987, more than 9 million people have studied, worked or volunteered abroad under the programme. Erasmus has thus proved to be a key tool for international mobility and intercultural exchange. It gives real meaning to the idea of European citizenship. Thirty years means that we can already celebrate three generations of Erasmus students. I am very pleased to note that, amongst decision makers, including within the EU institutions, many colleagues have their own personal experience of having participated in the Erasmus exchange.  We are now midway through the current programme, Erasmus Plus. Our focus now needs to be turned towards the next programming period and we should already start reflecting on the ways in which we can further improve and develop the programme beyond 2020.   (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: - Thank you, Minister Dalli, because you also spoke on behalf of the Maltese Presidency.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, Madam President of the Council of Ministers, Ladies and Gentlemen, Ladies and Gentlemen, I have three minutes to tell you about 30 years of one of the most emblematic programs of the European Union which, from 11 countries originally, now extends to 33 countries and which, by encouraging the mobility of all young people and allowing them to develop their talents and skills, has led to the emergence of a true union of citizens. Three minutes is short. So I will have only one message for the future, while we are going to celebrate the 9 millionth young Erasmus: let's be together at least 9 times more ambitious, because Erasmus is a good answer to the stupidity of national egoisms and withdrawal on oneself. Erasmus is a Europe with great promise, a confident, united Europe, resolutely turned towards the future. I am therefore counting on you to ensure that the European budget matches the talent of our young people. (Applause) Several members of the Commission participated in the Erasmus program. My neighbor Tibor Navracsics, when he was a young student in Hungary, could not participate in the program, but today he is the responsible commissioner. Plus, as we celebrate the 30th anniversary of the program, it is celebrating its birthday today, so happy birthday! (Applause) Jeder Euro, den wir in Erasmus investieren, ist eine Investition in die Zukunft, nicht nur in die Zukunft eines jungen Menschen, Sonde eine Investition in unsere europäische Idee. Denn Europa arbeitend und studierend zu entdecken, heißt auch, es auf Dauer lieben zu lernen. Viele, die bei Erasmus dabei waren, sagen mir, Erasmus hätte ihre Sicht, ihren Blick auf Europa verändert - ja, einige sagen sogar, ihr Leben verändert. Europa bringt einen unermesslichen Reichtum, der in seinen Menschen und in der Vielfalt an Kulturen, Sprachen, Traditionen begründet ist. Dieser Zauber Europas hat Erasmus von Rotterdam schon vor 500 Jahren zu einem überzeugten Europäer werden lassen.So geht es mir heute auch noch.Wenn ich auf unserem Kontinent unterwegs bin, verliebe ich mich jedes Mal aufs Neue - also in den Kontinent.Das soll ja auch schon bei dem einen oder anderen Erasmus-Teilnehmer passiert sein, mitunter auf romantischere Weise.Inoffiziellen Gerüchten zufolge ist sogar von einer Million Erasmus-Babys die Rede.Damit hat die Kommission nichts zu tun.(Beifall) Dies ist nicht auf das Wirken der Kommission zurückzuführen, aber ich begrüße diese Art europäischen Zusammenwachsens sehr.(Heiterkeit) In diesem Sinne wünsche ich Erasmus weiterhin viel Erfolg!(Beifall)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: - Thank you, Mr President, your speech was well received by the plenary, so we are very happy.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Minister, dear "Erasmus", also present here, dear European fellow citizens, good morning to all. Happy coincidence this between the recent 30 years of Portugal in the European Union and the 30 years of Erasmus in Portugal and in Europe. Coincidence between one of the happiest chapters in Portuguese recent history and one of the happiest programs of European identity. I am only a humble example of this happy coincidence. Middle class, from a small rural village in the north of Portugal, I left home very early to move to the city, to the big city, to study in secondary school. I later moved to one of the oldest Portuguese universities and then I had the opportunity to head to Europe. With a backpack on my back, full, certainly, of uncertainty, I felt that I conquered Madrid as if it were my small village. It was 10 eternal and wonderful months where I became an apprentice scientist and where I became, already there, a full European. But, before heading to Europe, I had already felt Europe in a very special way, with all the Erasmus students who visited my university and stayed there for a semester or an entire year. It was these “Erasmus” that preceded me that first taught me what it was like to be truly European. I wanted to tell you, I wanted to tell you, Europe, that you are right when you have the ambition to make Erasmus a lifelong partner for all your citizens. You will certainly have Europe, a more extended existence because you will certainly be more Europe, because we, those who have had the experience and all Europeans, will be more citizens. The speaker is an active ambassador for the Erasmus and Europe program. Regarding the months I spent there, I will say little, because we all know that what happens in Erasmus stays in Erasmus. Thank you very much, Europe. Thank you very much, Erasmus.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: – Now I would like to give the floor to Mrs Alexandra Pascalidou. Ms Pascalidou comes from Sweden, and is a writer, television and radio presenter and human rights advocate, but her name is a Greek name.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: - Mr President, I am delighted to be here. If you are a fan, you can play for free! - Ladies and gentlemen! I just found out that you can speak Swedish here, so fantastic! It is an honor and a privilege to be here. The best the EU has ever done is Erasmus. I was fortunate enough to be one of those who had the privilege of studying. This is perhaps the most important thing that has ever happened in my life. That is also the reason why I am standing here today. I, who am an immigrant child, a migrant child from Greece, with low-educated parents, with parents who have cleaned Sweden, who come to Sweden's poorest suburb Rinkeby, without any academic background, somewhere, sometime in the family, somewhere in the neighborhood where I living, I got the chance to study at a Swedish university and then get an Erasmus scholarship to experience my second home country, Greece, where I could study international politics and political sociology. My gratitude is infinite, and I express my gratitude by encouraging young people across Europe to continue to seize this opportunity, to move and to see the whole of Europe as our common home. Above all, I feel that it is such an honor to be here today. It is so valuable with initiatives like Erasmus given the dark and turbulent times we live in, with the racism, the misogyny, the extremism, the segregation that is a great challenge for the whole of Europe and that you and I and many others around in Europe, which is not here today, is struggling daily. Erasmus is precisely this bridge-building. Erasmus is the social elevator that can lift so many people with enormous potential. I just want to say a big and warm thank you and good luck. I will carry this memory and this benefit and try to spread the word. Thank you very much and good luck!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: – Three different languages – English, Swedish and Greek – but the same European identity. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: - I don't know if he will speak in Spanish, German or English, but now our friend has the floor.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: - Hello everybody! The time during my internship abroad in Spain helped me in many ways in my life. I have learned a lot that I can still benefit from today, be it the independence to find my way in a foreign country despite major linguistic, but also despite minor cultural differences. I have put aside my fears of communicating in a foreign language, because at some point I learned that it is not so important to speak flawlessly, but that communication is effortless even with small mistakes. I also learned a lot of cultural things about the country and about everyday working life in Spain. As an example, I think of my first day at the company, where when I arrived I would have expected a small welcoming committee, just as I am used to from my German homeland. But nobody was really prepared for it, which was not a problem at all. The right people were brought together in a very short time, and shortly afterwards I was on a company tour, which also involved minor linguistic complications. But you worked a lot with hands and feet and drawings, so it wasn't a problem. In summary, it can be said that the internship was a huge success for me. I got to know great people, also saw beautiful places, I found an excellent organization from Erasmus + and I learned many lessons for my future life. Congratulations Erasmus + on your thirtieth birthday! (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: - Germans who go to Germany generally have luck, think of Charles V. So Erasmus will bring luck to our friend too.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote.(Results and other details of the vote: see minutes)

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, I wish to highlight that July is Scleroderma Awareness Month. As some colleagues will be aware, I have a lifelong commitment to raise awareness of this rare and wicked autoimmune and connective tissue disease that claimed the life of my late wife, Carmen, at the age of 42. This disease, which is particularly common in females, has no known cure but early diagnosis can be of huge benefit to treatment of patients.  Accordingly, I ask all colleagues and their staff to go away and find out more about scleroderma so that they may better raise awareness in their Member States. Furthermore, I would like to pay tribute to the work of two charities, Scleroderma and Raynaud’s UK, and the Federation of European Scleroderma Associations, which work so hard supporting scleroderma patients and their loved ones.  (Applause)

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: speaker.- Mr President, just a few words.Today I would like to thank our tireless collaborators - Fernando, Andrea, Simona, Maria and Erica - and the activists of the 5 Star Movement who voted and sent us here and gave us suggestions and comfort, and all my family and my wife Laura whohas always been by my side since the beginning to support me in this fantastic adventure, which began more than ten years ago.Thank you, thank you to all of you colleagues who voted for us.Really thank you.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: speaker.- Mr President, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their support of this report.Actually, that is what allows a number of countries that belong to EFTA, or that are candidate countries for accession to the European Union, that can also participate in this program of the cultural capital.And that is not going to prevent the current countries that are part of the European Union from continuing with the same program.That is, there will be two countries that will belong to the European Union and a third country that will later join or EFTA countries.I would like again to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their support.Nothing else.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, in recent months or almost a year, we have become accustomed to the President not starting to explain the votes in such circumstances.I ask you to stick to this habit and wait for our fellow Members to leave the building or the room.It is also the humiliation of the electorate to speak in such circumstances.I kindly ask for a little more patience so that I can begin my speech under worthy circumstances!Thank you very much!

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The honorable Member, who now wanted to speak, is of course right.She cares about comfort during her speech, and she talks about important things.I would like to call you once again for the efficient leaving of the room by the Members of the Parliament.I am asking you to transfer the talks to the lobby, possibly to a restaurant.Madam, I think we can start.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, allow me to read out one point from the explanatory memorandum and opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, point 18, which states: 'Calls on the Commission to use tools that can not only assess the number of jobs created , but also its quality, as poor working conditions without adequate protection or contracts involving the exploitation of workers contribute to a negative perception of cohesion policy '. This is exactly what is related to why the so-called. a wage union civic initiative was launched with the participation of eight former socialist countries. The European Commission has adopted this initiative, the collection of signatures is beginning, and we see that the idea is not so far removed from the thinking of the European Parliament, the good forces of the European Union, the people-centered forces, because it is unsustainable that the wage levels, income levels and working conditions of the former socialist countries of Eastern Europe are so far behind those of the West, and the aim of the new cohesion policy must be to reduce this distance.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, only a third of European citizens have heard of projects co-financed by the European Union in the area where they live, although structural and investment funds are essential to improve their lives. Another problem is the degree of absorption of funds. The latest Commission report shows that for 2014-2020 the average level of absorption in the Union is 1.79% - very, very little. Romania has 0.18%. So we need to change all the mechanisms: people need to be informed, simplified procedures, uniform, transparent, easy to control, strict monitoring of spending money. In Romania, Code for Romania, an NGO of volunteer specialists in various fields, offers good governance solutions and is currently building a project for those interested to have examples of efficient use of European funds. So it is not the state that does this, but civil society. I want to see this effort at the government level as well. It would be proof that they care about people's lives and that they want to use European money for highways, schools, kindergartens, hospitals, justice and for people's lives.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, cohesion policy has greatly contributed to strengthening growth and employment, and reducing the growth of disparities between the regions of the European Union. Funding for European Union cohesion policy has a positive effect on the economy and the lives of citizens, but the results have not always been good and awareness of the positive effects remains quite low. Awareness of local funding programs for end-users and civil society is crucial, regardless of the level of funding in a given region, as the added value of EU cohesion policy goes beyond positive economic, social and territorial action. Increasing the visibility of European Structural Investment Funds can help improve perceptions of the effectiveness of cohesion policy and restore citizens' trust in the European project. I support the strengthening of the partnership and the importance of European funds through new ways of communicating the results of cohesion policy on the ground, all with the aim of increasing its visibility, providing a clear message to citizens and restoring confidence in the common vision of the European project.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I supported this report by Mr Buda, because the visibility of cohesion policy and its results is really crucial for our future.I think there is something to be proud of, ie.Despite a certain error rate, it is important to raise the profile of projects that have been successful and have been selected for support, reduce disparities in the lagging behind of the poorest regions and prove that they can boost their growth.We need to improve communication, strengthen it, that is already the content of the report, but also involve partners more.I think that one of the topics we should address for the future is the opportunity to appreciate it directly in the legislation, if a project with a clear media presentation is chosen so that the EU can be sufficiently involved in cohesion policy for the future.to boast.I think this is something we must not underestimate.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, at least we are being honest about our intentions and our motivations. We are not pretending really that the purpose of these Structural and Cohesion Funds is really to improve the economies of the recipients. If it worked, then Greece would now be bailing out Germany, as the biggest recipient versus the biggest donor. What it is all about, as the report says, is the visibility of the European Union. In other words, if you put enough 12—star flags on things, maybe people will support the project, and thus more and more people get drawn into a nexus in which they believe that they are financially dependent on the European Union.  There is though a cost to be paid. If you encourage people to look for every rise in life to Brussels, then they are not out making things and selling things and contributing to the robustness of the private economy, and therein lies our problem.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because we need people to understand how Europe works for them, unlike the comments of Mr Hannan. We have already had a very interesting presentation of the Erasmus Programme, which has been in existence for 30 years. Many students who are on Erasmus now do not realise that it is a European Union programme. So I say well done to the rapporteurs on this report. It is time that Europe started speaking out about its successes. We are damned by those who will point to our problems, but there are enough successes to far outweigh the difficulties that Europe faces. I welcome this report and I think it is the start of a fight-back for the European Union. I am proud that the flag of Europe is on projects. I am also proud when there is an Irish flag on those same projects and I see no conflict. I see a strength in that, not a problem.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr President, the Seventh European Union's 55 billion euro research program has proven that research and development of the latest technologies is a key priority for the Union's further economic growth. Initiatives and investments under the Program benefit not only all Member States of the Union, but also candidate countries and members of the European Economic Area that are not members of the Union. It is of great importance that funds were largely used to strategically encourage small and medium-sized enterprises among the funding of 25,000 other projects aimed at encouraging the mobility of scientists, technical innovation and investment in scientific infrastructure and centers of excellence. I support the conclusions of the Report, congratulate the Commission on the successful completion of the Research Agenda by 2020, but also support the proposal to expand the new mechanisms established under Horizon 2020, such as the flat rate for indirect costs, a single method of control and a single list of all institutions. participate in the program, therefore, expanding to other structural funds.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would just like to say on this report that I voted in favor, just as I commented on this report at yesterday's debate. I consider the support of research and innovation to be the real keys to our successful future. The EU is not a leader in this field, it is not an agenda on which we would lag far behind, but I think we can move significantly forward. I want to support the proposal that was voted on, ie. 3% limit for that support, and better preparation of the 9th framework. We are now evaluating the 7th framework, but it must be said that the 9th framework is also the biggest challenge for us. At the same time, I would be very reluctant if programs such as Horizon 2020 and others were weakened by recent instruments, such as the special Juncker Fund. I think we should find sufficient resources for this in other chapters. So definitely supporting research is our future and I was happy to support it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr President, (Start of speech not available - presentation started before microphone) ... research and innovation framework program is still ongoing, although it is a 2007 and 2013 program, therefore the final revision and evaluation is still ongoing it could not have been made, but what it does not have is a cost-effectiveness analysis of the Program, and this Report is precisely about the cost-effectiveness of the Seventh Research and Innovation Program. I supported the Report because, despite the lack of cost-effectiveness evaluation, it emphasizes the importance of this Program, which fosters scientific excellence at EU level, innovation, integration with the economy, strengthens European competitiveness and contributes to building the European Union as a global leader. Also, the Report provides very important recommendations that we really need to implement, such as the establishment of a joint support center, which will help coordinate the implementation of the program in the seven Commission administrations and also increase the role of national contact points. field support.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, this report is a big step forward towards awareness raising and the search for concrete solutions regarding the causes of statelessness and discrimination against stateless people in South and South East Asia. As a shadow rapporteur, I am very pleased to see that the emphasis in the report is on the identification and elimination of statelessness via empowerment of regional human rights bodies, coordination between states, and the encouragement of quantitative and qualitative research. We draw particular attention to the Rohingyas’ situation in Myanmar, where there are up to 1.2 million people denied basic human rights. In addition, we have called for examination of the role which the European Union can play in addressing this problem.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, stateless persons around the world are doomed to an extremely disenfranchised existence, often on the margins of society. They cannot acquire qualifications, do not have health insurance, cannot be legally employed, married or exercise a number of other civil and political rights. Of particular concern is the situation of people in many countries in South and Southeast Asia, and our knowledge of the number of people who do not have the citizenship of the country in which they were born and spent their entire lives is limited, given that such data in some countries in the region they collect or publish very poorly. Although the current state of stateless persons can be attributed to inefficient administration, serious problems arise where a group of people is marginalized for political purposes. Systematic discrimination against minorities, such as Myanmar, is a serious violation of human rights and the Union must do everything possible to improve the situation of vulnerable groups in the region, including the recognition of these persons as nationals of their home country. I support the Proposal because of the crucial importance of the issue of stateless persons. We must make it clear in which cases there is systematic discrimination and in which there is a lack of administrative capacity and, depending on the circumstances, implement the necessary measures.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I want to put on the record my support for this report because there are citizens in the gallery here who, I hope, do not understand because they have not experienced what it means to be in this category of statelessness. But, as we heard from previous contributions, it means that you do not have rights, and you do not have what other citizens have. There is a real problem in South and South East Asia on this issue. This report highlights this, calls for more information and wants action to address the issue. Mention was made of the situation in Myanmar and of the 1.2 million Rohingyas. This is a very big issue, and I am proud and happy that Parliament has supported this report. But we need to follow up with constant attention and vigilance to the issue, and we need to put pressure on regions and governments to do something about it.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal presented has taken on board some of our amendments in favor of the participation of small and medium-sized enterprises, with measures and tools designed to broaden the pool of potential candidates and above all the concrete opportunities to receive a grant. It is for this reason that my vote will still be in favor, despite the fact that the text is by no means decisive in some serious distortions already found. Research, science and the development of innovations should be tools for knowledge at the service and in the interest of citizens. For example, the Horizon 2020 program should be based on European ethical standards and therefore also on respect for human rights and international law. Instead, we are witnessing the participation of institutes and universities, for example Israeli, linked to the military sector, which are often involved in the occupation of the Palestinian territories or which experiment and directly use the results of research projects against the population of the West Bank and Gaza. This is not only contrary to European values, but it is also an indirect complicity in the violation of international law. This is therefore unacceptable for a European funding program.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of the report because it is important for the European Union to take action now and, with complementary measures, to support states that have been damaged by natural disasters. This now applies to Greece as well. We must support Lesvos, which has been hit by a 6.1 magnitude earthquake. We had a victim, a fellow citizen, and we express our sorrow and condolences. Also, Vrisa, a ghost village, now needs immediate help. I consider it important that the Commissioner, Mrs Creţu, accepted yesterday's proposal made by me to intervene immediately on this issue. The area of ​​Amyntaio also needs support, where we also had a great natural disaster due to the landslides that occurred, while the damages for PPC exceed 1.5 billion euros. We therefore consider it important that our Parliament took these decisions to support Greece and other countries due to the natural disasters they have suffered.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I supported this proposal, which lays down a framework for energy labeling.I believe that this change will make the existing labeling system clearer, and thus improve awareness of the environmental impact of individual products.In particular, the key to my vote was that this proposal would lead to greater transparency and also to the comfort of European consumers.I welcome the redesign of the energy labeling scale, which is at the heart of this proposal.The current scale can be misleading to many of us because of several A + classes.As for the new product database, I think it could create room for better market surveillance, which will also contribute to greater confidence in European consumers in this new system.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!Energy efficiency is very important, first of all, in industry, in the economy, but it is no less important in households.Taking care of a high level of energy efficiency is, after all, simply saving in homes, but also saving natural resources in the world.It serves to support sustainable development, which is the essence of the times in which we live.Energy efficiency also strengthens technical and technological development, and therefore innovation, which is extremely important.We have already discussed this in Parliament today, and we will continue to talk.Therefore, the changes following the regulation are right and necessary.I support them.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, people are choosing electronic products that consume less, give up heating fossil fuels as much as they can, and limit their household consumption. Of course, this is also due to the theft that is practiced by many of the companies that have a monopoly on the supply and distribution of electricity. But now we are talking about the labeling of electronic products regarding energy consumption. This is essential. It is a very good measure of transparency, which is in favor of the people. Every person who buys an electronic product needs to know how much that product consumes and what kind of energy it comes from. The market must be monitored so that industries and companies comply with these requirements. The industry, in turn, needs to adapt, especially to renewable energy. Let us not forget that it is not the people who have to adapt to industries, but the industries to adapt to what people want. The future is of renewable energy and the renunciation of independence from Russian gas. As long as we are not a European Union - or a country, any country - independent of Russian gas, foreign policy is not independent either.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, eighty percent of consumers recognize the usefulness of the energy efficiency scale in household and electrical appliances. However, most consumers in our country do not know that the majority of electrical appliances fall into category A and above, that is, the last refrigerator on the market is in category A. Today we correct a distortion that occurred over the years due to technological development. We are creating a clear scale that will make it clear that not all electrical appliances are energy efficient, a scale that puts data on its true footing. The introduction of the "A to G" scale, but mainly the provision of product scale updates, helps consumers save money and motivates manufacturers to further improve the energy efficiency of their products. With the new system, according to the forecast, we can save up to 200 billion kilowatt hours per year or, alternatively, the energy consumption of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania together. Above all, however, we have a great responsibility for the planet that we will pass on to our children and it is growing every day.

name: Seán KELLY
text: - Uachtaráin, vôté mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus bhí sé suimiúil a bheith ag éisteacht leis an Uasal Tamburrano nuir a bhí sé ag caint.Mhol se a bhean chéile agus is dócha gur féidir a rá gur féidir linn tionchar na mban a fheiscint sna moltaí seo mar se siad praiticiúil.Ar dtús nuir a fhéachaimid ar an tseanscéim a bhí againn, A, A +, agus A ++, chuir sé meascán mearaí ar chustaiméirí.Chonaic na mná, go háirithe mná céile, is sin agus tá athrú tagtha anois.Tá scéim i bhfad níos ciallmhaire againn, grav ag dul ó A go G agus dathanna éagsúla ag gabháil leo freisin, chabhraíonn laws in custoiméirí a n-aigne a dhéanamh your, ataíochtaí gcuid a nhhhhhhgive it.Give bhrí sin, is scéim phraiticiúil chiallmhar and seo agus molaim gach duine a bhí páirteach ann.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, international partners should be, and can be, reassured that research, development and innovation in the United Kingdom will continue at the same pace, if not faster, post Brexit. The European Union programme Horizon 2020 does not focus on wealth creation from innovation: it is all about support for researchers, and that is a serious flaw in the programme. By contrast, Singapore and China, for example, undertake regular and rapid updates of focused R&D to further their commercial and global advantage. If the European Union is absolutely serious, then, instead of the self-congratulation that we heard in the report, this Parliament should be asking the Commission to focus on a new initiative, and on putting a focused team structure in place to galvanise research, exploration and exploitation.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!Horizon 2020 is a huge program worth 80 billion euros.Europe must look for instruments to maintain a competitive advantage in the global market.I am convinced that the main instrument these days is innovation.Unfortunately, most countries spend less on innovation than the Europe 2020 strategy.Again, this is 3% of gross domestic product.Only four countries exceed this level.In this context, Horizon 2020 appears to us as a very important instrument for achieving these goals.Unfortunately, the Member States use this fund unequally, for example the countries of Central and Eastern Europe have used only 4% of the funds so far, whileold Europe over 90%.The conclusion is that more money from this fund should be directed to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Horizon 2020 should not be used to strengthen Europe 's defense industries, and we are committed to that. At the same time, the European Union must finally look at the proper implementation of various programs. I am referring, in this case, to the stage programs in Greece, where thousands of Greek citizens worked, but who were not remunerated under Directive 1999/70 / EC, but also the decision in case C-596/14 of the Court of Justice of the European Union. Those employed on stage should have received remuneration as if they were employees of indefinite time. These fees have not been paid to them. The European Union must now ensure that this difference in wages is paid to these thousands of Greek citizens who have worked in European programs. Also, the European Union must ensure that the insurance contributions to IKA will be paid, especially now that we have a decision of the Supreme Court in Greece. An appeal, finally, to the correct application of the decisions of the European Union to those who were employed in stage programs in Greece.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! It was a good report, but I want to emphasize that even more interesting, even better was the debate itself. Postulates regarding the next perspective appeared in the debate and I want to draw attention to them. Well, what is crucial in the report itself is supplementing with security issues: European security, security of military technologies, etc., etc. And in the report itself it was already stated that the next perspective should strengthen financing related to European security, military technologies, cyberspace. But now - during this debate that we have behind us - one important postulate has emerged that I am drawing attention to today: to separate the financing of this issue and not to burden Horizon 2020 with these goals in the next perspective. This is a very good solution from my point of view, and it is for this reason that this report deserves the support it has received.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the interim evaluation of Horizon 2020 is extremely important for the best possible preparation of the new, Ninth Framework Program for Research and Innovation for the period after 2020.
