It is important to contact users, scientists and entrepreneurs during the evaluation, because we need to hear their voice and respondto their needs.They are looking for faster implementation, they are looking for simplification, more resources for SMEs, they are looking for links to ESI funds and harmonization of rules so that as many projects as possible can be funded, because we know that many do not get funding from Horizon.In addition, the least developed Member States are under-represented and we must therefore find solutions through this program as well, with the aim of strengthening the single European research area.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - I gave my support to this report because I strongly believe in the role that cohesion policy has now and also in the future of the European Union. In this regard, I would like to express my strong support for this policy. Cohesion policy remains a key, very successful and valuable tool for investment and development in the EU, especially in the context of the decline in public and private investment in some Member States in recent years. The forthcoming Brexit is a cause for concern, but one of the most successful policies, the embodiment of European solidarity, must not be lightly encroached upon. Cohesion policy can and must play an important role in creating growth regions with the support of digital projects. Digital infrastructure will help reduce depopulation trends, especially in rural areas.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, it always shakes me deeply when experts on television, on the radio, explain that, dear Hungarians, understand that the basis of our economy and our competitiveness is low wages. This must be acknowledged, there is nothing to change about it. Sociologists would probably call this phenomenon interiorized self-hatred, or interiorized inferiority. As a criminal lawyer, I would venture to the point that this is almost a discriminatory hate speech. To humble people that you are inferior, you deserve less, you feel less because of your place of birth and residence than the one who may live 300 kilometers away from you. This is an amazing thing, and that is why I am reassured by the basic sentence of this report on cohesion policy after 2020, which states that cohesion policy for the period after 2020 must continue to 'eliminate inequalities and strengthen solidarity'. . I send this message to those who trivialize and neglect the wage union initiative of the eight Central and Eastern European countries.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, cohesion policy is the most important core of the European Union's development. More than € 350 billion, a third of the Union's budget, must be used to grow economies, certainly smartly, to stimulate investment and create jobs. Now, we have been saying this for years: not all states respond in the same way, because some want to keep their population in poverty, in order to control it more easily. We need to think about what this cohesion policy will look like after 2020 and after Brexit. We do not have clear lines of action. We now discuss various strategies and possible actions. We should have plans in parallel, because in the meantime, there are elections and, in several countries, some are changing for the better, others for the worse. That is why predictability is lacking and this brings uncertainty to people. A multi-speed Europe, as some argue, is a Europe that will be weak, incoherent and vulnerable, but of course the speed depends on the political will of the governments of the European Union. If they want to develop the country, they want the rule of law, they want free, healthy and educated people, then they will go first.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I did not vote in favor of this report, nor did I support it in the Committee on Regional Development.I feel that some parts of Mrs Westphall's report are definitely positive.As an example, I can talk about the fact that the call for non-restriction of cohesion policy after 2020 is, of course, very my own, or, on the contrary, another criticism of the gradual destruction of cohesion policy by other instruments, such as Juncker's investment plan.I agree with all this, but what I could not agree with is the abandonment or some dilution of the GDP criterion in terms of the use of this criterion in the distribution of European money.If this criterion is diluted, eg by the demographic development that the EP is calling for according to this report, then in my opinion it is a step in the wrong direction, which will lead to unnecessary discussions at the European level and, last but not least, is contrary to the Czech Republic's interests.That is why I did not support this report, as I say.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr President, I support the Report on the foundations of the European Union's cohesion policy after 2020, because one of the key tasks of the Union is to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion and solidarity between its various regions and member states. It is precisely the implementation of these objectives that is ensured through the European Cohesion Policy, which is also the main investment policy of the European Union. I believe that the main emphasis should be placed on keeping the amount of funds in the next budget framework. I expect simplification and a more flexible policy, ie easier programming, management and evaluation of operational programs. I emphasize in particular that cohesion policy after 2020 should cover all regions of the European Union and recognize their specificity. I am pleased that my amendments have been adopted, calling for the recognition of the special status of European islands, because it must be easier for islands and islanders to withdraw funds from the Cohesion Fund. In conclusion, the European Union needs a strong, clear and inclusive cohesion policy beyond 2020, which will strengthen a European identity based on common European values.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I was originally prepared to support this report on cohesion policy, because I consider cohesion policy to be an important EU tool for supporting less developed regions within the EU, but because, unfortunately, amendments have been passed which, in my opinion, violate and demolish the philosophy policy as it has been perceived so far in the EU, so I finally refrained from this report. That is why I give this explanation. It is important to me that cohesion policy is implemented in such a way that we support less developed regions through European money, and therefore the criterion for allocating money should be the GDP of individual regions. Unfortunately, amendments have been passed that dilute this criterion, ie. even richer regions, richer regions will be able to reach for cohesion money, in which case cohesion policy is losing its meaning for me. That is why I have refrained from this report, and I hope that, in the end, the criteria contained in this report will not be enforced in practice, because this report does not have a normative content.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, from the very beginning I also said in yesterday's debate: I support the need for this social cohesion program to exist even after 2020. I have heard voices in Parliament fighting against this. It seems to me that it is the essence of the European Union and that it respects the principle of solidarity. What I called on the Commission and the Commissioner yesterday is to find a new set of measures so that there is easier accessibility, especially for SMEs, especially in rural areas, and for us to be able to combine this with funding. social cohesion and the European Fund for Strategic Investments. We have poor regions. The social cohesion we were expecting has not been achieved and I believe that, through a new policy and measures for the period after 2020, we will be able to make people's lives better in the areas where there are still problems. It is a very good program, it is an important program for the European Union and I believe in the need to continue and I do not want to divert social cohesion funds to other programs.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, today, unfortunately, I did not support the Report of my colleague Vesval, because I believe that European funds should be the wind behind the implementation of well-designed development programs and reforms at the national level.If the state does not have its own plan and program of change and development and does not achieve results and long-term growth, then European funds are only helping to slow down the decline and divergence that is inevitable, and we do not want that.European funds must fit into good growth and development programs and be an added value.Therefore, I am strongly in favor of the future of Cohesion Policy, of strengthening cohesion policy in the future, but it must be linked to good economic governance.I also ask the European Commission to adopt regulations for the new period as soon as possible, so that the Member States can prepare for implementation in time and have projects under implementation as soon as the new perspective begins.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with 17 000 marine species, the Mediterranean is a world paradise of biodiversity and fishing is an economic sector of great importance for the coastal community and all related industries, especially on a small scale. This is why we need to find a synthesis between these two elements in the name of sustainable development. The proposal goes precisely in this direction. First of all, it emphasizes the importance of involving all operators in the sector in defining the policies to be implemented, including coastal communities, and respecting traditions and, at the same time, emphasizes the need to protect the Mediterranean fish resources, counteracting both illegal fishing and other factors such as oil tanker pollution that put these resources at risk. Measures such as biological shutdowns can help rebuild stocks, but must be accompanied by adequate income support measures. Furthermore, unfair competition constituted by imports of fish from places where sustainability is not guaranteed must be countered and, at the same time, it is necessary to work on the front of critical consumption, also with an effective and reliable traceability and labeling system.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Mr President, one of the most biodiverse areas in the world, the Mediterranean Sea, suffers from overfishing in 93% of its species. If there is overfishing in the Mediterranean but jobs are being destroyed, who is fishing? It is simple: the big bluefin tuna monopolies fish, which keep 80% of the quota for this species, while artisanal fishermen despair because they are prevented from going out to fish to earn their bread. In this Parliament it is almost a moral obligation, when speaking of fishing in the Mediterranean, to say loud and clear that the Spanish State is not complying with article 17 of the common fisheries policy. The Spanish Government distributes fishing quotas according to political and territorial criteria and is not controlling, for example in Catalonia, the effective payment of biological stoppages to the Mediterranean fishing fleet. Protecting artisanal fishing and defending marine resources go hand in hand and this requires strong political will because we owe it to the fishermen and their families, who have been feeding the people for centuries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the protection of fish stocks in the Mediterranean should not be to the detriment of small-scale fishermen, these people who are struggling to make a living. It is well known that overfishing is mainly due to the large units that catch fish, while, of course, small-scale fishermen are virtually unable to make a living. This is much more true for Greece, where fishermen are subject to tax evasion in terms of memorandum policies. Keep in mind that pollution in the Mediterranean is significant. It is due to the extraction of gas and oil, and from there we also have a reduction in fish stocks. Serious measures must also be taken to deal with toxic fish, such as the hare that has entered the Red Sea via the Suez Canal and is causing huge problems for the fishermen themselves. Therefore, fishermen need support, fishery income needs support, and especially fishermen in my homeland, Greece.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I hereby close the explanation of vote.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the Commission statement: Discussion paper on deepening EMU by 2025 (2017/2726 (RSP)).

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the reflection paper on the deepening of the EMU contributes to the broader political debate on the future of Europe started with the March White Paper. The Five Presidents’ reports and the Rome Declaration underline that the Union should promote convergence and that we need to work towards completing the economic and monetary union. I would like to thank Parliament for its valuable input in several own initiative reports, namely Brok, Bresso, Verhofstadt and Berès.  The euro is one of Europe’s most significant achievements. It is the currency of 340 million people in 19 countries and the second most used currency in the world. It has brought price stability and has made it easier to do business and to travel. The euro quickly became the symbol of prosperity for our citizens and it should remain so. The financial and economic crisis underlines the weaknesses in the way the euro is set up. The determined policy response has made EMU stronger but not filled all the gaps. There is still a lack of convergence and questions remain about the long—term resilience of the euro area.  We cannot wait for another crisis to act. The reflection paper presents a toolbox on the way forward. It is more targeted at what can be done over the next two years to 2019 and more open about what might come afterwards up to 2025. Key guiding principles for any advances are: a balanced approach in which responsibility and solidarity, risk reduction and risk sharing go hand in hand; the openness of the euro deepening process for all EU countries; and keeping the unity of the single market, transparency and democratic accountability. Our ideas on the way forward are structured in three building blocks: financial union, economic and fiscal union, and governance and accountability. On financial union, we are aiming at renewed financial integration, safer financial institutions that can finance the real economy and more risk sharing via private channels. The capital markets union is key to broadening financial options, so I am glad of the recent agreements reached by the co—legislators on venture capital and securitisation and look forward to working with you on the initiatives on the mid—term review. We should further reduce risks in our banking sector based on the package of November 2016. We are also working on Member States with a European strategy to reduce the stocks of non-performing loans. The EU framework for bank resolution will not be fully effective without a fiscal backstop to the single resolution fund, and without a European deposit insurance scheme depositors will not be protected to the same extent across the euro area. We need to further weaken the link between banks and sovereigns. In this context we are following the ongoing work in the European Systemic Risk Board on so-called sovereign bond backed securities. They can deliver tangible benefits by increasing the diversification of banks’ balance sheets and by fostering private risk sharing. They do not involve debt neutralisation among Member States or changes in the regulatory treatment of government bonds. For the longer term, we need a debate about the zero risk rates of certain banks under current banking rules and a possible new European safe asset. So there are both complex and sensitive issues. Our reflection paper frames them with strong caveats, notably in terms of preventing unwarranted consequences for financial stability and for moral hazard.  In the area of economic and fiscal union, the aim is to see convergence between Member States towards more resilient economic structures. With the bulk of economic and social policies under national responsibilities, there is no doubt that we need to have a continued commitment to structural reforms. The European Semester will continue to be the main platform for policy coordination and we will continue to seek improvements. The capacity of macroeconomic stabilisation in the euro area could also be reinforced. We are presenting three options for such functions to assist countries hit by economic shocks too large to cope with on their own.  One option is the European investment protection scheme. In times of strain, public investment is the first item to be cut from the national budget and this can harm future growth. The investment protection scheme could take the form of a financial instrument and I believe could be set within the existing legal framework. Other options include the European unemployment reinsurance scheme and a rainy day fund. In any case, it should not lead to permanent transfers among countries nor undermine incentives for sound fiscal policy—making at national level. Finally, we need greater democratic accountability and higher transparency, integrating intergovernmental agreements into EU law and ensuring proper democratic oversight. Pierre Moscovici will be elaborating on this in more detail. I would like to underline that the White Paper and reflection paper process is not an intellectual exercise for the Commission. We hope to reach a constructive debate across Europe in the coming months and to see a broad agreement emerging on the way forward.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, before presenting to you some of the key ideas in addition to what Valdis Dombrovskis has just said, I would like to perhaps do a political reflection. It was clear from the start of this reflection process that when it came to our Economic and Monetary Union, there was no question of whether we really needed to move forward. There could not, this time, be a question of having several scenarios, one of which would have been the status quo, because we are convinced in the Commission, and I am delighted, that it progress must be made to complete Economic and Monetary Union. Why? For three reasons: first, because we have an economic recovery in the euro zone which is there, but which remains too fragile and too uneven. We must relaunch it and promote convergence. Secondly, because there is a real risk which is that of a two-speed euro zone. These consequences would be serious because, yes, it is true that populism has lost a few political battles in Europe - I rejoice as a European, as a Commissioner and as a Frenchman - but it did not lose the war. It still feeds on economic dissatisfaction and inequality. Finally, because it seems to me that there is a political "window of opportunity" that is opening up in Europe. There is now a pro-European wind blowing and now is the time, I believe, to seize it. I want to stress that what we are proposing today is necessary and desirable for Member States. When I say 'for the Member States', I mean all the current Member States and I also mean the possible future membership of others. It's not about forcing anyone to join, of course, but it is true that after Brexit, the only country with a formal opt-out clause will be Denmark. All the others are intended to join the euro once the conditions are met. Our aim is not to make this accession process binding, it is to make it attractive, to make everyone want to join the euro. What are our concrete ideas? Valdis Dombrovkis has already told you about financial union. This is the aspect on which we must articulate the principles of solidarity and responsibility most precisely. There are several concrete proposals on the table which should make it possible to combine risk reduction and sharing, especially for non-performing loans. There are also other sites where work is less advanced, but which are no less important. This is the case, for example, with the idea of ​​setting up a new risk-free asset for the euro zone, which could take several forms, but which should not be confused with what were called “euro- obligations". What I would like to emphasize above all is the creation of a true economic and budgetary union, which we must pursue if we want a sustainable and upward convergence of our economies. What does this imply? First, in the short term, we will explore the possibilities to strengthen the "euro area" dimension of the European Semester and create convergence criteria with financial incentives to achieve them. There are also other possible ways to strengthen the existing capacities in the European budget to help stabilize our economies. But we are convinced that in the medium term we will have to be more ambitious in creating a macroeconomic stabilization function for the euro area. In our view, an instrument of this type would have many advantages: it would support the action of national fiscal stabilizers in the event of a crisis and it would allow better aggregate fiscal policy at the level of the euro area as a whole, in particular when monetary policy reaches its limits. We know that this instrument should not be a permanent transfer mechanism, that it should not encourage moral hazard, but we believe that it should be put in place. Of course, we have to debate its form, use, financing and possible links with the European budget or with a reformed European Stability Mechanism. Then again, I said, there aren't multiple scenarios, but there are very clearly multiple options on our ambitious scheme. We also need to discuss the precise form it can take. It could be a system for protecting public investments in the event of a recession, a European unemployment reinsurance scheme or even a rainy day fund - a reserve fund for hard times. The most ambitious interpretation of this idea would be that of a real euro zone budget. This has been debated several times in your assembly. Each idea has its own merits. The only one we rule out - if I may say so - is that of doing nothing. So let's start the debate. Finally, and this is not the least important thing, today we want to launch a deep debate on strengthening the governance of the euro area and on its democratic capacity. We believe that a strengthened Economic and Monetary Union depends on our Member States agreeing to share more responsibilities, to take more decisions together on matters of common interest with a legal framework that is also common. We must therefore go further in the political integration of the euro area. We must proceed gradually, then, in parallel, perhaps launch new projects. A first step could be - should be, in our opinion - the formalization, by the end of next year, of the already very regular dialogue between the Commission and the European Parliament on economic policy. We have arrangements. I think they could be extended to other institutions, starting with the Eurogroup whose members, of course - the finance ministers - will remain primarily accountable to their national parliaments. This could lead to an arrangement on the democratic accountability of the euro area, signed by all the players, with a view to the election of the next European Parliament, in June 2019. Then, in the longer term, I think such agreement, if it were to see the light of day, could be incorporated into European treaties. It should be added that the integration of the "fiscal pact" into European law was already decided by the participating Member States when they signed the treaty. It should therefore be implemented quickly. Another path could also be explored, which would be the integration of the European Stability Mechanism into the European scheme. This would of course be linked to the development of this European stability mechanism: some people speak of a European Monetary Fund. What, it seems to me, is decisive in ensuring that our decisions are taken more in the direction of the general interest, is democracy. This is the reason why, in my opinion and in our opinion, a new balance must be created between the Commission and the Eurogroup with - it is possible - the merger of the roles of commissioner in charge of the euro and President of the Eurogroup. We can and must also move forward. We have already made proposals in this regard for a unified external representation of the euro area. This takes up what we already said during phase 1 of the EMU debate. We can go even further with the creation of a Eurozone Treasury, which could take over the tasks of budgetary surveillance, coordination and management of the stabilization function that I mentioned earlier. This Treasury could in a way bring together existing responsibilities and services, including the European stability, once it becomes an integral part of the institutional framework of the euro area. This Treasury could ultimately be placed under the responsibility of a euro area finance minister. It is not, moreover, a question of focusing on the nomination or the name - Mrs Mogherini, who chairs the RELEX working group and who is vice-president of the Commission, is not the Minister for Foreign Affairs of the 'Union -, it is not a question of supervising the ministers, but it could be a question of a personality who, precisely, could exercise these functions of president of the ad hoc council, of the Eurogroup and of commissioner at the same time . Finally, the idea of ​​a European Monetary Fund, which would naturally be built from the European Stability Mechanism, deserves more debate. Here are quickly gathered the ideas that we can find. They have different degrees of ambition and precision. There are a lot of options, but we wanted to build a package that is balanced. The euro is already seen as a symbol and as a guarantee of stability by Europeans. Our ambition is to make it, beyond that, a vehicle for prosperity. As Jacques Delors said, "the euro protects but does not boost". We must complete it in this direction and we believe that it is only by reducing economic and social differences in the euro zone that we can sustainably beat populism, which is always dangerous in our countries. Basically, our ambition and our intention is to say that it is now time to complete this course that we started to build at the time of the Maastricht Treaty to move towards a real and complete Economic and Monetary Union with real institutions and with a dimension that is missing: when we are in the Eurogroup, our fellow citizens are shocked and frustrated at not knowing what is going on there, within four walls. We sometimes decide the fate of peoples without anyone, starting with you, ladies and gentlemen, is informed.We need democracy, because there is no political union without democracy.I believe that we have provided serious work here, which is subject to your debate, and it is this debate that we are of course quite prepared to conduct with you and, even more than that, eager to do so..

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, Commissioner, is Europe sick of its currency? We are at his bedside today. The euro - you said it - has been a great success. The euro has protected us, certainly, but today our currency area is torn by too large macroeconomic divergences, and these divergences increase inequalities and fuel Euroscepticism. The euro is therefore at a crossroads. I congratulate the Commission, because its proposals are ambitious and constitute a useful basis for reflection to strengthen Economic and Monetary Union. The euro is no longer a taboo: everything must be put on the table. There are three keys to our success: trust, responsibility and solidarity. Trust, first of all, is a prerequisite; however, this confidence has been weakened by promises too often aborted. Many states are on the path to reforms, I hope that it will be the same for France, but everyone's efforts are essential to restore confidence and thus complete the banking union, in particular with a European deposit guarantee - you mentioned it - which is still sorely lacking. The corollary of this trust is responsibility. Responsible management of public finances, according to the rules, for example, of a convergence code, would pave the way for the creation of a common fiscal capacity and a strengthening of the governance of the euro area. Solidarity, finally: if we want to share the same currency, we must set up solidarity mechanisms. It is not, of course, to create a transfer union, but to be able to stick together when the going gets tough. To this end, I plead for the establishment of a European monetary fund. However, I believe that we cannot wait until 2025 to put these reforms in place, we have to hitch up now.The political stars are aligned, now or never is the time to act.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, the Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen! My group wants a strong euro area. The euro is one of our greatest achievements, but it needs a creative environment. It needs political instruments, it needs a framework in which not only the currency can develop, but also the economy. We congratulate the Commission on going in the right direction with its paper. We need more investment, we need greater coordination of our economic policy, we need responsible institutions, and we need a process in which the modernization of our economy and the modernization of our societies are advanced - economic modernization, ecological modernization and social modernization. Yes, we want a semester that has binding goals. It cannot be explained why the rules of budgetary discipline are binding, but why it is not binding to fight against youth unemployment, or why those who modernize their education systems faster, who ensure that the work of the future comes to us more quickly, and that young people should be qualified, not rewarded. They are treated in our systems like those who put the money into a water-headed bureaucracy. We need to sharpen our instruments so that they can distinguish between good and bad policies. That is what our common political framework must achieve. We need a common budget to support these initiatives. And we need this budget quickly. All of this will only succeed if the European Parliament is involved accordingly. I understood the Commission's invitation. We want to accept this invitation, and we look forward to a - hopefully - effective and rapid process of strengthening the European Union and especially here the Eurozone.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear colleague Bullmann!I listened carefully, and in the end I said, so to speak: We need a budget.I assume that what is meant is a budget for the euro zone.Where does it come from?Who is filling this budget?Who pays the taxes that go into this budget?Should the European Union be given the authority to collect taxes - which it has not yet - or will that be done from the Member States?I find this a bit abstract and would be grateful for a specification.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Lambsdorff!Both in your current capacity and in your possible future capacity, you can contribute a little to make it work.My group has made sufficient proposals on this.We are the ones who uncovered how many billions in taxes the European Union is losing every year.We would like to raise these 1,000 billion with your help.In this respect, we would also be very happy if your group no longer received motions, such as yesterday in the relevant vote, where the country-by-country principle is being undermined and we are no longer able to see where tax money is being hidden.So there is a great deal you can do to fuel these initiatives, and we look forward to your cooperation.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! The reflection paper says: The euro is more than a currency. Yes that's right. But it is also correct that a wrongly constructed monetary union harms and divides Europe. You say it yourself. Your foreword says: “The European Monetary Union is not yet sufficiently capable of stopping and reversing the social and economic drifting apart of the euro countries resulting from the crisis.” That is a crucial sentence. Why is that? We have an incorrect relative exchange rate within the euro zone. The euro is valued too low for Germany and too high for the countries of the south. In Germany we go from record to record. In the countries of the south, unemployment remains at a sadly high level. Now Draghi has tried to hold that together with a zero interest rate policy. But at some point it has to move to normal rates and then it falls apart. And what are you going to do now? The next phase of communalization. I tell you: you cannot get rid of different development skills and different competitiveness by pooling risks - that's just the way it is. And then at the end of your paper it says - a wonderful sentence: “It is time to put pragmatism above dogmatism.” Who is meant by dogmatism? Is it Mrs. Merkel? And what does that actually mean? Ultimately, pragmatism means: We no longer make clear solutions. And with this policy you will not save Europe, you will not save the eurozone, you will destroy the European Union. (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we have had great news lately in the eurozone. For the first time in a while we are feeling more optimistic about the future of our project; that is great news. But before we rush into asking for more new instruments, maybe we should use all our energies to make sure that the current ones work properly. Implementation and enforcement are fundamental for our future. A good application of EU law is basic in order to regain the support of our citizens and increase the efficiency of our monetary union.  For the future of the euro we need to ensure that all Member States comply with the relevant EU economic legislation. Take the Late Payments Directive, for example. As you well know, more than one million jobs have been lost in the south of Europe in recent years due to the bad practices on payments by central banks and big enterprises, forcing thousands of solvent SMEs to close. A business is only made when it is cashed. This is the basis of our model. We need to ensure this before talking about more integration.  So, in my opinion it is better to concentrate our political capital on the outstanding projects that we have initiated, before beginning new ones. For instance, we have to implement the bail-in legislation in a consistent manner in all Member States and all Member States already have to implement correctly the Deposit Guarantee Scheme Directive.  Moreover, we have to rethink our current economic governance framework. Implementation of the deficit rules is still not satisfactory and many recommendations in the European Semester are never implemented by Member States. I hope that in the coming years we will do all this and leap forward in our euro integration, but before we think about eurobonds or an economic treasury, a European treasury, we have to ensure that this is properly done. Finally, I think that the best way to achieve economic convergence in the eurozone is not through massive fiscal transfer between Member States, but by sharing and extending economic and financial best practices among us.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - At a time of stalemate where the profound crisis of this model of European Union integration is all too evident, this reflection document represents a true flight forward. At a time when deep reflection on the role of Economic and Monetary Union would be required, in this long process of social and economic divergence, this document proposes, in practice, to deepen all the factors that were at the basis of this divergence. In my city, Aveiro, the workers who are fighting for their rights today and are on strike feel the effects of this neoliberal European Union dominated by multinationals. Europe does not need a Minister of Finance. It will not be a single IMF representation that will solve the problems of unemployment and economic dependency. Budgetary capacity, with all associated constraints, will only reinforce the oppressive nature of the euro area and limit the ability of Member States to respond to their problems according to their models and according to the will of their people. Today, there is evidence that the euro zone represents a political project aimed at forcing a neoliberal agenda and, therefore, what is necessary is not its strengthening, but rather its dissolution in a process that includes the recovery of the monetary sovereignties of Member States and the renegotiation of public debts, the increase of which cannot but be associated with the euro and its economic governance.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, none, I mean no monetary union - Mr Starbatty, Germany is one - no monetary union is possible without powerful mechanisms of financial solidarity, both private and public. To put it simply, without a full banking union, without a social, fiscal and democratic union, the euro is doomed to disappear. This evidence, the reflection document tabled by the Commission two weeks ago, recognizes it, but only in the background. It is added to those proposed in 2012 by Barroso, on the one hand, and by Van Rompuy, on the other, and to the famous report of the five presidents tabled in 2015. We have therefore been beating around the bush for five years, because it lacks the vision and the political will to act. Yes, we need to complete the banking union by adding to common supervision and common crisis management a common deposit guarantee backed by a common fiscal public safety net. Yes, we need a euro zone budget to invest in particular in the energy transition, because, deployed counter-cyclically, it will cushion macroeconomic shocks, but it will also improve the strength of the European economy. Yes, we need to deepen the solidarity between our social protection systems, for example with a common unemployment reinsurance system. Finally, if we are to tackle excessive deficits, whether they be trade balance deficits or budget deficits, we must tackle excessive surpluses with equal force, because they are just as harmful as the former. Likewise, we must stop the excessive growth of both public and private debts, because their increase is a sign of danger. None of this can happen without strong democratic control. The European Parliament and national parliaments must be closely involved in this device. Dear colleagues, to share a currency is to share a common good. This presupposes both strong solidarity and an equally strong sense of shared responsibility. All this is only possible with common rules, for example for the financial sector. On that note, let me tell you that what we've been witnessing over the past year is more of a quiet unraveling of the few progress we've made rather than the simplification and tightening of the rules that we need. . We certainly have budgetary rules, but experience shows us that they are inapplicable, quite simply because they are procyclical, that is to say that they worsen the situation when it is already serious and that , combined with the neoliberal doxa which continues to dominate this assembly, the Commission and the Council, they mean that it is the weakest shoulders which find themselves carrying the heaviest part of the burden. Rather than freeing ourselves from the rules, we must have the courage to transform them, both financially and in terms of the budget, so that they regain their meaning, that is to say that of defending the general interest. I will end, Madam, if I may, by saying that Europe is a symbol. Some would like to make it a symbol of financial oppression. Me, I say that Europe can become or become again the symbol of a common belonging.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too agree with Professor Starbatty, who spoke before me, because there is a need for a profound critical analysis of what is the current situation linked to economic governance and linked to the monetary economic union. We have a currency that has created clear imbalances because it has been placed in a non-optimal currency context. These imbalances are not successes, because it was the citizens who saved the euro, devaluing wages in the peripheral countries and creating the conditions of competitiveness that the Commission strongly demands, driven by the neoliberal policies that are required by globalists and the market. With this situation and this analysis, perhaps we can identify what the problems are. In a functioning monetary economic union there are contributions from countries in surplus and enjoying the benefits linked to the single currency towards depressed areas. Perhaps with this intellectual honesty we could try to find a solution. But I don't see the Nordic countries that enjoy these surpluses wanting to do this kind of political action and therefore it is very difficult to be pro-European at the moment, when there is no intellectual honesty on the part of those who put "Germany first" - so to speak - for several years within the European Union. Even on banks, I'm sorry to say, the solutions that are applied adopt wrong weights and measures because, if we analyze the situation from 2011 to 2013, which led European countries to take action on banks, we see how there is a distorted competitive situation , where banking systems like the German one have received almost 250 billion and have created aid situations, which today are not allowed in Italy, for example, when the banking system needs to give a hand to what the system is credit, in turn put under pressure from the neoliberal market and the Basel rules.By putting these principles under the magnifying glass, perhaps solutions could be found but, since I do not see this in the Commission proposal, I think it is more appropriate to speak of a position of disintegration of the currency union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! In addition to a sustainable solution to the refugee problem and a realignment of defense policy, the reform of the Economic and Monetary Union is certainly a very important topic and a very important step for the future of Europe and the euro zone. This reflection paper reflects the Commission's opinion on this. I agree with one thing you said today, Commissioner Moscovici: this House should be included in the dialogue to a greater extent, because this is the only way to ensure democratic legitimacy. But the Member States are also very active now. As you know, a working paper between Germany and France on reforming the eurozone is expected by July. A common budget for the euro zone including euro finance ministers, common taxes and secured debt options, a mutualisation of unemployment insurance and deposit insurance are, in my view, not effective answers to the problems of monetary union. What the monetary union needs is not more redistribution and more transfer, but more personal responsibility, more competitiveness and compliance with the current deficit and debt rules. The euro crisis in particular has shown that hardly any member state adheres to the Maastricht criteria. Why also? Anyway, no real consequences are foreseen. The economic and monetary union does not need any further communitisation of debts in the form of Eurobonds or ESBies. Much more important are responsible budgetary policies, measures that create growth and jobs. In this way we will be able to stimulate investments in Europe again, gain the trust of investors and generate corresponding projects.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Madam President, the European Union, as a transnational alliance of capital, cannot go beyond the DNA of capitalism: anisometry of economic development and social exploitation. A portion of monopolies and states are pushing for its further consolidation, with one or more speeds, strengthening European semesters, linking funding to capital with anti-labor reforms. They compete with other factions that develop centrifugal tendencies, protectionism, with an expression of bourgeois Euroscepticism. They are competing over who will benefit most from a slim, uncertain recovery, a precursor to a new crisis. Everyone agrees on one thing: escalation of the anti-popular attack everywhere without end. The Greek debt discussed the day after yesterday in the Eurogroup reflects such contradictions. Prerequisite for its regulation and quantitative easing means further permanent slaughter of salaries, pensions and allowances, bloody surpluses for decades for new capital incentives, subsidies and tax exemptions. The people owe no debt to pay. Liberation from the European Union by overthrowing the power of capital, by popular power, is the only way for it to survive.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: - Madam President, Commissioners! With its reflection papers, the European Commission is making a valuable contribution to the debate on deepening economic and monetary union. This is a debate that the European institutions must have together. We need broad consensus on the direction and order of the next steps. We can only do this if we strengthen the credibility in the system. That means that we have to deliver based on the instruments currently available to us. That is certainly the starting point, and the Commission rightly recognizes that. The European Economic and Monetary Union has its very own architecture. The EU Commission is right when it says that we should not copy a national or international model. We would like to build on our existing system by strengthening the application of rules, achieving a better link between national reforms and European controls and means, striving for economic convergence and thus greater competitiveness, and strengthening decision-making processes in the Union and, above all, making them more transparent. The completion of economic and monetary union must remain open to all EU member states. Membership in the euro should not become a symbol of separation, but a symbol of prosperity and competitiveness. That is why the Commission rightly emphasizes that constant transfers do not help to stabilize the economic and monetary union. I think we have to avoid moral hazard and, as the keyword “credibility”, pay attention to the contractual barriers to which we are all bound. For us, this is the basic requirement for all further considerations. Unfortunately, the Commission also leaves opportunities untouched. For example, I am missing a proposal for state bankruptcy law. The exchange has only just begun. I believe we all do should work actively and constructively on the further development of the Economic and Monetary Union.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, the European Union can only have a future if the eurozone becomes an area delivering prosperity and upward convergence for all its Member States and for all the other states which are planning to join. We need to stop this machine for divergences which are not only economic; they are social and political. So we welcome the Commission’s proposal with a plan which, finally, recognises that the problems of the eurozone are not only financial stability, but also growth, job creation and upward economic and social convergence. Of course, Member States do need to engage in an effort of their own in reforms and investments in the framework of the European Semester. But exactly because they are confined by a common fiscal discipline, they must also count on an instrument to support this upward convergence. We hope that this instrument will be created in the upcoming next budgetary framework. We need to have it as soon as possible, otherwise we cannot reverse this logic of divergence. Beyond that, of course, we need to equip the eurozone with the proper fiscal capacity and this fiscal capacity should be based on democratic governance. The proposal of having a Minister of Finance, who is also a Vice-President of the European Commission makes sense from our viewpoint, but this will suppose full accountability before the European Parliament. The proposal coming now from the Commission to have an agreement involving Parliament, the Commission and the Council to discuss this makes sense and we are available to do so.

name: Sander LOONES
text: - I live in Astridlaan in Koksijde, Oostduinkerke, and we have a good line in our street. The rule is that everyone sweeps in front of their own door. That way the whole street is clean. Sometimes I also sweep in front of my neighbor, when he is ill, for example. Solidarity. If I did not live in Astridlaan but in Europastraat, it would be different. Then the northern part of the street would be clean, swept, but the southern part would not. Because that is what we see in Europe today: several southern European countries refuse to do their part of the work and of course it does not work that way in this eurozone. The eurozone can only run when all member states assume their responsibility. But today we are not talking about taking responsibility here. No, we are talking again about eurobonds, about a European Monetary Fund, about a European Minister of Finance, about establishing a European transfer union. A transfer union! With all due respect, that's not the solution. That is not solidarity, that is profitariat and that is not a structural future for our eurozone. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: "blue card" question.- Mr. Loones, Germany has been around for more or less 150 years now.Germany has been a monetary union for 150 years.There have been transfers within Germany for 150 years.Do you call Germany a large profitariat?

name: Sander LOONES
text: "blue card" answer.Thank you for the question.The question is how we will make our European economies stronger again.And what do I find?The transfer policy does not work in Germany either.It also does not work in Belgium, where we have billions of transfers to Wallonia every year and Wallonia does not recover.It also doesn't work in Italy.A transfer policy will not bring a stronger economy, will not bring a stronger eurozone.So that's not the way forward.The only way forward is the way of responsibility.Do what has to.Structural reform, so that we can move forward together.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Madam President, there is still a strong tendency to talk only about EMU, and that shows that we have a very short memory. Nobody cares to remember what happened after 1971: nobody wants to remember the tunnel, or the snake in the tunnel, and all the havoc they created. Then, all of a sudden, when we decide to get some systematic approach to the whole problem, then half of Europe more or less breaks in, because they had to come here. I think part of this discussion is still about finding a culprit for a diverse range of things that happened outside our control. Things happened which we could not have any control over, but one of the issues – and I think Mr Loones spoke about it just now – is that, at the same time, we have a very sharp technological conflict going on. We have very steep technological development, and it is very easy to get left behind.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: - Madam President, Mr Dombrovskis and Mr Moscovici, how and when will the democratic control and accountability of the Eurogroup be strengthened? How long will the Eurogroup decide behind closed doors? I hope that the day after tomorrow, on June 15, in the Eurogroup, and with the contribution of the Commission, there will be a road that will allow Greece, my country, a fair and strong development. I think this is a goal not only Greek but also European. But more clarity and courage is also needed from the Commission, because you have an excess of findings and a lack of proposals. We need new, bold solutions with enhanced growth, political governance, transparency, democratic accountability, solidarity, and at European level. We need more political and democratic Europe and not just a market. To do this, the role of the European Parliament and the Commission needs to be strengthened, not weakened, and a European Monetary Fund finally set up.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: - Madam President, the Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen! First of all: from our point of view, the Commission has put forward good proposals - they point in the right direction. We need more of a common economic and financial policy in the eurozone - there is no getting around it if we want to keep the whole thing together. That now also means: The ball is now in the playing field of the member countries. The member states must now finally - after years of non-functioning cooperation behind closed doors in the Eurogroup - find their way back to the ground of European democracy and submit their own strong proposals on how we can get ahead. The proposals that you have put forward must now produce results. The European Central Bank can no longer be solely responsible for holding the euro area together. The damage this creates is always greater and irresponsible. The answer to that means, however, that we have to come to a common economic and financial policy in Europe instead of insulting Mario Draghi. Incidentally, I also think it is correct that you have not submitted any joint state insolvency proceedings, moreover - as Mr Balz suggested - without allowing any transfers at the same time. Why? That would drive the eurozone apart again, because of course the weaker states would have to bear correspondingly higher burdens for their national debt. So we're driving the euro apart - instead of making sure that it sticks together. The point now must be that these reforms are not implemented intergovernmentally - i.e. around a deepening of the European stability mechanism, as Mr Schäuble would like - but within the framework of the European treaties: a common budget, a euro finance minister, i.e. an EU commissioner , who also chairs the Eurogroup, also has more social responsibility and investments.We can do all of this within the framework of the contracts.Let's do it!

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Madam President, eurozone leaders remain mired in denial. It is true that, by its miserable standards, the common currency is having a less disastrous year, transforming itself from a snail to a tortoise in terms of growth, but a fortnight ago Mr Dombrovskis claimed that, after its inception, the euro quickly became a symbol of prosperity for our citizens. Tell that to Italians, whose economy is not much bigger than it was at the turn of the century! Tell it to Greeks, whose death rates have soared amid the collapse of the healthcare system! Mr Dombrovskis says recovery is firmly under way, after having incorrectly anticipated it for several years, but this so-called eurozone recovery is akin to a drunk managing to stagger three consecutive paces in a straight line. We know it is going to lurch face first into a brick wall at any moment, because this is a flawed political construct. To trap Greece and other southern economies in the same currency as Germany is simply folly. These economies need their own currencies that can depreciate to protect their activity levels in the face of Germany’s superior productivity path. They do not have Germany’s scale, brands, R&D budgets, communications infrastructure, technical education system, export networks, harmonious industrial relations or work ethic. Even their climates dictate a daily pause in activity. But instead of navigating back toward sensible economics, the EU keeps using the ideology of integration as its lodestar. Even Romania and Bulgaria are expected to join the euro, lining them up for the same fate as has been visited upon Greece. Unless the people of Germany are willing to fund giant and permanent transfer payments to the weaker parts, which they are not, there is no long-term case for expanding or deepening the eurozone. Do not deepen it: dump it.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioners for coming to the Parliament this afternoon. How we will make the Euro more stable by the year 2025? This is the key topic of the reflection paper put forward by the Commission which we are discussing this afternoon. A more stable euro and a more stable Economic and Monetary Union will undoubtedly lead to more growth, more investment and more jobs. The stability of the euro and the job creation process in the European Union is one of the main concerns of the citizens of the European Union, and this is why we have to address this.  How should we achieve this? Firstly: by respecting existing rules. More than 20 Member States of the Union, over the course of the recent years, have been in excessive deficit procedures. We still have six excessive deficit procedures open right now. We should not start now by questioning the rules which we have given to ourselves, but we should start by applying these rules, because, as we know, unsustainable debt leads to loss of trust, loss of credibility and is also a big burden for the economy. Besides respecting the rules, what should we do? Firstly, we should encourage and support the Member States of the Union to reform, to improve their competitiveness and to strengthen their economies. If this economic reality leads to the conclusion that we should adjust our institutional framework through the creation of a treasury and a finance minister, then we should be ready to think about this and to discuss it, but we should not start the debate about improving our economy by new changes in our institutional set—up in Brussels.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, thank you for this diagnosis. This is a useful line of thought in defending the common good that is the euro. For both political and economic reasons, we must preserve it. You will enlighten us on its weaknesses: it is useful to highlight the need to complete the Economic and Monetary Union, as has already been done in the report of the four presidents, in the report of the five presidents and in many resolutions of this Parliament, including the last on a budget for the euro zone. This analysis can be completed, because it is also necessary to point out the flaws in the conception of Economic and Monetary Union in its current state and in its development, which lead to the existence of rules that are too complex, too opaque, sometimes totally unsuitable and which induce a bias contrary to the investment necessary for the functioning of the euro zone itself. In the diagnosis, it seems to us perhaps that a sense of urgency is relatively lacking, because we are at a time when the strategic interest of the euro area needs to be reaffirmed, including in the context of Brexit . I would like to focus more on the solutions you are proposing, many of which are in line with what we are supporting and what we are working for, starting, as Commissioner Moscovici has indicated, with an arrangement that allows a more democratic functioning of the euro zone itself. Among the four guiding principles that you propose, I suggest that you add that of a contribution to sustainable development and to the implementation of the objectives of the Paris conference. I know we shouldn't make the boat too heavy, but all the same, we cannot divide our resources. You are proposing macroeconomic stabilization mechanisms: we welcome it, this is an essential avenue. We also suggest going to a code of convergence which makes it possible to escape an overly punitive logic and which favors an incentive system thanks to its own budget of the euro zone, of which the European stability mechanism should be the embryo.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - Madam President, the European Union is preparing a joint deposit guarantee, it sounds nice and European, but it is extremely unfair.Namely, the more countries have bad loans, the more likely they are that their banks will go bankrupt and this deposit, the joint deposit, will be guaranteed.There are a total of over EUR 1000 billion in bad credit in Europe, and let's look at where, in which countries, these bad loans are located.Portugal 41 billion, France 148, Spain 141, Greece 115, Italy 276. By comparison, Slovakia has only 2 billion bad loans, while only half as large as Greece or Portugal.Therefore, I fundamentally reject the joint guarantee of deposits, because once again the citizens of Slovakia will only pay for it, as was already the case in Greece, when we, a much poorer country, paid on Greek highways.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: - Madam President! First of all, thank you very much to the Commission. It is an important debate that is going on here. It is a good debate with different ideas, and the debate brings us back to the starting point of monetary union, namely convergence, and the question of how we can achieve convergence, that is to say how the economies in this single currency area will grow together. This raises a question that is often asked with a view to Germany, namely: Can we create more convergence by weakening the stronger members of the monetary union? I think this is the wrong way to go. We have to ensure that the weaker members can catch up, and that requires resolute reform policies. I am optimistic about France. I'm not that optimistic about Italy; I'm very worried about that. Second point: stabilization. There can be no-fault shocks, asymmetrical shocks. That is why it is right to upgrade the European Stability Mechanism. But, and that is the third point: rules are only adhered to if the incentive systems are in place. It is therefore impossible to build such a system without a state bankruptcy law. Because without that, there are disincentives for bad policies when it comes to solid public finances. But we need solid public budgets.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: - Madam President! As one of quite a few countries, we in Denmark have actually held a referendum on the euro. At the time, we were repeatedly told that it was only about finances, about interest rates, about exchange fees. Since then, it has turned out that it is not possible to have a monetary union with such different countries without also introducing a real political economic union. And that is also the development we have seen since the financial crisis. The building of a political union in which the EU puts strict control over the economies of the member states and in which thousands of citizens live with the consequences of cuts and welfare deterioration. One could have hoped that the Commission, with this vision paper, would have broken just a tiny bit with the austerity regime. But instead, there are plans for more EU unification, stronger control over the countries' economies and even stronger EU institutions with a euro finance minister! But dear friends, it may be tempting to try to solve the world's problems with more EU, but the citizens who live with the consequences today will not be heard in this proposal - on the contrary.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: - Repair the roof, of course you do better when the sun is shining. I think most would agree. And so it is logical and rightly so that the European Commission is relaunching the debate on the much-needed deepening and strengthening of the eurozone with the reflection paper. But everything stands or falls with a sound foundation, and according to the EPP that is primarily the Stability and Growth Pact - you stick to the rules that you agree with each other - and the trinity of structural reforms, investments and sound public finances. If we want to take steps towards perfecting the eurozone, we will have to work mainly on restoring confidence, and you do that through concrete measures. Yes, also through a European insurance system for deposits, but a system based on responsibilities where they belong: in the Member States and in Europe. It is not the case that you can shift your responsibility to the European level and then as a member state can say: save it. Hopefully, the only way we can start with such a system in 2019, because it is necessary, is to find a way to share that responsibility and not make it an excuse mechanism, not shifting responsibility towards Europe. In other words, concrete steps that restore confidence instead of a huge flight ahead with extra budgets of which no one knows how to be paid, ministers of which no one knows what they should do. Work on the concrete, then you work on trust.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the Commission's document on deepening and completing the Economic and Monetary Union. It is an ambitious and realistic document, at the same time, which in many points reflects the proposals put forward by this Parliament and which must now be transformed into a concrete roadmap. As for the financial union, the measures necessary for its completion are clear: guarantees and deposits, backstops just waiting to be concluded. With regard to the Economic and Fiscal Union, it is instead necessary to exit quickly from the stage of possible scenarios and undertake with courage and determination the one indicated by Parliament, and also present in the paper, namely the realization of an exchange between reinforced and binding mechanisms convergence of economic policies and the construction of a budgetary capacity of the euro area, to be placed in the Union budget and to be used for stabilization functions, of which the most effective is undoubtedly that of a European unemployment benefit. In this sense, it is useful to point out that this allowance does not require a prior harmonization of labor market rules, but on the contrary can contribute, together with other instruments, to create the conditions for greater convergence in this area. It is also important to clarify that, as Parliament has shown, both the Convergence Guidelines and the Fiscal Capacity can be implemented under constant treaties, without resorting to intergovernmental solutions, and on the basis of the Community method, which is the only one that can allow a appropriate democratic control. In this sense, I welcome the Commissioner's invitation to formalize the dialogue between Parliament and the Commission on the Semester, which for us is not an arrangement but an interinstitutional agreement. As far as the safe asset issue is concerned, this is a very important issue and positive, which of course needs to be addressed carefully to avoid risks to financial stability.Finally, as regards the integration of the Fiscal Compact, the lesson of recent years is that there is recovery and confidence, also because the rigid austerity policy has been overcome.So integration of the Fiscal Compact if there is its reform.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - The same mistake is often made in the European Union.When a problem is difficult, the big leap forward is made.Clear exit criteria for the euro are still lacking, but instead of establishing them, the Commission is now taking a giant leap forward.Unfortunately, no thought is given to how to solve the existing problems.What are those problems?France and a number of southern member states are not reforming the labor market and are not reforming financial-economic relations as the Netherlands and Germany have already done.The result is that debts remain and that unemployment grows.What has to happen?The instruments of the Stability and Growth Pact need to be used and perhaps slightly tightened.We should not incur joint debts.Countries themselves must implement reforms and reduce debt.Such a big step forward with a total EMU is really not necessary for that.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, in typical Commission fashion, a European unemployment insurance scheme is dangled like a carrot to gain public support, while the trade-off is the harmonisation of labour relations and anti-worker reforms. As for the proposed investment scheme, it is contradictory nonsense to create a scheme to protect investment during downturns while insisting on keeping the Fiscal Compact strait-jacket in place. These measures will not solve the eurozone structural problems, and they demand a trade-off in rights, democracy and popular sovereignty. I do not oppose transfers to correct imbalances but I will oppose them if they are conditional. Social rights cannot be dependent on economic performance or a state’s adherence to fiscal rules. Rights are rights. We will not fall for the trap of surrendering more ground on democratic rights in exchange for crumbs off the table. What we ultimately need is a real public investment plan to stimulate growth. We need effective sanctions against current-account surpluses, investment to be excluded from the fiscal rules, and rejection of the Fiscal Compact being enshrined in the Treaties at the end of this year.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, eighteen years after the debut of the euro, the optimal currency area that you promised us is not working. Many countries, including France, are victims of this fixed exchange rate system, which causes euro-divergence, including economic growth rates, unemployment rates, interest rates, sovereign debts as well as external debts are a serious problem. This situation forces states to pursue recessive policies of internal devaluation, modestly called structural reforms, intended to restore their economic competitiveness. In the wake of MM. Sarkozy and Hollande, President Macron will continue and increase this purge which, as we have seen in Spain and Greece, hits the most vulnerable hard. But that is not enough for you. To resolve the structural defects of this currency, you propose, in this report on Economic and Monetary Union, to dispossess the nations of their last economic and budgetary powers by transferring them to Berlin via its branch in Brussels. So, after removing our national borders with Schengen, our currency with the euro, our banks with the banking union, you are now attacking our public finances. Mr Macron, we will fight you politically to solve the problems of the euro area in the framework of intergovernmental cooperation and consultation.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, I believe that the demand for change in Europe provides strong legitimacy for difficult and far-reaching reforms when it comes to the governance and functioning of the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). It is true that there are changes feasible within the current Treaty framework but there are also others that need Treaty change, and of course discussions on decision-making processes are never without controversy. There might not be great haste or great enthusiasm to embark immediately on Treaty change. Nevertheless, this should not prevent us from analysing where our Treaties should be improved. But the challenge is not only to strengthen the architecture and governance of the EMU. We must also find a way to strengthen its democratic legitimacy. Lastly, we must make sure that the unavoidable integration gap between EMU members and the non-eurozone will be mitigated by safeguards protecting the integrity of the internal market and the consistency of policies across the Union.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner and Vice-President, the truth is that we all welcome this new report, which sets a medium-term scenario for monetary union. I think the recommendations they make make sense; probably some of them should be advanced in time, bearing in mind that this budgetary capacity should accommodate the new multi-year scenario, the new multi-year budget, which will have to be discussed in the coming years. In any case, one wonders when we are going to be able to move from roadmap plans to proposals. We were familiar with the report of Messrs. Van Rompuy and Barroso, in 2012. In 2014 we had the report of the five presidents. The Commission also published another White Paper, a few months ago, with different options for the Union. And now we have this Green Paper on monetary union. The reflection is fine, the discussion is fine, but we need concrete legislative proposals from the Commission and we also need this Parliament to respond to some that you have already tabled. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I would like to thank Mr Fernández very much because, of course, this action plan in particular creates new opportunities for employment.How do you think the small and medium-sized companies actually get a positive effect from these new framework conditions, which makes it very easy to operate not only in Europe, but above all in exports, with private-public partnership arguments, new marketsto develop and to ensure prosperity on both sides?

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: "blue card" response.- I very much appreciate the question, because closing the monetary union model should make it possible to expand the growth capacity of all the Union's economies and, therefore, offer new prospects for the future to SMEs - small and medium-sized enterprises -,that make up the core of the European economy.We are discussing and have been discussing initiatives within the framework of the capital market union to allow small companies to be financed not only by using banking channels, and I believe that this effort to improve the functioning of the Union and internal demand isa commitment to the future for the whole of the Union.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Indeed, the problem is convergence in the euro area - the convergence that is not happening. We have no convergence, Graf Lambsdorff, we have divergence in the euro zone. Over the past ten years, various countries in the euro zone that are poor have become poorer; income inequalities in the euro zone have increased. These income differences, which are now greater than they were ten years ago, now give the Commission reason to say: Then we have to redistribute, then we have to create some forms of transfers, then we have to try to use the resources that are available To bring countries into the poor countries. These are the steps the Commission can think of to do this. But that is curing the symptoms, it is not addressing the causes. The reason for this is that productivity developments are different in different countries. We cannot simply wish that they experience the same productivity developments everywhere, but we must acknowledge that they are different and that either wages will then develop very differently, which will lead to the EU or at least the euro zone becoming stronger Tensions are exposed, or that we have to abolish the euro so that the devaluations that previously led to convergence in the euro zone can take hold again. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Lucke, I agree with you on many points.Italy is the best example: there has been no improvement in productivity for 20 years.That is because of the labor market policy, it is because of the education policy, it is because of the refusal to reform, it is because of an overall social democratic understanding of politics, also with regard to the social partnership - I agree with you everywhere.But if the Commission had now said on its own: "We have to settle the whole thing with a transfer union", I would criticize that as harshly as you have just done.However, the Commission has not done that at the moment; it has started a debate on how we can use democratic control to ensure that convergence finally takes place.Would you agree with that?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Lambsdorff!I do not agree with you that democratic control will lead to the onset of convergence.I am completely with you in the criticism that you also expressed in your speech.But I do not believe that through structural reforms we will be able to get the countries that are now having difficulties in the euro zone like Germany or Denmark or the Netherlands.It is a wrong approach to believe that what we have in terms of structures in the advanced countries of the euro zone can simply be transferred one-to-one to other countries and that in the long run they will become like us.I believe we cannot pursue this approach any further.We have to respect and accept the heterogeneity and diversity of the countries in the euro zone.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, what your document brings to the table is that you do not have a plan for the euro;that seek to deepen the neoliberal reforms of the labor market and austerity, ignoring that it is these reforms that are tearing the euro zone apart, those that are impoverishing its periphery, those that are condemning entire generations to poverty, unemployment and unemployment.precariousness.It is not for lack of imagination, it is cowardice in the face of Germany that, like the Romans, created a desert and called it peace.A desert of relocations, of massive unemployment, of workers forced to dance to the sound of an international capital that plays the music to which the Commission and governments dance —for example, like that of my country, Spain—.Without transfers, without labor harmonization, without fiscal harmonization, the only future of the euro is its disintegration.Because no people can live to be a slave to a coin.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - Colleagues, creating a currency zone from member states that are so fundamentally different from each other socially and economically, that was asking for instability. In my opinion, instability was structurally ingrained in the euro concept. And now, as the failure becomes more apparent, we see that it is precisely this instability that you are using to push through your further European integration, your political integration. It is that instability of the currency that is used to smooth out the differences, and in that reflection paper that you are coming up with now, you come up with a political project in a pretty impudent way. A political project not only of the Banking Union and of the Capital Markets Union and of the Resolution Fund, but also of a fundamental continuation of the convergence standards and of a European Finance Minister and a European Parliament, and of course of European debt securities. You want to continue to smooth out the differences, which is precisely the un-European aspect of this entire project.
