The differences that have made Europe great, the differences in competition that have brought Europe to well-being and prosperity, are further smoothed out and we believe that this is a serious, fundamental mistake. It is the mistake that the European Union always makes: if there is a problem, there must be more European Union, the flight ahead. In our opinion, pushing through a political straightjacket to political unity is un-European. This is particularly the case with the monetary policy of your ECB. It should try to prevent instability by allowing southern European countries to park their debt on the ECB balance sheet, which inevitably leads to transfers. This is also the case for the monetary policy now conducted by Draghi, which ultimately fundamentally wastes our reserve capacities. The potential stimulus packages we need later if we have to prevent ourselves from entering a recession in the event of a downturn in the economy or the next crisis will no longer be possible.Your labor mobility, your immigration, your globalization - these are social flattenings whose price is the pressure on low wages and poverty.Debt levels are still the same as before the crisis.Member States no longer have brake pedals, no more motor, they no longer even control the steering wheel.You take all that away from them.We had better go back to the drawing board and return to the origins of what the European Union was: a Union of different countries that, by contrast, created more prosperity and more well-being for the population.You do the opposite.

name: Paul TANG
text: - The Commission's contribution comes at an excellent time.After the elections, the Franco-German axis can get going again and there is a new debate on the euro.That is high time, because the euro is not working properly.The euro should bring countries together, not tear them apart.It should ensure stability and, above all, full employment.But the European instruments for the European currency that are needed for this are lacking.A mutual guarantee fund, which was already voted in favor by the European Parliament in February, can ensure that public spending comes at the right time and in the right place.A European guarantee for savings can prevent banks from overturning countries.And democratic accountability must be improved.Why a shadowy Eurogroup and not a Eurozone parliament?In short, it is not too late for the euro to work.It is not too late to end the ostrich policy.It is now time to make choices.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Madam President, EMU and the euro have proved to be a mechanism for economic and political enforcement of specific policies in favor of the most economically powerful countries and in favor of capital. In the eighteen years of EMU, and especially in the years of crisis, in the name of fiscal stability, stricter austerity has been applied, resulting in widening regional and social inequalities. Countries such as Greece entered into a memorandum to save the banks and the euro. Memorandum governments, such as those of Greece, and European institutions have violated national constitutions, annulled referendums, discredited the will of the people and democracy. Today, the need to deepen EMU essentially calls for more austerity, more privatization, fewer workers' rights, and more unemployment and insecurity. For European peoples, EMU and the euro offer no prospects for prosperity and growth. The peoples of Europe will find alternative ways of economic cooperation outside and outside the shackles of the euro.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, the Vice-President, Mr Dombrovskis, rightly noted that our policies should not be mutually reinforcing on the basis of our common goals. And rightly so, the Commissioner, Mr Moscovici, has emphasized that a two-speed eurozone is dangerous. However, our declared policies, based on our goal of converging our economies, must also be evaluated a posteriori by their results. For example, it is known that the Banking Union also contains a European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, which is a key parameter for stability in EMU. But without its implementation, there is an indirect discrimination against Member States, especially in the European South, which is weak and small. This is a transfer of deposits to other Member States. Well, then, the big steps for a European Monetary Fund, but first let us fulfill what we have agreed.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: - Madam President, the European Union will succeed if two essential conditions are met: firstly, if this euro area succeeds in bringing prosperity and convergence between the Member States of the European Union, if solidarity between the Member States becomes a reality, which has not been the case so far, and, secondly, whether European citizens will continue to support the European Union. At the moment we do not have a safety net for European citizens. All the costs of these reforms are borne by European citizens and it is not normal for this to happen. That is why we need strong democratic control, that is why we need the involvement of the European Parliament in decision-making in this area, because the European Parliament is the only institution democratically elected by the citizens, representing the European citizens. Last but not least, there is no plan to support the countries that will join the euro area. There is no plan to support countries that will join the euro area in the future.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Madam President, the eurozone still faces two major fundamental problems: its component parts diverge economically and socially, and divergence is increasing. This allows parts of the system to automatically benefit from the rules of the game and others to lose out. Secondly, the only available mechanism to repair imbalances is internal devaluation. This creates huge social hardship which, when unfairly distributed, undermines the legitimacy of EMU. As in the Five Presidents’ report, the Commission paper lists the tools that could, if properly used, help to counteract these two major flaws. However, experience has shown that tools lined up to address the problems of European integration – unless they are properly structured through political agreement – correct symptoms while leaving underlying problems to fester. This has been the case with the application of the two—pack and six—pack process, so we have budgetary balances while public investment remains in decline. Any new structural change in the eurozone’s structure would need a prior political agreement between eurozone members regarding how such change would operate. Leaving it to be guided by free market forces or making it subservient to the dogma that there can be no transfer union would again simply give greater impetus to divergences while allowing social unfairness resulting from internal devaluation to grow.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam President, the completion and strengthening of Economic and Monetary Union is necessary, because it is a way to achieve the goals that are important to all of us, and that is the growth and development of the European Union, job creation, economic convergence, financial stability.The first step on that path is, as many colleagues pointed out, the quality application of the existing rules.But I would also add changes and adjustments in the parts that analyzes show would be useful and necessary - we must not be afraid to be flexible.Member States outside the EMU should be supported and assisted on the path to this important integration, especially those that apply all the rules and meet almost all the criteria, such as Croatia, from which I come.All Member States should be involved in decision-making on the future of EMU, be in Eurogroup meetings, if we seriously think that their integration is secure in the near future.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a true economic and monetary union requires first and foremost the promotion of the general interest of the euro area and greater transparency of decision-making in the monetary and financial fields. Greater European integration, particularly financially, can only help strengthen Europe in the globalized market. A possible roadmap for 2025 would include issuing sovereign bond-backed securities for the euro area, establishing common support for the resolution fund, and simplifying the rules of the stability pact. In essence, we must bring Maastricht's Europe to completion by equipping it with a reference financial institution. To do this, it is necessary to be able to seize the moment and exploit the positive signs of deficit reduction throughout the eurozone, creating a framework in which responsibility and solidarity go hand in hand, starting with the guarantee of sovereign debt. But even before that, it is necessary to ensure that the economic and social aspects converge, especially at a time like the present one, marked by new nationalisms and populisms that are rowing in the opposite direction, asking to return to the competing European states.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the philosophy and structure of the euro area is leading to imbalances, resulting in increased trade surpluses in Germany and trade deficits in the South. At the same time, Economic and Monetary Union did not envisage any system of fiscal solidarity and the creation of Eurobonds. As a result, we have armies of the poor and the unemployed, with the countries of southern Europe turning into "colonies" of German Europe. We reiterate our position that the National Central Banks must become the ultimate lenders of their own countries. At the same time, the European System of Central Banks needs to become even more decentralized and flexible, with the aim of the National Central Banks pursuing an independent monetary policy, tailored to the needs of their country's economy, using conventional and non-conventional instruments, such as quantitative easing. easing), creating money without the approval of the European Central Bank and up to the percentage of the participation of each National Central Bank in the current balance sheet of the Eurosystem, which currently amounts to 3.5 trillion euros.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, I heard earlier that, apparently, the symbol had become a symbol of prosperity. You can try and dream that up and say it is true, but it is not true. It is a symbol of incompetence; it is a symbol of bad planning. In fairness, you have admitted that there was bad planning, that you did not have the right architecture in place, and it was not very well organised. Imagine you went out in the morning and bought a car, but when you went out to drive it you discovered when the dark came that there were no lights, and when you tried to put your foot on the brakes, it would not stop and crashed into the ditch. You have admitted that you caused the problem, but when that happens – when you go for something, when you promise something – if it goes wrong, you get compensation for what happened. In Ireland, we got hit the tune of EUR 60 billion because you had no brakes or no lights on this vehicle. We are currently picking the glass out of our face. EUR 6 billion in the last two years we have borrowed and burned. Symbol of prosperity? Cop on, get real!

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about a euro which, together with the Stability and Growth Pact and the Fiscal Compact, has hanged citizens, exacerbating inequalities, accentuating the effects of the crisis, leading thousands to suicide. The paper on the euro indicates it as an instrument of success, of convergence, to be preserved or even carried forward. And with what? With the banking union, with the Capital Market Union, with tools to satisfy the bulimia of big finance? The euro was supposed to give prosperity, instead it increased poverty and misery. The euro was supposed to push integration instead it fueled resentment and hatred. The euro was meant to be a means and instead became the end of every political action to be defended at any cost. But Europe today is also made up of countries that do not have the euro and that are in the EFTA and is made up of many citizens who would like the union of peoples, cohesive to protect the social well-being and rights of each. A union that is strengthened cooperation and solidarity. No paper has yet appeared on a Union like this. While you deal with finance, the euro and the markets, there are more than 500 million citizens out there waiting for a Europe that has not yet been seen.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the title of this discussion is a reflection paper on the deepening of EMU by 2025, and I would like to compliment Commissioner Moscovici and Vice-President Dombrovskis for coming here and making their presentations and taking the views of Parliament on board. I am quite sure they will reflect on what has been said and eventually come up with good, practical proposals. One of the nicest headlines I have seen in the last couple of weeks was one which said: ‘Eurozone economy grows more than expected’ – 1.9%, in fact – and I was here in the last mandate when everybody was forecasting the demise of the euro and the European Union. Now that measures have been taken to get things on a proper footing and things are beginning to grow again, it is only right that we should reflect and see how we can keep this growing without impinging on national sovereignty. I think this is a good discussion and we can get good progress in due course.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, you said that the euro is a symbol of the European Union. Earlier, we celebrated the 30th anniversary of Erasmus, another symbol if there is one, and I am convinced that the euro has helped make our students convinced Europeans. We cannot look at this single currency with bliss, however. On the contrary, we need to do a critical analysis to better support this currency which has become, somewhere, the DNA of the European Union. Hence the necessary work carried out by the Commission on Economic and Monetary Union with the idea of ​​creating a strong and democratic euro area. A euro zone budget would indeed be the engine of a new economic development based on investments for the future, in particular those linked to ecological transition, and thus allowing the creation of jobs which European youth so badly need. . This zone should, of course, constitute a space of solidarity to reduce social and fiscal inequalities.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Vice-President and the Commissioner for the presentation. The more integrated the eurozone is economically, the stronger the EU will be. However, with the UK looking to develop a new relationship with the EU it is really critical that we have clarity in how capital markets union (CMU) becomes a reality for the EU-27. Given the important role the UK is playing in terms of market finance and given the importance of the euro as a global currency, how does this reconcile with calls to localise CCPs out of the UK?  Secondly, with the CMU mid-term review, one of the focuses is on greening of the CMU. This is really welcome and positive, but more needs to be done, for example on the investment side. How do we ensure, Commissioner and Vice-President, that greening of the EU economy finance becomes mainstream? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: blue-card question. – First off, congratulations on Labour’s great result. I would like to ask you this question: do you regret Britain not joining Economic and Monetary Union? If it had joined, Jeremy Corbyn would not have been able to make the wonderful promises that he did to put money into the economy and borrow forward into the future. You would not have been allowed to do that. You would not have had a choice in the election if you had joined EMU. Are you sorry you did not join it, or are you glad?

name: Neena GILL
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the congratulations and indeed we are very pleased with the result. We hope that this will lead to a different kind of relationship between the EU and the UK and that is what we are looking to do. Of course we had our reasons in terms of whether we could join the eurozone or not. The timing was not right for us and I am not going to go into what would have been the consequences had we joined or not. I think it was absolutely the right decision at the time for the UK not to join, but we wish the eurozone every success because our economy depends on the eurozone being successful.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this debate, which has been high-level and very constructive. Obviously, as you can imagine, the Commission feels closer to those who want to give the euro area greater strength and greater ambition than to those who believe in ideas, in my view quite regressive, that it is good. to undo it and come back to some sort of previous situation, for which we must not keep nostalgia. I would just like to make two points in this conclusion. The first is that I am convinced that it is time to make the euro a tool for shared growth and not just stability. That’s what it is about. The crucial question is that of convergence and the reduction of territorial, social and economic inequalities within the euro zone to assume the cohesion of the euro and to fight against Euroscepticism which in turn feeds populism. . From this point of view, there is a notion that I retain from your debate, which is that we must strike a balance between the tools of solidarity, which are essential, and the principle of solidarity as well as the rules without which there is no euro zone that holds. But, at the same time, all this must be integrated in all fields: financial, economic and monetary. Finally, my last remark cuts across all the speeches that have been made here, and that is that we need more democracy in the euro zone but not more technocracy. We need to be accountable, we need transparency. There are, in fact, situations which cannot last indefinitely and which do not concern - you were right to say this, Mr Papadimoulis - only Greece, but which concern us all. A euro zone budget must be voted on and must be controlled. For this it is very clear that even though parliaments national governments play an important role, in my opinion, it is the European Parliament which must play the leading role and which must be at the heart of this democratic construction.This debate is only just beginning.It is to be continued and we will continue it with you.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the honourable Members for this debate. It clearly shows that views are often quite divergent, and indeed that there is no single answer or one-size-fits-all solution to the future shape of our Economic and Monetary Union. What is needed is an overall common approach and a vision of the future of our single currency. The challenge now is to put the different ideas into practical solutions and to identify a way forward that is pragmatic and flexible, yet effective. The objective is to restart the process of convergence, to strengthen the euro as a source of shared prosperity and economic and social welfare, and to ensure inclusive and balanced growth, and price stability. This reflection paper is the Commission’s contribution to the debate on the way forward. We look forward to working closely and constructively with the European Parliament to deepen Economic and Monetary Union.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - We all welcome this new report, which sets a medium-term scenario for the monetary union. I think the recommendations that are made make sense. Closing the monetary union model should make it possible to expand the growth capacity of all the Union's economies and, therefore, offer new prospects for the future to small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up the core of the European economy. Some of them should probably be advanced in time, bearing in mind that this budgetary capacity should accommodate the new multi-year scenario, the new multi-year budget, which will have to be discussed in the coming years. In any case, it is necessary to move from plans, from roadmaps, to proposals. Let us recall the report by Van Rompuy and Barroso, in 2012. In 2014 the report of the five presidents was published. The Commission also published another White Paper, a few months ago, with different options for the Union. And now we have this Reflection Paper on the monetary union. The reflection is fine, the discussion is fine, but we need concrete legislative proposals from the Commission.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - One of the European Union's greatest achievements is the continent's common currency. Slowly, all Member States adopt the euro. Among our neighbors, Slovaks and Slovenes have long since adopted, and Romanians and Bulgarians will now adopt the euro. Unfortunately, this is not even the case in Hungary, despite the fact that we meet all the conditions. In countries using the single currency, economic growth has begun and exchange rate risk has completely disappeared. In Slovakia, for example, people have been living much better since the introduction of the euro, and living standards have started to rise brutally. Moreover, there is a common EU protection behind bank deposits in the euro area. The euro is the second most important currency in the world behind the US dollar. Why don't we want to introduce it? Why don't we want Hungarians to enjoy all the benefits of a common, strong euro? We are committed to Hungary's accession to the euro, which represents the interests of the Hungarian people.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: signed up. - I welcome the European Commission's initiative to discuss directions for deepening Economic and Monetary Union. I regret that this report has abandoned the idea of ​​agreeing with non-euro area Member States on action plans and foreseeable dates for the changeover to the euro. These Member States, with the exception of Denmark, have undertaken to take all necessary measures for the changeover to the euro and most of them meet the accession criteria. We find that, under pressure from the banking system in particular, the governments of these Member States are "discovering" all sorts of arguments against joining the euro. This position is contradictory: on the one hand, these countries are declaring themselves to deepen their integration, and on the other hand, they are postponing their accession to the euro for an indefinite future. I believe that it is time for non-euro area Member States to present a concrete action plan and a deadline for joining the euro to the European Commission and the European Central Bank. This deadline should not be beyond 2025.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on glyphosate and the authorization procedures by Angélique Delahaye, Miriam Dalli, Julie Girling, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Kateřina Konečná, Bart Staes, Piernicola Pedicini and Jean-François Jalkh, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000046/2017 - B8-0316 / 2017) (2017/2695 (RSP))

name: Miriam DALLI
text: author. – Madam President, glyphosate, which we are speaking about today and the oral question that we are presenting and the topic that it is focusing on, is the world’s most used herbicide, and obviously the European Union is no exception to this. The carcinogenity and the genotoxicity of the substance are confirmed by certain studies but denied by others. The fact is, that it is undeniable that there are serious doubts as to the substance’s safety. The Commission keeps on insisting that it arrives to its decisions based on two things: scientific evidence and the rule of law. The issue we are dealing with today goes further. It is about the lack of transparency; it is about questionable scientific reliability and scientific independence. It is about losing public trust and about corporate giants overstepping their authority – and yes, transparency matters. The glyphosate hazard classification process of the European Commission and its two agencies, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA), appears to be a good example of how lack of transparency regarding the scientific evidence that underlies important public health decisions can end up eroding public trust and raise serious concerns. Independent analysis indicates serious flaws in the EFSA and ECHA safety assessments – namely, eight instances where increases in tumours as a response following glyphosate exposure were not included in the assessment by either agency. In March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, which forms part of the World Health Organisation, said that glyphosate was ‘probably carcinogenic to humans’. On the other hand, the Commission is claiming that ECHA and EFSA concluded that the available scientific evidence did not meet the criteria to classify glyphosate as a carcinogen, as a mutagen or as toxic for reproduction. No wonder that questions and doubts still exist. Is it too extreme to imagine that there could be an expert panel, financed by corporate giants, who would conclude that available data will not support the conclusion that that glyphosate is a ‘probable human carcinogen’? How can we be sure of the validity of the conclusions about the safety or otherwise of glyphosate when there is lack of transparency, and when it has been publicly revealed by the latest US court cases that the scientific data provided by the company experts was falsified? We have to take a strong stand on this issue. Until we know for certain that glyphosate is safe for our citizens and the environment, we cannot allow this substance to be freely sold in the EU market. And this is why we are presenting this Oral Question: we want to understand what steps the Commission is taking to make sure that the decision on the renewal of glyphosate is based on credible and independent scientific findings. We want the Commission to recommend ECHA and EFSA to critically revise the validity of the current studies, and not to propose the approval of glyphosate as long as the scientific uncertainties have not been clarified. We also require the Commission to rapidly ensure an independent review of the classification of glyphosate in relation to hormone disruption, genotoxicity and carcinogenity. Finally, we want the Commission to promote and support the agricultural sector so that our farmers can move towards glyphosate-free agriculture, and towards alternative sustainable and cost-efficient solutions for pest management. We asked precise questions on behalf of the Environment Committee to the Commission, and we are looking forward to precise detailed answers. Ultimately, people’s right to health and a healthy environment should be our priority at all times.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am pleased to attend this plenary session to talk about a substance which has generated a great deal of interest and debate, namely glyphosate. I hope that you will allow me a bit of time to insist on this point as it was repeatedly requested by various Members of this House who asked for the debate today, and of course I had slightly different questions compared to those which I received in writing. I believe that it is of the utmost importance to reply as precisely as possible to the specific questions raised by honourable Members. On the chronology of events: as you know, glyphosate is the most frequently used active substance in herbicide products in Europe as it is has already been on the national markets since 1970s. It was previously subject to national approval processes. Since 1 July 2002, this substance has been approved for use at European Union level after a review assessment. It is currently under evaluation as regards a possible renewal of its approval. This evaluation is done following the procedures laid down in the EU legislation concerning pesticides. This is a very strict legislation which you wisely contributed to put it in place. In April 2015, in accordance with the legislation, a comprehensive assessment of all available data was carried out by the Rapporteur Member State, Germany. This assessment included both studies that industry legally has to submit and independent peer—reviewed scientific literature. This assessment was then also peer reviewed by all other European Union Member State bodies and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) – a lot of bodies together, as you can see. An agency of the World Health Organization (WHO), the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), also carried out an assessment and concluded, in March 2015, that glyphosate is ‘probably carcinogenic’ to humans (Classification Group 2a). This is why, taking into account public concern, I asked EFSA to ensure that the IARC assessment was fully considered in the EU peer review of glyphosate.  In November 2015, EFSA concluded, in contrast to IARC, that glyphosate is unlikely to pose a carcinogenic hazard to humans. But the same conclusion was also reached by all – except one – of the regulatory agencies in the European Member States: 27 agencies. In 2016-2017, the same conclusions were also reached by agencies in Japan, New Zealand, Canada and Australia – a lot of agencies worldwide. In May 2016, the Joint Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) and WHO Meeting on Pesticide Residues also reached their conclusions, taking into account the work of IARC, which was only a first step in the WHO assessment. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that, even without mentioning tobacco, solar radiation or processed meat – alcoholic beverages are, for instance, classified by IARC in Group 1 as ‘carcinogenic to humans’, contrary to glyphosate. But only glyphosate is high on the agenda in public debates. Does this mean that I should label processed meat or alcoholic beverages as carcinogens, or even ban them? That is an open question.  In 2016, the Commission discussed a possible renewal of the approval of glyphosate with the Member States. Following the divergent opinions between, as I mentioned, IARC and EFSA – and also between different Member States – on the carcinogenic potential of glyphosate, the Commission took a cautious approach, also in light of legitimate public concern. We also used the precautionary approach and therefore made a proposal to extend the expiry date of glyphosate until 31 December 2017 (at the latest!) to enable the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) to deliver its opinion on the hazardous properties of glyphosate based on the proposal from the Rapporteur Member State, namely Germany. In parallel, in April 2016, your House adopted a resolution asking to renew glyphosate for seven years. As always, the Commission was very attentive to this expression of Parliament’s position. We took good note of your support for a renewal of the approval based on scientific assessment conducted in the EU. Lastly, on 15 March 2017, ECHA’s Committee for Risk Assessment (RAC) concluded that glyphosate should not be classified as carcinogenic, mutagenic or toxic for reproduction. In recent weeks various sources have reported on the so—called ‘Monsanto papers’. First, the facts. According to media reports and correspondence sent to the Commission, a US Court ordered the release of documents following a freedom of access to documents request, which you mentioned in your speech. I will now turn to your first question. You rightly pointed to a very important aspect: ‘in light of public concern, to ensure credible and independent scientific findings’. In this field, as in others, I heard and listened to public concerns and many questions are legitimate and I am happy to provide you once again with answers. From 2014 when I took office, I have indeed received a lot of letters, messages and emails concerning glyphosate, together with a European Citizens’ Initiative registered in January this year, a request for a urine sample last year, and even a citizens’ Monsanto Tribunal. This shows a real picture of different opinions and concerns. We are working on this. For some people, glyphosate is a symbol of intensive agriculture and strongly linked to GMOs. This debate is broader than glyphosate, but this is why the need to maintain a strong scientific assessment in this context is crucial. We will also always take public concern very much into account. This is why we asked EFSA and ECHA to indicate what impact the allegations, if confirmed, would have on the Agencies’ overall assessment and conclusions on glyphosate.  Both ECHA and EFSA reached the same conclusion. EFSA confirmed that: ‘even if the allegations regarding ghost-writing proved to be true, there would be no impact on the overall assessment as presented in the EFSA Conclusion on glyphosate’. ECHA confirmed that: ‘the information contained in the so—called “Monsanto papers” did not have an impact on the overall assessment as presented in the draft opinion of the Committee for Risk Assessment (RAC) on 15 March 2017’. This is because ‘EU experts had access to the raw data and to the original study reports’ and they produced their own independent conclusions based on the original data and not on another interpretation of it.  In contrast, the articles mentioned were study reviews summarising or substantiating the industry position on glyphosate that had been presented elsewhere. These study reviews were known by all assessing bodies and are not new as they were mentioned in the Declarations of Interests of the participating experts.  In other words, the study reviews have limited weight in the overall scientific assessment of glyphosate and, I quote, ‘would not normally on their own be sufficient for a conclusion to be reached on a harmonised classification’. This answer is from scientific bodies. The statements of both agencies have been available online since last week. Overall, there is thus broad convergence between the European and international community of scientists on the fact that glyphosate is not carcinogenic, keeping an eye on public opinion and different views around the world. All agencies – in Japan, Canada, New Zealand, Australia, the EU – came to the same conclusion and only one agency, IARC, had a different opinion. It was little strange to see that so many scientific bodies agreed but we will ask once again how to move forward, keeping an eye on scientific based arguments.  While individual persons may continue to disagree with this overwhelming convergence of scientific opinions, this cannot call into question the robustness of our system and we should proceed with the renewal of the approval of glyphosate as there is no reason to doubt the evidence-based arguments about the safety of the substance. Therefore the Commission decided, in light of public concern, to propose a renewal for ten years. In parallel, three very clear recommendations to Member States were adopted last year: first, to ban the co—formulant Tallowamine from glyphosate-based products; second, to minimise use in public parks, public playgrounds and gardens; and, third, to be attentive to the pre-harvest use of glyphosate. Let me also recall that, even if glyphosate is approved at EU level, it is within the responsibility of Member States to authorise plant protection products containing glyphosate at national level and decide on the conditions of use. They of course have the right to ban it because it concerns co-formulants. The Commission is therefore not the only one to decide when it comes to pesticides.  On your second sub-question, on investigation, let me stress that, in the case you refer to, the Commission does not have any proof that the allegations are correct. I am not a lawyer but I know that we have a very thorough assessment. Let me turn now to your second question. I can confirm that the way in which data and information is provided to the regulatory authorities and shared with the public for consideration of the approval of substances will be examined in the context of the REFIT evaluation of the European Union pesticides legislation. Indeed the Commission is specifically asking the external contractor that will conduct an external study on the preparation of the REFIT evaluation to look into this issue. This is actually reflected in the terms of reference which are publicly available, as is everything we do.  As the REFIT evaluation of the EU pesticide legislation and the fitness check of the General Food Law are still ongoing, it is a little bit too early to make assumptions or consider a different course of action at this stage. However, I would like to stress that the outcome of the fitness check of the General Food Law will also be publicly available, once completed, and the outcome of the REFIT evaluation of the EU pesticide legislation will be presented to this Parliament.  In the meantime, I am aware that Parliament is preparing an own—initiative report on the implementation of the Plant Protection Products Regulation. The Commission will of course carefully examine this report and its conclusions once it is finalised and will consider this during the preparation of the REFIT evaluation.  I will now turn to your third question. Let me start by first highlighting that the process of examining the claims made by companies to exclude the public release of certain information is, of course, directly managed by EFSA and Member States. Such claims are considered in conjunction with the rules outlined in the Plant Protection Products Regulation and the relevant rulings of the Court of Justice.  In this context, the Court of Justice rulings of November 2016 in relation to the implementation of the Aarhus Convention in the EU concern two important issues: first, access to confidential information related to the manufacturing and detailed composition of substances, in this case concerning the original approval of glyphosate; and, second, disclosure of studies on substances and formulated products submitted to Member States in the context of product authorisation. In the first ruling the Court of Justice referred the case back to the General Court and the proceedings before the Court are still pending. As regards the protection of confidentiality and access to information at issue in this case, the Commission is awaiting the outcome. I can assure you that I welcome the initiative to have more clarity in this field. There is no doubt that we need more clarity.  In the second case, the Court of Justice defined information on emissions into the environment with regard to studies submitted for active substances in plant protection and biocidal products. The Commission and the Member States are currently assessing the consequences of this judgment.  I would like to emphasise the following: first, at my request, the companies applying for renewal of the approval of glyphosate made available to Members of Parliament and stakeholders the key studies underlying the assessment of glyphosate in a reading room; and, second, in addition EFSA provided Members of Parliament and stakeholders with access to raw data from a number of key studies, following a request for access to documents. This access is on top of the extensive documentation that had already been made available as part of the standard procedures by EFSA during the peer review of glyphosate.  Therefore, one can only conclude that there has been a particularly high level of transparency in the specific case of glyphosate in the light of public concern. I understand that this might not be enough for some of you in this House and I am also aware that a complaint is about to be lodged with the Court of Justice. Once again, I can only welcome the increased clarity that the Court would give on this matter.  Let me now turn to your fourth and last question. I would like to stress that the Commission, through its research and innovation programmes – such as the Seventh Framework Programme and Horizon 2020 – supports a broad body of research in plant protection to identify new low—risk products and biological control techniques. This is what I highlighted again last week in a very interesting conference in Parliament on biological low—risk pesticides.  Let me stress again that in the Seventh Framework Programme over EUR 100 million was invested by the European Union in cooperative research projects and coordination support actions in the areas of plant protection, plant health, integrated pest management, and risk assessment and diagnostics.  Furthermore, specifically in relation to alternatives to chemical herbicides, a Horizon 2020 initiative, supported by an EU contribution of EUR 7 million, is currently looking at strategies, tools and technologies for sustainable weed management. So, as you will notice, a lot of money has already been invested already in terms of research and development.  With regard to sustainable plant protection more specifically, the need to find alternatives to traditional chemical solutions is also reflected in the Sustainable Use of Pesticides Directive, which aims at reducing the risks and impacts of pesticide use on human health and the environment, and at promoting the use of integrated pest management and of alternative approaches or techniques such as non-chemical alternatives to pesticides.  The Commission audits Member States to monitor implementation of the Directive and also encourages Member States to share best practice, identify challenges and ensure harmonisation. The Commission is also undertaking several actions to increase the availability of low-risk products. These actions include prioritisation of the assessment for the renewal of potentially low-risk substances and amendment of the low-risk criteria to facilitate their identification.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, you said, Commissioner, we must take decisions on the basis of sound scientific analyzes and not on postures. Of course, the subject is technical, but it has become, as you have said, political. We owe it to ourselves to protect the health of our fellow citizens in general, but and in particular that of users. We have a system in place for the authorization of substances, and no offense to some, just because the results don't suit us, doesn't mean we have to attack it or go through the back door to modify it, when it suits us. On the other hand, we must have confidence in our system in order to assure citizens that the decisions that are taken are in their best interests. Today's debate is obviously welcome, since doubts have crept in for a year, as you have stressed, Commissioner, and these doubts remain for different reasons:. First, the different approaches of our agencies, some based on risk, others based on danger - and all of this creates confusion, unfortunately well-nurtured. I have confidence in our system, Commissioner, and then, as you have pointed out, Parliament took a consensual stance on in a resolution last year. But given the mistrust of our fellow Europeans and given that a doubt exists and is emerging, we need to clarify things. In this regard, I hope that you will be able to go a little further in the answers you have started to give us, on the clarifications made given and the measures taken by the Commission and the measures it is taking for better transparency of its decisions which are taken by the latter, in order to restore confidence lost by some.You have been questioned by researchers.I would like to know how the Commission has taken this question into account.by the Commission, And do you know what the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) have done, or have done with this information?You pointed out that many agencies around the world are highlighting that this substance does not present a risk of cancer with this substance.Unfortunately, we have to go further and I hope that we have, for professionals, alternative solutions that are economically viable and environmentally viable in economic and environmental terms.On this point, I would also like you to go further on the measures and the funding of research.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for your intervention, I know the work you are doing within the Commission and I would like to thank you publicly for it. That said, it is true that, on the issue of glyphosate, the position taken by the Commission regarding the renewal of its use for ten years does not appear to be suitable for the current situation, as it is true - you have recalled it. in your remarks - that we are at the heart of a strong controversy, even if a good number of studies - you have said it too - reveal that glyphosate is not potentially carcinogenic. However, others say the opposite. It is true that, at this time when we have to choose, you, as a Commission, but also we, here, in Parliament, have a duty to ensure the quality and the veracity of scientific approaches. You are not a scientist, neither are we here, and we have to rely on real research. But, at the moment, not relying on the precautionary principle does not seem to me appropriate as a responsible and political position. You also said it, you referred to the "Monsanto Papers" and we both know the revelations that are made there. At the time when the American justice and the Californian court take up this situation, it appears, to our knowledge, that Monsanto would have known since 1999 that this molecule was potentially carcinogenic. Today, it is in this context that the debate has been rekindled, here, through this oral question. In any case and as far as I am concerned, I cannot take responsibility for it and I will not participate in what can or could potentially amount to a criminal act, as long as it is true that, if it were revealed It is true that glyphosate was potentially carcinogenic, we should collectively take great responsibility. Also I you solemnly requests that this absolute precautionary principle be applied immediately and then to take into account, as you have expressly said, all the scientific expertise on this subject and not only those carried out by the agencies of theEuropean Commission, and finally allow access to all their studies for the sake of absolute transparency.Finally, I ask you to prepare, as of now, other possible molecules for our farmers in the event that glyphosate turns out to be potentially carcinogenic because, once again, if we do nothing, they will be the first victims ofa system of which they are hostages.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: blue card question to Mrs Delahaye.- Mr President, the blue card I picked up was for a question to the previous speaker.You did not notice me.I think he can be given the opportunity to answer now.I did not understand at all what her position was, whether she was for or against this substance and I would ask her to clarify it further.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: "blue card" answer to Takis Hadjigeorgiou.- Sir, it seems very clear to me in the comments I made earlier that the question is not whether we are for or against, but whether or not this product presents a danger for thehuman health.I am waiting for scientists to give us clear and sure answers so that I can assume my role as elected representative.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Glyphosate has been widely used as an ingredient or plant protection product for years and has been under discussion for years, and we are still operating with too many unknowns in these discussions. Conflicting reports on the harmfulness of glyphosate continue to appear, and moreover, emotions often prevail in the discussion, and they do not facilitate an honest voice and assessment of the glyphosate situation. However, I am appealing not for emotions, but for a matter-of-fact and strictly scientific approach to the issue, harmonized primarily on the scientific level and only in a further context on the economic or social level, where health safety must be a priority. While some recent studies have noted successive cases of carcinogenic correlations of glyphosate, so that some Members even suspect European agencies of manipulating scientific data, it is in line with the above that I very openly call on the European Commission to, firstly, closely monitor and closely cooperate with the European Food Safety Authority and European Chemicals Agency and others. These agencies should also absolutely cooperate with the US Environmental Protection Agency to jointly develop some appropriate system, firstly for collecting and analyzing scientific data, but also working out a specific modus operandi to resolve ambiguities about glyphosate in the health context. Not emotions, but scientific evidence, and what's more, Commissioner, we need greater transparency of the European institutions.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the glyphosate saga therefore continues. The ball is once again here at home in the European Parliament, fourteen months to the day after the vote on our resolution which already called for its ban in specific uses. From study to study, from agency to agency, from expert to second-expert, opinions follow one another and are not alike and there is no clarity, to put it mildly. Last March, it was the "Monsanto Papers" that set public opinion on fire in the United States. Declassified documents have spoken. Monsanto had serious concerns as early as 1999 about the mutagenic nature of glyphosate. A cover-up of evidence if there is, but the investigation will have to say so. The ALDE Group, which I represent, continues to trust and want to trust the work of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA), which has its headquarters in Helsinki. We also know very well - and the Commissioner reminded them - that, on this dossier, as on GMOs, for example, the Member States hide their divisions and do not take their responsibilities. However, there is no more time to waste: the Commission’s roadmap should be based on a few principles. The Commission must ensure that its final decision is based on independent scientific studies and not on biased work and documents provided by Monsanto or other firms. In this transitional phase, before December, it is imperative for the Commission to change its model and finally move to a logic of progressive ban of the substance, rather than re-registration and derogation. We must also give the European agencies the means to achieve their ambitions. I find it quite shocking - I say this in passing - that EFSA's budget is almost four times that of the European Medicines Agency, when food is the third item of expenditure for European households.This is what you should do, Commissioner, but which you are most likely not going to do, given what you have just answered us this afternoon.Basically, all the elements are known, I quote you, there is nothing to declare, worse still, the "Monsanto Papers" will not change anything, circulate.It is a staggering end of inadmissibility, which I find regrettable, and I still use a euphemism, because, the main thing - and sometimes the obvious facts must be hammered out - is that your principle of actionpublic, it must be the precautionary principle, Commissioner.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - What has been happening in recent years at the European Commission and EFSA regarding the authorization of glyphosate is outrageous. I wouldn't be afraid to use the word farce at all. The European Parliament has on several occasions given clear instructions to the Commission on this matter, which it clearly does not follow. In the meantime, one scandal after another is leaking over Monsanto and their already proven direct influence on the scientific studies of glyphosate. The study, which can reasonably be assumed, is also used by EFSA to support its position on the safety of glyphosate. At the same time, even after years of pressure, no one has seen these studies. They are still not even available to the International Agency for Research on Cancer, which has identified glyphosate as possibly carcinogenic. According to the leaked communication, it is clear that Monsanto did not even shy away from practices such as writing his own studies, which only some scientists eventually signed for them and subsequently pretending to be independent. In addition, for 17 years, the company has suspected that their flagship product is carcinogenic and is trying to cover it up to prevent it. And EFSA and the Commission are still silent. That is why it remains with the European Parliament again. Unless the European Commission urgently investigates how these Monsanto practices have affected EFSA's assessment of glyphosate, I would be in favor of setting up a committee of inquiry to examine the matter. Commissioner, you do not need an extra 20 minutes to explain. We want one thing from you: real actions.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, if I have understood the Commissioner well, then everything is fine, everything has been done properly and we can just continue. That is more or less the summary of his 15 minute speech. That, however, is not really paying attention to the huge scientific debate that has been ongoing on glyphosate from the 1980s onwards, broader than only carcinogenicity – it is broader than that – but secondly and more importantly, it is ignoring the fact that the Monsanto papers show that Monsanto was unduly influencing studies that were being used also, later on, by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). That is a concern and the problem is that EFSA is saying that they used more studies, one that for example the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) did not use, but do not have access to it. So we do not know exactly which studies have been used by EFSA to come to those conclusions. It is lack of transparency, it is lack of trust in these organisations, and we see in the United States that there is undue influence from Monsanto. We want a good investigation by the Commission on this issue, otherwise we will have to do it ourselves.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the deadline for the re—approval of the use of glyphosate in the EU is rapidly approaching, and soon a decision must be made on this very important issue. Although I agree that the release of recent confidential documents disclosed to the public in the US are reason for concern, we take the position that glyphosate is one of the few herbicides that our farmers have at their disposal, and compared to earlier products is safer. Glyphosate is the world’s most widely used herbicide, and such products are also used in public and private gardens, as well as in agriculture. However, as much as I would like to see herbicides phased out completely, realistically this is not possible, especially in the UK where we have a very mild, damp climate which is conducive to weed growth. Until an alternative product is found, I believe that we cannot remove a necessary tool from the arsenal of farmers who cultivate vast areas of land. I would, however, like to see Member States give more encouragement and financial help to those farmers that wish to farm organically.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. President, to speak of glyphosate is obviously to speak of Monsanto's weight, but also of the opacity concerning the disclosure of studies carried out on this product and on its impact on the environment and therefore on humans. The European Chemicals Agency has refused to classify this product as carcinogenic, which obviously allows it to remain on the market. The vast majority of farmers want to continue using glyphosate because it is the only product that effectively meets their needs. The precautionary principle could of course oblige us to ban it, but that would not solve everything. Because that is the root of the problem: what to replace it with? Today there are no substitutes. The debate is no longer the dangerousness of glyphosate. The real question is what alternative solution is the Commission working on. Can it be transparent about the funds allocated to research and development of substitute products? Finally, I think we have to listen to farmers in these consultations, because they are the main users of glyphosate, often because they have no other choice. Their voices must be heard and taken into account in the glyphosate debate as well as in the search for a viable alternative solution.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, decisions involve choice and choice involves consequences, but the issue that I believe we are facing this afternoon is one of public confidence in the decisions that the European Union takes. Two of the issues that I have with what the Commissioner opened with is how can he stand there and make the points he did when the European Union expert body, the European Union Chemicals Agency, this year said it should not be classified as a carcinogen; the WHO conclusion: ‘potentially’ hazardous to human health – not conclusively hazardous to health. We have lots of products out there that are ‘potentially’ hazardous, but we do not ban those. We have to draw a line somewhere in terms of being reasonable. Some of my colleagues have already highlighted – and others will, I am sure – the issues, the consequences, that will come of banning this particular product, and none of them are very positive for our farmers and for our agricultural business. I have read quite widely issues about protecting wildlife. If the decision to ban this is to protect the environment, I am for it – but not based on the flawed information we have heard.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to point out that, after intensive discussion, this Parliament took a position on glyphosate and adopted this position with a large majority. This is in contrast to the Council, where many Member States, including the one I come from, have ducked away. For political reasons there was no position. And I think we should build on that, and the Commission should better than before to listen to what Parliament has said on this matter. Glyphosate is a problematic substance. If, at the beginning of the debate on the Commission proposal, some Commission representatives said: 'You can drink it like water', then that was certainly wrong. You have to be very careful with it. But if it is used carefully and if it only happens in certain areas, then the use of glyphosate is acceptable for a limited time. That was decided by the European Parliament, and it certainly played a role in the fact that there are currently few alternatives. That is why I agree with Ms. Delahaye, who says: We have to do research, we have to bring new alternatives onto the market. But that takes time, and we cannot convert Europe completely to organic farming within a short period of time. Therefore: for a limited time, but that doesn't mean fifteen years, that doesn't mean ten years. Parliament says: a maximum of seven years. And we are in favor of many restrictions - more than the Commission has proposed. For me it is particularly important that the pre-harvest treatment stop. There is still the practice that the crop is killed with glyphosate before harvesting to facilitate the harvesting work. That is certainly not what we can represent with a clear conscience in front of our citizens. Therefore, dear colleagues, let us take this position, which we have adopted by a large majority, continue to represent.And, Commissioner, do not wait for the Council;it won't help you with this question.Orientate yourself to Parliament!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: For the sake of clarity, transparency and understanding, I need to say that, due to time constraints, I will not be taking any blue—card questions.

name: Pavel POC
text: - Just to deal with all the tricks that the Commission has shown here, I would need 5 minutes. The Commission received 20, was entitled to 3. Just by chance, the parliamentary resolution required authorization for a maximum of 7 years, not 7 years, with a set of restrictions that would actually ensure maximum security, and the Commission did not respect it at all. This is a little different from what the Commissioner has said here. I filed the objection myself, so I remember it very well. I filed it against the Commission's proposal to authorize glyphosate for 15 years. One thing the Commission simply cannot deny is that the Monsanto papers scandal has simply called into question the credibility of research funded by an industry that has a financial interest in that research, is interested in its results, and thus clearly called into question our own European authorization system. studies addicted as well. After all, we know why there is such a contradiction between EFSA and IARC, and the tabloid dishonesty of IARC that we have heard from the Commission here, which sounds like a quote from the glyphosate manufacturer's website, will not change that at all. We know that. IARC and agencies use different statistical procedures, but mainly use different data sets. The IARC uses publicly available academic research, and unfortunately our agencies use industry-funded work. That's the difference, that's why the result is different. So in no way can anyone claim with a clear conscience that glyphosate is safe, nor can they even claim that all the proper procedures have been followed in approving it. I must say quite clearly that, after today's speech by the Commission, I firmly believe that we must unconditionally set up a parliamentary committee of inquiry, not only because of glyphosate, but also because of the whole process of authorizing pesticides.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that we are asking farmers to meet the challenge of climate change and to provide a growing world population with a reliable food supply. Only productive, competitive agriculture can do that, and the key is safe technology. So the message is absolutely clear: public health is not negotiable, but farmers need every tool in the box. This debate about glyphosate is going to be the first of many future technologies, and those debates have got to bring clarity, otherwise scientists are not going to invest in technology. It has got to bring consistency, otherwise farmers cannot plan their future. And it has got to bring confidence that the food we eat is safe. Any debate in the future about technology like glyphosate has to be balanced and has to be proportionate, and that means, Commissioner, the debate has to be about proven science – not about emotion.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: - Dear colleagues, when authorizing plant protection products, the European Food Safety Authority as well as the national authorities ensure that all evidence is considered and everyone heard. These institutes have been established to make an independent and informed judgment about the risks of these types of resources. Very important, because I believe that science should be leading in this and not our political views. A recently released exchange of letters calls into question the credibility of a number of Monsanto-funded studies. These studies have been used to evaluate the safety of glyphosate. Like my colleagues, I would very much like to know how reliable these studies are and what the consequences are for the risk assessment of glyphosate. We must always monitor the decision-making process critically and improve it where necessary. But that does not mean that we have to give in to our confidence in science. Because the alternative, a political yes-no, undermines the facts and leads to unrest.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: - As early as 2015, the World Health Organization concluded that glyphosate is likely to be carcinogenic. Meanwhile, two European authorities, EFSA and ECA, have gone to great lengths to demonstrate that this is not the case. The studies on which one relies partly come from Monsanto, the producer of glyphosate. The other's research results were even co-written by Monsanto. We can, of course, wonder how Monsanto was able to manipulate research into its own products for years. But more importantly, why is the plan to extend glyphosate's authorization by ten years still on the table. If you no longer rely on manipulated and unpublished research, then you have no reason whatsoever to continue to expose the environment, humans and animals to glyphosate. Glyphosate has become the symbol of what is wrong in Europe: multinationals over the environment and money over health. And you, Commissioner, still have six months to use your common sense. I also believe that the European agricultural sector must be phased out.

name: José BOVÉ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I am worried. For months, Monsanto has been leading actions of denigration against the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a United Nations agency. This firm threatens independent researchers to force them to shut up. This campaign recalls the scandalous, even criminal, practices of Philip Morris in recent decades to explain that tobacco was harmless. This is the same cabinet that defended the tobacco industry that now defends Monsanto. Since then, these manufacturers have been banned from attending the World Health Organization (WHO), as has the International Institute of Life Sciences (ILSI), which today is the armed wing of the defense of glyphosate. Scientists at IARC put glyphosate under the category of “probable carcinogens”. However, the Commission is relying on IARC to ban a number of chemicals. Why doesn't she do it for glyphosate? Commissioner, I ask you to put in place a moratorium until the full light is cleared and possibly take action against Monsanto if it is found that the company has cheated.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we believe that transparency and access to information are non-negotiable rights. We therefore find it shocking that the dangerousness of a product such as glyphosate should be assessed on the basis of scientific studies produced by the same industry that produces glyphosate, among other things by choosing the data that are most congenial to the industry itself. We find it shocking that any legitimate request for access to records is systematically denied because these data are classified as "confidential". We believe that the entire regulatory system must be changed and rethought because it will never be possible to have independent studies as long as the industry itself finances these studies. We are not just talking about herbicides, but also about animal feed, meat, milk, milk products. In short, we are talking about public health, so it seems to me to be the very least to demand that scientific assessments are truly accessible, transparent and in any case independent.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the renewal of the authorization of glyphosate for another ten years reveals the limits of European regulations, which are struggling to find a substitute for this herbicide. The "Monsanto Papers" have completed warning us about the reliability of private research and prove to us the influence of very large groups on political decision-makers. This balance of power places private interests above the general interest. The Bayer-Monsanto merger, planned for the end of the year, is an additional threat to see a private and global group weigh more in the political decision and impose its vision of agriculture on farmers, as on European countries. . In this regard, can the Commission tell us its position on the Bayer-Monsanto merger? The second problem is that of research, carried out in particular in European universities and other public structures, with a view to finding a sufficient substitute for glyphosate. Through the European Union's research programs, does the Commission intend to initiate an impact study on other molecules and technologies available? The raison d'être of the European institutions lies in such initiatives.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Commissioner, I find it unacceptable that the Commission accepts, as evidence capable of renewing the marketing authorization of glyphosate, studies funded by Monsanto, the company which produces the herbicide in question, while it is impossible to cross-check the data and continues to do so. refuse to publish the studies, arguing that it is its investment. Monsanto focuses mainly on trade secrets and intellectual property, but the core of its message is always the same. The data of the study are the property of her and are not violated. The dangers of glyphosate, both for human health and the environment, must be objectively identified. Research should be carried out by independent laboratories long before the license renewal process and scientific data is made available to the scientific community. It is the task of the European Union institutions to assess the contribution that information makes to the protection of the public interest. Thus, European citizens may receive a clear message that European institutions do not serve the interests of large multinationals and are not indifferent to the protection of their health and the environment.

name: Norbert LINS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The same topic, a similar debate - do we really have new knowledge? ECHA has confirmed that glyphosate is not carcinogenic - nothing new to me. I trust the work of EFSA and ECHA here. It is therefore right for the Commission to propose a legislative act that has now been amended. In my opinion, the Commission should take another close look at the resolution of the European Parliament from 2016. It was passed by a clear majority here in the house. We have spoken out in favor of the approval of glyphosate for a further seven years - but with significant restrictions on use. From my point of view, this alone allows more biodiversity, especially if we were to restrict the pre-harvest treatment and no longer use it in kindergartens or in public places. From my point of view, farmers still need glyphosate, the active ingredient and the corresponding mixtures, because there really are no alternatives. In my opinion, politicians would be well advised to focus less on emotions and more on scientific findings. But I also believe that it is right to intensify research here in order to ultimately have alternatives. I would like the Member States not to put on the same theater again in the Council as they did last year. Incidentally, I would also like my home country to finally take a clear position here in this discussion.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: - Mr President! How many people are not living with the reign of terror on our continent? Our task must be to ensure that fewer people are affected. It is therefore irresponsible for the Commission to want to allow the sale of a substance that the World Health Organization's International Agency for Research on Cancer has classified as potentially carcinogenic. According to EU law, the precautionary principle must apply, and it should be clear here that it must be applicable. It's about human health. Glyphosate is widely used in today's agriculture worldwide. The uncertainty that prevails over how it affects people is deeply serious. I also think that the Commission is weak when it comes to its responsibility for human health in other areas, such as endocrine disruptors. Nor does it show that people take seriously the risk of developing cancer. There are now - and several colleagues have raised this in the Chamber - recurring problems regarding how EFSA acts and what reliability they have in terms of how they treat the industry.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman! After many years of clinical and teaching experience in a world where absolute truth is not recognized, sponsored research is a big problem. Nevertheless, observations and some experience have long proven that, contrary to Monsanto's opinion, glyphosate is poorly biodegradable, and its degradation products can be found in the blood of pregnant mothers and in the blood of newborns. Vaccines containing glyphosate are injected shortly after birth. The largest amounts, according to the literature, in the long controversial vaccine against measles, mumps and rubella. In addition to the carcinogenic effect suspected even by the UN bodies, the effect of this herbicide - present for years in soil and in water - on the formation of congenital defects, liver and kidney damage, fertility disorders, allergies, and hormonal disorders has been proven - which is sufficient evidence for this to collect credible research with the overarching goal of protecting human health and life.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Mr President, if the European Commission finally extends the license to use glyphosate for another decade, do you know what will happen? That citizens will have very little doubt that the European Union is dominated by the lobbies of the chemical and agro-industrial industry and that people's health matters very little. The European Food Safety Authority has relied on studies sponsored by Monsanto to conclude that there is no evidence to consider this substance as a carcinogen. Do you want evidence beyond the World Health Organization studies? Ask the residents of neighborhoods like Ituzaingó, in the Argentine city of Córdoba, surrounded by fields cultivated with transgenic soybeans and fumigated with glyphosate. We have already said it many times: you cannot play with the health of our people! If the European Commission again ignores the precautionary principle, the complicity of some institutions that are not at the service of the citizenry, but that of multinationals will be evident. Show that the European Union is not at the service of agribusiness, which destroys the environment, endangers our health and perpetuates social inequalities! Stop the air we breathe in the European Union from being impregnated with a carcinogenic pesticide! Ban glyphosate!

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: - Mister President! Commissioner, I actually thought that the precautionary principle still applies to us. There are still unresolved doubts about glyphosate and you are consistently ignoring it. They also ignore that the studies did not include certain studies in the testing process at all, only studies that the industry produced. We really have to think seriously about whether our test procedure still meets the new standards. And you have absolutely no doubts. If you have read the Monsanto papers from the USA, then you too should have doubts as to whether the process was not manipulated a little by Monsanto, to put it cautiously. And the consequence of this is no restriction at all for glyphosate, not even in pre-harvest use. You are completely ignoring the dangers to biodiversity and you are now saying: business as usual, it can go on. It can't be like that! They also ignore the fact that nearly a million people are collecting signatures to have another debate here in the European Parliament. You are completely ignoring that, too, and that is not a good democratic measure.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to ask you a direct question: you personally do not think that it is more correct to use only and exclusively published and peer-reviewed studies for scientific evaluations, in order to be able to make a scientific evaluation by part of the European institutions and therefore authorize on the market a potentially dangerous product such as glyphosate? I believe that this is the path that European citizens are asking of us and obviously it is the only path that we can take for the future, to restore credibility to what is the European institution we represent. Also, I would like to ask you if you give a reassurance. I would like to ask you, when glyphosate should be banned, I would not want other more toxic and more dangerous substances, such as those for which some new GMOs that we are authorizing at Community level are resistant to and which are resistant to 2 , 4-D, the Agent Orange component used in Vietnam, are the future of agriculture.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his very detailed opening to this debate. I think we owe it to you, Commissioner, to read the detail and study it because there was quite a lot of information in this. I think it is also important to point out, because there seems to be some confusion about what glyphosate is, that it is a weed killer, not a pesticide and I think that is an important point. Secondly, to those who say we can do without it – hands up those in this Chamber who will go out and weed the fields. Because there are very few of you who will do it. I used to do it as a child, and that is long, long time ago. I think we need to be mindful of the possibilities or the options for farmers who need it. I am looking in the gallery here and when I go into a garden centre anywhere in Europe, I see wall-to-wall glyphosate products because gardeners across Europe use this product. This is a debate that is worth having. Monsanto, I think, is on trial here and I am happy for Monsanto to be on trial, as is GM technology, but I do think we need to be careful about the other issues and Agencies that are on trial here: the Food Safety Agency and the Chemicals Agency. We do have to have trust in these Agencies. I would be deeply troubled if this Chamber became the authorisation place for any product, but I do believe that this Chamber should be where we debate these issues. And that is why I welcome the debate but I am concerned about some of the comments that have been made. This is an important part of the technology, as has been said, that farmers use. If I believed that there was a problem, I would call for a ban as well. However, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) is out of step with all of the other Agencies that have looked at this product and we need to acknowledge that. So perhaps Commissioner, when we analyse the information you have given us and follow up, as many of us will, with some questions, there will be greater clarity on this issue. However, I think many of us come to this debate with closed minds; mine is slightly open, to science.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
