text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to be honest, Commissioner, you have not convinced me.You evade an essential point.Not bad environmentalists and dangerous extremists, but the acts of a court highlight opaque fraudulent attitudes and undue pressure with emails and transcripts.Because if everything is in order, the cards are rigged.I have faith in science but I have no faith in those who manipulate scientific research for partisan purposes.This is why we need to clarify.That is why an investigative commission is needed and that is why, in the absence of this clarity, an extension for ten years would be a slap in the face of the precautionary principle.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Last year I voted against renewing the glyphosate license. After all, there was no scientific consensus about the key question whether glyphosate is carcinogenic. At the time, I argued for more transparency, clarity, independent research and that position remains fully intact today. The news that Monsanto allegedly sent and manipulated research makes the call for transparency even more compelling, if possible. The Commission must now show decisiveness. I strongly believe in “evidence based policy” based on objective science. The question to the Commission how it intends to further guarantee such a policy and how it deals with the call for transparency is therefore essential. At the same time, we would like to contribute with an open mind to any structural changes to the herbicide and pesticide approval system and we advocate a thorough analysis of the professional use of glyphosate. I hope that the Commission, like us, puts the protection of human health and the environment first and comes up with clear answers.

name: Stefan ECK
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! In March 2015, the IARC concluded that glyphosate could be carcinogenic. Only six months later, EFSA came to the conclusion that glyphosate is unlikely to pose a carcinogenic risk to humans. So there are two different assessments of health risks. That led to uncertainty and justified distrust among the population. In addition, the individual investigations by EFSA and the background that led to this study are not completely available to the public and to us. The suspicion has rightly arisen that Monsanto might have a hand in it. Commissioner, the only way to regain confidence is complete transparency. When it comes to human health, we mustn't bow down to industry or to farmers. I appeal to your conscience to apply the precautionary principle.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - The history of the so-called Monsanto documents has raised scandalous questions in public.Is it possible that European Union executive agencies, such as the European Food Safety Authority and the European Chemicals Agency, are complying not only with European Union law but also with Monsanto's instructions?I do not want to believe that, but I have to admit that such accusations are greatly reinforced by their uncompromising position taken by these two agencies, claiming that glyphosates are not harmful to human health and are rapidly decomposing.I want to believe that this glyphosate scandal will be the threshold from which the Commission will start to assess substances that are potentially harmful to health more responsibly.This must be done by independent scientists, not by officials, and the results of research must be clear, accessible to the public and verifiable by the scientific community.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, for 40 years, we have been using this material in Britain very successfully. The British authorities were quite happy to pass it for safety under the risk-based assessment. The EU likes to use the hazard-based assessment – but of course anything can be a hazard, such as the salt and pepper we put on our food; it is the degree that counts. The Canadian authorities have crawled all over glyphosate and they cannot find anything wrong with it. And, of course, over these 40 years we have had canaries in the mine – these are the sprayer operators who handle the concentrated material. There would be queues in doctors’ surgeries if there was a problem, but there are not queues in doctors’ surgeries. The Health and Safety Executive in Britain, which looks at accidents on farms, sees far more problems with falling from heights, getting tangled in machinery, drowning in slurry or drowning in grain – exposure to pesticides is way down their list. The World Health Organization says this material is no more carcinogenic than sitting in front of a log fire, cutting human hair, working night shifts, being exposed to dry cleaning fluid or drinking the Argentinian drink ‘mate’. The WHO says that this material is far less carcinogenic than drinking coffee, drinking alcohol or eating processed meat. We are being very silly here.  The burden of proof is obviously on the manufacturers, and they have always got in mind the thalidomide scandal. It now costs EUR 200 million and nine years to get a material through this process – only a large company can afford to do it. The green lobby are determined to kill agriculture.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Our health largely depends on the quality of the food we eat and the state of the environment, so I think it is very important that any additives and chemicals that we use for food production, plant protection or agriculture do not raise any doubts. . Today we are talking about glyphosate - the herbicide that is most used in the world and looking today at the increasing incidence of cancer, at the declining amount of natural pollinators, by looking at various research results, and looking at the Monsanto affair, it's natural, that many questions and doubts arise. Last year, I asked the European Commission a question about the negative effects of glyphosate on human and animal health, which reportedly could be the cause of birth defects, cancer and serious diseases. The Commission replied that glyphosate was unlikely to pose a carcinogenic risk to humans. This answer contradicts the results or the WHO opinion that glyphosate may cause cancer, so I have a question for the Commission - why, why these discrepancies, based on what research, what opinion did you give this answer? I think that these credible answers are waiting for consumers, farmers, especially in view of the fact that glyphosate use is to be prolonged in the European Union and we, consumers, are to be 100% sure that it is a safe product and that the tests are credible the order was not paid by the company that is most interested, because it is the producer of Roundup or other products that contain glyphosate.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Mister President! Commissioner, in the past we have always come to know you as a very level-headed and responsible person who, in his decisions, has repeatedly relied on the fact that the decision must be knowledge-based, that the decisions must withstand empirical research. And it is precisely for this reason that I urge you today to continue to act in this direction. Because what we have before us, which led to the decision that you now want to extend this by ten years - we cannot rely on this decision because we do not know how these studies came about. We have already had studies in advance that on the one hand claimed: Yes, there is a risk here. Others did not see the risk. If there is now serious doubt that these Monsanto studies are really correct, transparent and honest, and there are great doubts as to whether I can rely on them, then you must not use these studies to make a decision. May I ask you again to think about it. I think Parliament's position of a maximum of seven years was already extremely far-reaching under these conditions.

name: Claude TURMES
text: - Mister President!We have known since March that Monsanto is lying, hiding and worse: using the worst secret service methods to pursue scientists from a UN agency and in the USA with Trump is now trying to cut the funds of these UN organizations - only because this organization has independent scientists.And what has the Commission been doing since the Monsanto Leaks?Continue as before.10 more years of this product.Why are we as Greens interested in this dossier?This is about Europe's credibility.That is why we wrote letters back in March, that is why we are going to the European Court of Justice to clarify which studies will be made available.I can only warn the Commission from Mr Juncker: this is not just about health, this is not just about agriculture - this is about trust in Europe.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I have listened to this debate. I heard Miriam Dalli outline the case against glyphosate and I listened to the Commissioner very carefully when he answered. I think that on balance the Commissioner is correct. Because if one reputable agency said glyphosate was safe, then you would be inclined to say: this is an independent agency saying it is safe, so you should go along with it. But when two agencies say it is safe, then I think to actually go against them, and especially to ask for a ban, does not make much sense to me. I have spoken to many farmers, horticulturists, etc. about this, and they are deeply concerned. Before you talk about any ban, you should have an impact assessment on what the effects are going to be. Are we going to allow the weeds to destroy the village farmers’ crops? The same for the horticulturists, the same for our gardens when glyphosate has been used for many decades and, to all intents and purposes, seems to be safe. We have, of course, to take public concerns into consideration. We have to allay people’s fears. But we can do so in a practical and logical manner. As the Commissioner pointed out, it is not just European agencies, agencies around the world have said similarly. So I think that this is an overreaction. We certainly have to be careful, we certainly have to be prudent and we have to allay, as I said, people’s fears. But in relation to Monsanto, they do not own the rights any more. They produce it, there is a company in Ireland that produces it and sells it, and they have been doing it for many years. Are we going to suddenly say: ‘sorry folks, fold up the tent, your business is gone’? That is not the way to go ahead.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Sir. Chairman! Yes, then we are here again with the glyphosate case, the case that will not die! The Commission says there is nothing to catch up on. Science has spoken, and everything is safe. But still you also say that it is important that the Member States make a great effort to limit the use of glyphosate in parks and private gardens, etc. You would not do that if you did not think there were concerns and problems about this fabric. What I think we need is a clear plan from the Commission. We need you to make a plan for how we phase out glyphosate. We need you to make a plan for how we ensure transparency and credibility with the authorities that must assess substances that we use in the EU. And then we also need a clear plan and funding for how we can find alternative herbicides so we can get rid of glyphosate and round-up. There is no need for us to use it. We'll have to find some new ones. It is dangerous to continue with that course. Come up with that plan now!

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: - Mr President, glyphosate is, according to the World Health Organization, a possibly carcinogenic substance, that is to say, harmful to our health. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority has been refusing to make public the studies supporting glyphosate for a year. Of course, we in the Verts / ALE Group have not stood still and have brought these serious events before the European Court of Justice. We want the data to be transparent and for experts to be able to work with scientific rigor. And, also, to know the role of Monsanto in this process. Meanwhile, almost a million people are already calling for a glyphosate ban, through a European citizens' initiative. We ask the European Commission for common sense, a moratorium on glyphosate and an independent and transparent investigation. This is essential for a quality democratic debate with which to rethink our agricultural system and protect our health.

name: Emil RADEV
text: - The issue of the use of the world's most widely used herbicide glyphosate remains relevant, and the existing approval for its use will expire on 31 December 2017 at the moment. Glyphosate is currently used intensively not only in agriculture but also for the maintenance of parks and public spaces. This means that a wide range of people are exposed to it - from agricultural workers who come into direct contact with the product to the end user of agricultural products. We all know that the product glyphosate is highly controversial, as it is suspected to cause cancer, severe damage to the fetus in the womb, serious diseases of the gastrointestinal tract and a number of other negative effects on human and animal health. Clear and definite conclusions about its toxicity or safety are still lacking. On the other hand, glyphosate-containing products are widely used in a number of countries, not only in Europe but also worldwide. In practice, this means that even if its use in the territory of the European Union is limited, its influence on European citizens will not cease. In this context, it is extremely important for all of us that the Commission and the Member States have reliable data on the real impact of glyphosate on human and animal health. These data must be based on independent, in-depth and transparent research and studies.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, like you, we must trust science. Politics must rely on science to decide, but decades ago scientists said that asbestos was completely harmless and today asbestos still numbers in the hundreds of thousands. deaths per year on the planet. Scientists have said aspartame is harmless and still say it today, but aspartame is probably the next food bomb that's going to explode. Scientists have said that glyphosate is harmless, but the Monsanto Papers since last March have shown us that some scientists altered their results and rigged their investigation to allow glyphosate to be marketed. Therefore, it is permissible to doubt the scientific opinions that are given. We must therefore be fully transparent about the independence and reliability of the investigations on which our agencies rely to deliver their opinions. Commissioner, that is why we need a commission of inquiry, to establish all the truth and all the reliability in order to have confidence in our system. It is in the interests of the 500 million European citizens and their health, and even the 7 billion citizens who inhabit the planet.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues!We exchanged many arguments.I cannot support all of them, but I can follow many.Thank you, Commissioner, above all for your very detailed answer at the beginning of this discussion here in Parliament.However, I believe that we have to face one reproach very harshly, and this reproach concerns our European agencies, namely ECHA and EFSA.It says that selfish studies by Monsanto have been consulted here.This accusation must be dispelled, also and above all in the interests of our own European agencies.That's why we have to discuss here, and that's why we have to argue with one another here and see that we can do this much better in the future.This also includes - Frédérique Ries mentioned it earlier - good equipment for the agencies that we have in Europe.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I know your integrity, I know your expertise, I know your will, because we work together, to protect the health of Europeans. In this matter, there is urgency. It is urgent that you take a protective initiative in the months to come, before next autumn, first of all to counter the growing concern of Europeans in the face of recent revelations concerning this endocrine disruptor detrimental to their good health and their life expectancy. There is also urgency on the concerns that are developing due to the lack of transparency. The opinion of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) was allegedly based on studies sponsored by the agrochemical industry. The identity of the 73 national experts who participated in this assessment remains unknown. I therefore hope that before the Member States make their decision, in the autumn, the new French Minister, Nicolas Hulot, will be in line with what he said on April 20, within the framework of the Nicolas Hulot Foundation. : yes, we must take our responsibilities and protect the health of Europeans, by banning this renewal of glyphosate, given the growing concern that it arouses.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I myself agree that we need to keep the health of EU citizens in mind as much as possible. That is why I am glad that we have put this controversial issue on the agenda here in Parliament as well. I suggest that we approach the issue with common sense. An alleged scandal in America must not undermine confidence in the European Food Safety Authority and the European Chemicals Agency. As long as the patent protection of the product was alive, the strange way was not the issue on the table for decades. Nevertheless, I believe that the precautionary principle must be borne in mind in all cases. I confess that all poisons are poisons, however, controlled use can reduce their harmful effects. We cannot allow the excessive use of these agents, as the agents applied to 100 tonnes accumulate in nature. But a total ban is not the answer either. In the absence of an alternative solution, I therefore believe that, in addition to research and development, we must also pay attention to expanding the knowledge of farmers. I also call on the Commission to develop safeguards and ensure that authorization procedures are 100% reliable.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, you are a doctor and therefore you will understand what I am going to tell you. Glyphosate is the most widely used herbicide in the world, with 76% of its use worldwide being in agriculture, in forestry, urban and garden applications. Glyphosate and its residues were detected in water, soil, food and the human body. The WHO has classified this herbicide as a probable carcinogen for humans and a proven carcinogen for laboratory animals. Glyphosate also has a negative effect on the oceans, where everything depends on the phytoplankton at the top of the food chain. The Stop Glyphosate initiative aims to pressure the Commission towards two objectives: to guarantee the transparency and independence of the processes in the reuse of pesticides and to impose mandatory deadlines for the progressive reduction of the use of all pesticides. The process of authorization of glyphosate in the Union has run marshy, with contradictory studies, documents kept secret and conflicts of interest revealed, which is why we need a study based on all available scientific data regarding the carcinogenic character of glyphosate , as well as possible disturbing properties of the endocrine system. Under the precautionary principle, they will continue to pressure the Commission not to renew the authorization of glyphosate, in the light of the overriding public interest in protecting the environment and public health.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time we have debated glyphosate in this House and I have the distinct feeling that it will not be the last. The recent publication of the Monsanto Papers raised reasonable doubts as to the credibility of some Monsanto-sponsored studies, which featured among the documentary evidence used by EFSA and ECA for the purposes of assessing the safety of glyphosate. For weeks, rumors have been filtering about the possibility of an over ten-year renewal of the authorization of this active ingredient, while dozens of campaigns for its ban have already started in all European countries. On this issue, the Commission must first regain credibility in the eyes of European citizens by acquiring in-depth information on the allegations of undue influence by Monsanto, before granting any authorization. When public health is at stake, transparency and the availability of credible scientific studies are of utmost importance and the European Union has a duty to respond adequately to the legitimate concerns of millions of consumers.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Commissioner, I listened to you carefully, you spoke for 19 minutes, it was perhaps the longest speech the Commissioner has ever heard in this Chamber, and I am very often here in the Chamber. Eventually, after your speech, my questions and concerns increased. The same applies to the majority of Members of Parliament, because if, as you claim, glyphosate is supposedly harmless, then why do you take special measures when we have applications in products accessible to children? Why, if there is no problem, will the Member States be able to ban it? The precautionary principle must be strictly enforced, in particular, after the "Monsanto papers" which show that glyphosate is a potentially carcinogenic substance. Monsanto, as you know, will merge with Bayern at the end of the year. So why use this controversial substance, based on controversial evaluation reports, when the same World Health Organization has classified it as carcinogenic?

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, I think the speech by the Commissioner was problematic. Glyphosate, according to the World Health Organization, is obviously carcinogenic. The UN speaks of aggressive and immoral marketing tactics aimed at thwarting reforms and paralyzing restrictions on pesticides. At the altar of easy money, institutional processes are suppressed. Science is redeemed and the facts are hidden. Following the decision of the European Chemicals Agency, I emphasize that the safety of a substance should not be based solely on its harmful properties. Ensuring a high level of protection of human health and the protection of the environment requires access to primary data and not a simple analysis of research results funded by the companies involved. The pesticide industry demands more science and less politics. For our part, we must ensure that politics produces results by ensuring democratic legitimacy, listening to the needs of the market and society. It is necessary to monitor the levels of glyphosate residues in food and beverages and to support the agricultural sector in various ways to develop sustainable solutions.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - I am a fruit grower from Slovenia who has been using glyphosate for 25 years, and if anyone wants to know what the ultimate truth is about glyphosate, it is for me. Because I wouldn’t want to poison anyone with my apples I sell, I wouldn’t even want to poison myself. In my work, I must also take into account the institutions we have established for this. I have reviewed such an EFSA report, I have now also reviewed the report of the Chemicals Agency, which confirms what EFSA has previously claimed. Many world agencies say there is no danger in glyphosate. I also read what the health agency wrote down. The agency’s chemicals office says it’s not carcinogenic glyphosate, while the cancer prevention office says it’s in the category along with red meat and similar things. And I think I believe what the Commission is saying here, and we have a responsibility to talk about ensuring, firstly, that Europeans are healthy, that agricultural production is sustainable, that Europe does not become dependent on those parts of the world, which uses both glyphosate and Monsanto’s GMO products. I myself am also against these products.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: - Mr President, thank you very much, Commissioner, for your extensive explanation: almost twenty minutes. Many of those who have intervened have neither listened to you nor will stay for the end; They came with their preset position, their minute of glory, to speak a political position. And that is what is happening with this. The International Agency for Research on Cancer said that the coformulant that was mixed with glyphosate was the one that could have carcinogenic effects. By removing the co-formulant from the herbicide, glyphosate would not have any carcinogenic problems. You promised that with the scientific analyzes that EFSA would give you, the authorization would be granted or not, also taking into account the opinion of Parliament. I trust the European institutions. I trust you, Commissioner. I trust the agencies that give us food safety. So here we have reached a point where there are political trials. Many circumstances will have to be clarified, also Monsanto. But Monsanto has become "Attila's horse" in a position against herbicides in general. Therefore, there is a great political manipulation.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: – Mr President, I have listened very intently to this debate, and I just want to say that of course we all want a healthy countryside and a good environment for us all to live in; so do our farmers. No one in this House has a monopoly on virtue in this particular matter. Our farmers are responsible farmers. I represent the East of England, which is a major agricultural sector in the United Kingdom. Our responsible farmers rely on good scientific, evidence—based information for what they are doing. From what I have heard from the Commission this afternoon, that is exactly what we have. I hope that the Commission will bring an end to all the uncertainty on this, and confirm once and for all the authorisation for glyphosate. It has been very clear: we are hearing repetitions of the same sort of scaremongering, the same things. Listen again to what the Commissioner had to say, look more closely at what he said to us all. So let us put an end to all this nonsense, and let us give certainty to our farmers – our responsible farmers.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr President, I expect transparency, credibility and trust from the institutions whose work is financed by the taxpayers of the Member States. This also applies to the work of the European Food Safety Authority and the European Chemicals Agency. These agencies should ensure a high quality of life for Union citizens without risk to health from the products they use on a daily basis. The publication of Monsanto's correspondence in court proceedings in the United States that have flooded the media in recent months, in connection with more than 60 health claims and the occurrence of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma associated with the use of the active substance glyphosate in plant protection products, has shaken US credibility. agency for competent health and environmental protection due to doubts about the credibility of certain studies that were used in the risk assessment. Of particular concern is the fact that these studies were also the basis for assessing the safety of glyphosate before the European institutions. I expect a quick answer to the questions asked, and suggestions for improvements in procedures that would make biocide safety assessment procedures more credible.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking all the honourable Members because, ladies and gentlemen, you have put a lot of questions on the table but, as you know, I will not be able to address all those questions and to comment as we do not have enough time. However, may I draw your attention to this WHO report which I have here in my hand, because many of you quote the WHO’s International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC). Here is the IARC report too. I have both reports: from IARC and the WHO joint meeting on pesticide residues.  Two agencies – one and the other – which then decided – because this is the final decision – that glyphosate is unlikely to be carcinogenic. When you speak about the WHO, please read all the documents together, otherwise you will repeat the working group and the very active Professor Portier, who was a chair of the working group. I met him and we discussed this together. I was in Lyons, where we had a lot of discussions. I have visited all the agencies – IARC, EFSA – because I am not responsible to judge on science, colleagues, and I do not think all of you can judge on science.  It must be understood that we have our framework of actions and the framework is law. You mentioned the Monsanto papers but it is enshrined in law that Monsanto is obliged to present a study review, because this is enshrined in law. This law was adopted here in this House together with the Council.  I am responsible for following the law because the rule of law is my basic area in which to act and I would like to say to you, very openly, that we have a very precautionary approach, but do not mix up precautionary approach and precautionary principles. We do the same: we have a precautionary approach and then we use the precautionary principle: we ask EFSA, we ask the ECHA for an analysis. And then nowadays we have all the agencies at EU level. The 28 EU Member State agencies did the same. ECHA did the same, EFSA did the same. That is all, colleagues. Please, then, do not ask me to present another scientific review. I would like to present you with a scientific view that goes into a very detailed explanation but IARC and WHO are not European Union agencies, they are global agencies, but we take those outcomes into account too. Please tell me: how can I act in this situation? My answer is very simple. I would like to follow only plant protection product legislation. Otherwise I will be in a dangerous situation.  OK, I can show you all the materials I have. I have a lot of meetings with my colleagues from the S&D Group. I have a lot of meetings with the Greens. I know very well that you have your own approach. Here is the Monsanto Tribunal paper. Here you can see the urine test. Here you can see seven reasons why we can ban glyphosate.  Colleagues, this is about politics, it is not about science. But I read it very carefully because some write, quite rightly, that it would be good to ban glyphosate because this would give a very good momentum to promoting organic farming. I am not against promoting organic farming but sorry, it is not about science! It is about your political platform! OK, I respect your political platform but I would like to follow the instruments which are in our hands. I know that scientists have a slightly different approach.  Professor Portier has one approach. John Little sent me a letter today and a lot of their working group people are very active discussing this. OK, we will continue those scientific discussions. I welcome those discussions. It would be good to organise scientific debates and move forward, but we must follow our legal obligations, and I would like to say very openly that I am ready to fulfil my legal obligations.  When I started in 2014 I had doubts because I listened to you and I had doubts about our European Union system. Today I would like to say very openly – let me reiterate this – that I firmly believe that the European Union system concerning the approval of active substances to be used in plant protection products is robust, trustworthy and ensures the highest safety standards for human and animal health and the environment. And this is true, colleagues. I spent two and a half years but I would like to say that today I am a big believer in our European Union safety system. Please follow me. I would like to invite you to organise debates and once again address those issues in a more detailed way.  I don’t know who is repeating that I said I can drink glyphosate as a glass of water. Sorry, I never, never, told you such a thing. I would like to mention that glyphosate is, as you know, labelled – this is a hazard classification –as corrosive, causing serious eye damage, hazardous to the environment and toxic to aquatic life, with long-lasting effects. This is on the label. OK, we need to move forward and to see how to manage the situation and how to keep our instruments to guarantee levels – hazard approach, risk approach – and then to fulfil our obligations and of course also finalise our decision. Otherwise it will be very difficult.  Please look, research the consequences of ignoring science and EFSA conclusions in the field of plant health. We now have an entire region infected by Xylella in Puglia. Can you imagine the disaster in Puglia? There is no treatment for this, the only possibility is to remove the trees. Those people who attacked the EFSA proposal to remove those trees did not listen to me – and what is happening today in Puglia? But the scientific advice was clear.  With regard to conclusions about glyphosate, we have today conclusions built by ECHA. Then I have legal obligations, colleagues; six months or until the end of this year. I know that it is only me who will follow the rule of law but I would like to fulfil my obligations.  With regard to the idea to have an inquiry committee, please do it; I will be more than happy to look at your inquiry compared to the Monsanto Papers. Please do it because it will be very good to cooperate with you, and from the Commission side we have no grounds to start with the inquiry procedure but maybe parliamentarians have a bit more space for manoeuvre. Please do it. I will be more than happy to communicate, to coordinate our common knowledge and to present to you the whole picture.  Sorry, friends, but I would like to say that the Commission approach is very clear, based on science, based on precautionary principles. I am a medical doctor, colleagues, and I know how difficult it is to encourage my patients to use medicines in the proper way. You always know how difficult it is to manage medicines but without medicine you have no chance of moving forward.  I know some of you have it in mind to propose glyphosate-free agriculture in the EU. Yes, please do this, please organise a pilot project, encourage farmers to do it; but it is not up to me, it is not up to science. Friends, I am very happy to listen to you very carefully but, sorry, I do not touch all the questions about transparency because I have answers about transparency. I have discussed those issues in a very detailed manner together with EFSA, together with ECHA, together with IARC, together with those working groups and I think we will see possibilities after REFIT. Move forward, but we will do it together. You know, you are also responsible in regard to risk management and risk communication because those messages which are being disseminated today create distrust.  We live in a very difficult society where distrust in science creates a lot of problems. It does not matter what – medicines, vaccinations or plant protection products. Blaming each other is very dangerous. I would be happy to be the scapegoat, the bad guy, but I count on my teams, I count on DG SANTE, I count on our specialists, I count on our scientists around the world – a lot of scientific communities which presented a common picture. And only a few create a lot of problems. Sorry, friends, I would be more than happy to move forward together with you in responding to your questions, but I trust in science.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Commissioner Andriukaitis!Especially your last speech convinced us that you listened to 32 opinions and statements.It was a real debate.I do not know if you have convinced them all, but undoubtedly everyone is satisfied that they participated in a decent exchange of views.I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. - Glyphosate has been widely used for years as an ingredient or as a stand-alone plant protection product and has been discussed for years as it is an extremely controversial substance. Conflicting reports on the harmfulness of glyphosate continue to emerge, and in my opinion, there are serious concerns about its safety. The authorization to use glyphosate in the territory of the European Union expires at the end of the year, which is a great opportunity for the European Commission to ban its use completely. Unfortunately, another attempt has been made to renew the authorization for its use, even though recent studies report further cases of carcinogenic effects of glyphosate, and the German environmental agency documented serious negative effects of glyphosate on biodiversity. Organic farming proves at all times that glyphosate is not essential to its productivity, and that the agriculture of the future should be based on high biodiversity, a wide variety of crops, and working in harmony with, not against nature. That is why I call on the European Commission to closely monitor pesticide research and to closely cooperate in this area with the European Food Safety Authority and the European Chemicals Agency.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - Glyphosate is the most widely used herbicide in the world. It is widely used in both agriculture and horticulture. In European cities, it is widely used in weed control and de facto millions of Europeans are exposed to this herbicide. The European Commission itself defines the substance as corrosive, causing damage to eyesight, toxic to aquatic flora and fauna and with a long-term effect. These are enough reasons in research on the part of private business to set up a substitute to overcome these dangers. I support the establishment of a committee of inquiry in Parliament to raise awareness of an issue that is raising increasing concern among citizens. I believe that Europe has enough scientific and economic potential to stimulate European industry to develop substances that carry less risk than those developed decades ago elsewhere. This will support European production and the Union can prove itself as a leader in applying good practices and working with herbicides with minimal risk to the environment, human health, soil and the environment.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (2017/2703) (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the draft resolution before this House identifies a number of key issues which I would like to endorse. First, the need to address urgently a serious upsurge in violence and human rights abuses; second, the need to implement in full the political agreement of 31 December 2016, and to create the right political atmosphere for credible, transparent and competitive elections; third, the importance of working closely with the African Union and regional organisations; and fourth, the importance of support to the United Nations.  Regarding the United Nations, I share the deep regret of this House at the assassination of the two members of the United Nations group of experts and their Congolese colleagues in Kasai in March this year. I express my sincere condolences to their families, friends and colleagues. But let me repeat once again that the agreement of December 2016 is the only pathway to a democratic and peaceful transition of power. The Catholic Bishops’ Conference provided leadership in facilitating this agreement and they deserve our particular recognition. But for that agreement to succeed, actors on all sides of the political spectrum have to act in the national interest. This is the only way to deliver elections before the end of 2017, and it is the only way to restore full constitutional legitimacy to DRC. Regrettably, it is clear that the inclusivity required for a successful transition has not yet been achieved – this is the reality – in particular as regards the composition of the current government and on the leadership of the National Council for the Monitoring of the Agreement.  The intimidation and arbitrary arrests of opponents and activists, and politically motivated prosecutions, do not contribute to such an environment. I agree with the call made in the resolution for the need to ensure that investigations of violence and killings take place quickly and that they are demonstrably independent and transparent. This is an issue that we will be pursuing bilaterally with DRC, but also at multilateral level, and particularly in the current session of the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva.  Freedom of expression, including for the independent media, and freedom of association and assembly, must be guaranteed by the authorities. Now, unfortunately, we see too many restrictions.  As you know, my own responsibility covers humanitarian affairs. We cannot ignore the human impact of the outbreaks of violence in all three Kasai provinces, and the ongoing threats in other parts of the country where armed groups are active. The violence affecting civilian populations has already resulted in over 3.7 million refugees and internally displaced people, including 1.1 million in the Kasai region. We are in constant contact with the humanitarian actors on the ground, MSF and the Red Cross. ECHO Flight, the EU’s humanitarian air services, stands ready to intervene and provide them both with support when needed. We are also in contact with other donors to coordinate the next steps of the response to the growing needs in Kasai. This comes on top of our presence in the rest of the country, where we mobilise EUR 23 million this year for a wide range of humanitarian activities.  In responding to the political crisis and the violence and human rights abuses that it has generated, on 29 May the EU adopted individual restrictive measures against nine individuals. I want to be very clear about the use and context of these sanctions. They are not intended to replace justice – they are a tool intended to encourage a change in policy or in behaviour. Sanctions are reversible – we would be open to lifting them if those concerned were to demonstrate that they had turned away from violence. And sanctions are adaptable: the European Union would consider further listings for those – at any level, including the political level – who would obstruct the way to a peaceful and consensual end of the crisis.  I would like to end on a positive note. We believe there is potential for an African-led solution, in line with UN Security Council Resolution 2348. We are encouraged by the interest shown by the African Union, and by regional organisations such as the Southern African Development Community. We will support them as we also continue to definitely support MONUSCO, insisting on an energetic execution of its mandate. Resolution 2348 must be implemented in full and the DRC authorities should allow MONUSCO to fulfil its entire mandate with the necessary resources. This includes the protection of civilians in the areas most affected by violence. We must also not forget the risks presented to DRC’s neighbours and the need for contingency planning.  We will also maintain support to DRC and its people through projects and programmes. And we are, of course, if requested, ready to support the preparation of elections if progress is achieved, such as the successful completion of the voter roll, and a realistic calendar and budget.  Once again, please remain assured that despite the difficult situation, the European Union is ready and willing to take part in political and policy dialogue to the benefit of the rights and aspirations of all Congolese citizens.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner very much for his statement, and I can say for my Group that we share his viewpoints and demands. The situation in the DRC is indeed terrible and it has been this way for quite a while, and I am deeply concerned about the handling of the current issue with regard to the Kasai province. You have rightly said that we have got 3.7 million internally displaced people, including the ones in the province of Kasai. Just three weeks ago, I had the privilege to speak as chair of the Delegation for Relations with the Pan—African Parliament (DPAP) in the Pan—African Parliament in Midrand, and I referred specifically to the situation in Kasai. After me, there were two other speakers from the DRC, and not a single one had the feeling that they would have to address this burning issue. That shows, in my mind, the attitude of those who are in charge there. As we speak, we’ve had a minister from the DRC, Liyota Ndjoli, who was contacting different MEPs here today, and I’m sure we have all given him the same message: fulfil the agreement of 31 December; prepare the elections properly. There is no way out, and if he says ‘well, perhaps a month or two later’, I will not accept; I think we should not accept anything unless there’s really a broad consensus with all political stakeholders. When it’s about one month more at the end I wouldn’t bother, but I have the feeling rather that Mr Kabila does not, in real terms, have a true intention to leave his office and his position, where he still sits, so we must keep up our pressure and also apply the sanctions that have been referred to and make it very clear that there is no alternative to fulfilling what has been agreed.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. president. Well, once again, we are speaking of the Democratic Republic of the Congo in this Chamber to speak again of the political crisis, the humanitarian crisis and the security crisis in the region. The figures have already been given by my colleagues, and also by the commissioner. The point is, all this has a name, it already has a name. It's Kabila. We can no longer ignore that there is a situation that is getting worse every day and that has a lot to do with Kabila's null intention to leave power. So we have to do something, in addition to our demonstrations and having tried a political agreement in December 2016, which is not working, although I agree with the commissioner that it is the only space we have to negotiate. Maybe keep the sanctions; perhaps increase them. Give a response to a blockade that is causing a lot of suffering in a country that has already suffered hell for a long time in many of its regions and is waiting for a response from the European Union. Higher penalties can probably have bigger effects.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, when discussing the Democratic Republic of the Congo in this Chamber six months ago, there was some hope that the deal brokered by the Catholic Bishops’ Conference would pave the way for elections by the end of this year, ending the political stalemate, and President Kabila’s 16 year—long rule. Today, no progress has been made in implementing the terms of that agreement and the general security situation has actually worsened. This is particularly the case in the Kasai province, where security forces and members of the Kamuina Nsapu militia continue to clash regularly. Reports suggest that in the last five months, 500 people have been killed in the fighting and a further 1.3 million people have fled the area. In North Kivu province, meanwhile, concerns remain about the activities of rebel groups including the March 23rd Movement and the Islamist militia known as Allied Democratic Forces. The latter has been accused by the government of being responsible for an attack on a prison just a couple of days ago – an attack in which 11 people were killed and over 900 prisoners escaped. As similar security threats manifest themselves across the country, the urgency for President Kabila to go and to have fresh elections to be called becomes ever more necessary. Certainly, his justification that the country cannot afford elections is frankly ridiculous.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, thank you Mr Stylianides, what he said is absolutely correct, but we are going to say things by name: Monusco does not work for him. Monusco is a joke; Monusco is a very expensive fraud: 17,000 soldiers who do nothing but be soldier-tourists. Seven kilometers from Goma, women are raped when they leave the refugee camp to fetch water, because the Monusco soldiers, although they have the mandate to neutralize the rebels and the armed forces, are tourists-soldiers - who patrol the main axes and they are cantoned - because their national commanders forbid them to intervene. The mandate exists; what is a joke is that they charge and do not comply. This is the first problem. The second problem is that the sanctions that have been established are for a small number of people who are engaged in trafficking, which is the logistics of war. If we do not act on the fundamental mass, on the maximum leaders of the traffic, we will do absolutely nothing. And secondly, certainly, the Government of the Congo is a government that is based on corruption, on the violation of human rights. The agreement reached by the group of bishops on December 31, 2016 is fundamental. But what is fundamental is that the Kabila government does not play again with an element that consists, through parliamentary tricks, in delaying the elections - which they already say will be held in the first quarter of 2018, when they had to be held before of December 31, 2017—. And for that to work, you don't need legality, you need to tighten the nuts on the decisive elements: personal and economic sanctions regarding the assets of these people - who are mainly abroad and in Europe as well - which will affect them decisively. If we do not politically squeeze the corrupt government of Kabila, in 2018 we will continue to have Kabila and, here, another debate for nothing.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, this is our fourth debate on the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) in less than a year. At the end of last year, we had had a wave of hope, but the episcopal conference itself has just thrown in the towel and Joseph Kabila remains clinging to power. His recent statements can only cause concern. "We need a perfect election," he tells us, adding that he made no promises. We remain speechless. Human rights violations continue to worsen, including with the assassination, you told UN experts last March. How can we be surprised at the increase in the number of displaced people and refugees? We all know here that multinational companies present in the Congo are partly responsible for financing the armed groups that operate there. So, beyond the support of the United Nations and essential humanitarian aid, action must be taken, in particular by using the legislation on blood minerals, even reduced to the minimum by the Council. It is a tool the Union must use to move from rhetoric to action.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, in January 2015, demonstrations broke out in several Congolese towns against an attempt to modify the electoral law. Twenty-seven people were killed. Already at the time, the European Union was aware of the serious political crisis in the country, but the Commission and the Council waited almost two years to act and finally impose targeted measures against certain Congolese authorities responsible for the repression. opposition and serious human rights violations. At the same time, the European Union welcomed the National Dialogue, an initiative aimed at helping with the organization of the presidential election, but which instead turned out to be one of President Kabila's many attempts to postpone the elections. For years, the Congolese authorities have violated key provisions of the Cotonou Agreement. Normally, this should have triggered formal Article 86 consultations a long time ago. What are we waiting for? While President Kabila has yet to implement the December accords, the political, humanitarian and human rights situation is increasingly worsening. It is time for the European Union to engage more actively and strongly in the Congo in order to avoid any further escalation and further destabilization across the region.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, since the beginning of our mandate we have dealt with the Democratic Republic of the Congo many times and with problems of various sizes and types. We have political leaders who manipulate the Constitution - as it happened, we can call him a political leader - in order to remain in office. We have vast regions under the control of armed mercenaries, a serious and widespread violation of fundamental rights, international crimes, bloody raw materials. The situation is getting worse visibly. It is true that the European Union does not have binding powers in matters of foreign policy, but it could act consistently in the areas in which it is competent, I am thinking above all of trade policies. Congo's problems are certainly complex and not all attributable to the speculations put in place by multinationals in order to take advantage of huge reserves of precious materials at low cost, but this is certainly one of the determining factors of the country's instability and I am sure that more decisive action by the European Union on the liability of multinationals would allow significant progress for the Congo and beyond. Congo is a rich country, Mr. President, rich as hell, in the real meaning of the term.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, our resolutions rightly underline the human and humanitarian toll of the conflict in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. However, I fear that they are mistaken as to the causes of this situation which has been going on since 1998 and which has already killed between six and eight million people throughout the African Great Lakes region. Indeed, who in Uganda prepared the so-called "rebel" operation? Not Joseph Kabila, not even Laurent-Désiré Kabila, whom we went to look for, but the Western powers. Who is responsible for the execution of Laurent-Désiré Kabila? Not Joseph Kabila, the Western powers. Who maintains the disorder to be able to plunder the resources of the country? Not Joseph Kabila, the Western powers. Who lets Paul Kagamé occupy the east of the country to export the minerals stolen in the DRC to Rwanda? Not Joseph Kabila, the Western powers. Who is proposing to add destabilization behind democratic formalism? Still the Western powers, not Joseph Kabila. Dear colleagues, while a smooth transition has been negotiated through the bishops, some of you are more intransigent than the Congolese opposition, while President Kabila follows the Constitution, by the New Year's Eve agreements still in force. You are more extremist than the Congolese by forgetting the purpose of these agreements, namely the stability and security of all Congolese. On December 31, there will be a transition. I hope it will be in favor of peace.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! As many have mentioned, the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo has deteriorated sharply since last year, when President Kabila pledged to hold democratic elections by the end of 2017. But today, after six months of promising negotiations between the United Nations and the Congolese government, the situation in the country gives rise to much concern. Attempts to extend the presidency by Joseph Kabila have made people's lives uncertain and threatened not only by the army, but also by rebel groups and militias. This, moreover, is often tolerated by the government side. Apart from this crisis - as the Commissioner spoke about - instead of security, we are dealing with a humanitarian tragedy that affects almost 7.5 million inhabitants of this country. The reports and reports from the Congo show us the alarming state the country has found itself in. There are human rights violations, racial and ethnic crimes, the use of children in the activities of military groups, violence against women, etc. Our concern is also caused by attacks on employees of humanitarian aid organizations. I believe that political stability in this region is very important and can also help us in future development aid, not only humanitarian, and not only in this region, but throughout the African continent. That is why our actions and this resolution are very much needed and we should participate in this active effort to stop the political crisis in Congo.

name: Maria ARENA
text: - Mr. President, the humanitarian and security situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is deteriorating sharply. In Kasai, which was once peaceful, violence and repression are raging. Since August 2016, summary executions, the murders of children, the recruitment of child soldiers and sexual violence have hit civilians. This violence, which involves militiamen, soldiers and police, has left more than 400 dead. More than 40 mass graves have been discovered, 400,000 children are at risk of famine, more than a million and a half Congolese have fled the region. This crisis in Kasai is playing out against the backdrop of what should be a political transition provided for by the agreement of 31 December 2016 and which is struggling to see the light of day. Even if the enrollment of voters seems to be accelerating, the adoption of electoral laws and the establishment of the National Council to monitor the agreement are all challenges to which the Congolese authorities must respond by holding free elections, transparent and democratic. In a serious context, the European Parliament calls on the Congolese authorities and the international community to do everything possible to respect all the commitments made in the New Year's Eve agreement, including the setting of a clear timetable and precise for the holding of elections, without modification of the Constitution. In addition, we call for the establishment of an international investigation into the violence in Kasai so that the perpetrators of these crimes can assume their responsibilities. Finally, the European Parliament also supports the targeted sanctions put in place by the Union against those responsible for serious human rights violations. I also remind you that it is up to the government to guarantee the safety of its people and that it is responsible for this. Therefore, we call for the responsibility of the Kabila government to protect its people.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, I share the Commissioner’s assessment of the situation. I would like to stress several issues though. Firstly, the necessity to implement a political agenda based on the Accord of December 2016, the strengthening of the MONUSCO performance, full implementation of the UN Security Council mandate without national caveats, as well as the important implementation of an independent investigation of violations of humanitarian and human rights law. There is one other item as well: the criminal aspects of mining for minerals in Congo, a possible spillover effect and the necessity to strengthen the rules of international trade applied in Congo.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: - Mr President, we bring here the worrying situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The figures have already been given: more than 7 million people, of which 4.4 million are children, need education, medical services, assistance and clean water; Almost 6 million have food problems and there are many people displaced both internally and externally due to the conflict situation. We are, therefore, facing a situation of maximum humanitarian urgency and - as the Commissioner has rightly said - in which human rights are violated on a daily basis. The conflict is daily, there is torture, there are kidnappings, there are rapes, there are rapes and there is extreme violence on the part of all sectors. The disproportionate performance of the armed forces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo itself is of great concern. The country is awaiting elections. It is necessary for the European Union to force dialogue so that as soon as possible a democratically legitimized government can be had in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. We cannot be - and I know we will not be - mere observers of a situation in which human rights are violated on a daily basis and in which we, the European Union, want to be the ones who represent the values ​​of peace and security. We condemn, therefore, all these violations and we are especially concerned about this violence and the disproportionate use of it by the state bodies themselves. The lack of freedom of expression also occurs in Rwanda. We had a Resolution here in which we asked for the release of Victoire Ingabire. Well the same also for the Democratic Republic of the Congo. And we must point out the need for the United Nations mission to be stabilized so that it can really exercise its mandate and humanitarian aid can reach all areas. Ultimately, all crimes must be investigated to the end, those responsible identified and prosecuted. Democratic Republic of the Congo to a true democratic government.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Mr. President, article 52 of the Congolese Constitution states: "All Congolese have the right to peace and security." Yet violence and insecurity are spreading across the country. Articles 23 and 24: "Everyone has the right to freedom of expression and information." Yet any voice that speaks out against the regime in power is violently suppressed. Article 15: "Sexual violence is made a crime against humanity." Yet thousands of women in the DRC have still not found justice. Article 58: "All Congolese have the right to enjoy national wealth." Yet the state does not guarantee any equitable redistribution. Article 47: "The right to health and food security is guaranteed." Yet 400,000 children in Kasai are currently victims of a humanitarian disaster. Finally, article 70: "The mandate of the President of the Republic is renewable only once." And yet, to date, no date for the elections has been decided. The DRC must reclaim its future and become the greatest democratic and prosperous nation it should have been in a long time. The resolution of the European Parliament demands responses to all these systematic violations of constitutional principles.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - In March, the bodies of Zaïda Catalan and Michael Sharp were found in Kasai province. The 2 UN experts were murdered by militiamen or Congolese soldiers. They had just been sent out to find clues to the violence that had just started. In the meantime 20 mass graves have been discovered and sources say 1,500 dead. It could have been completely different for the citizens of Kasai. The possibilities to become a prosperous part of Africa are enormous. Kasai is rich in minerals and fertile agricultural area. Kasaï's deaths are a symptom of the real problem. Congo is a rudderless ship with a grabbing elite, a divided army and an invisible president who clings to his position. The massive escape from Bukavu prison in South Kivu last Sunday is further proof of this. The political system in Congo has failed. It's bankrupt, just like the international community. He is watching. It reacts now and then but is otherwise completely divided and therefore powerless. The people of Kasai have no international condemnations without consequences.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Mr President, this Resolution is the firm voice of this Parliament that joins the cries of pain of so many raped women and girls, children used as soldiers and displaced people fleeing the violence that has affected the Democratic Republic of the Congo for a long time. more than twenty years. Hope for the political agreement signed between Kabila and the opposition has not lasted long. The agreement does not advance; what does advance is the fear of a population fleeing violence, caused by those who should avoid it. We are talking about war crimes, committed by those who take children from their families to use as soldiers. We are also talking about thousands of raped women and girls. Congo is known as the rape capital of the world. Many are the mothers who spend their nights awake to save their daughters from the rapists who will mark them for the rest of their lives. Nobody defends the rights of the victims because the generalized corruption and the difficult access to justice mean that mothers, like that of a raped child, end up being accused of having handed over their daughter to the rapists. I know of much more egregious testimonies, but it would take me an hour and not a minute to quote them. In defense of a dying population, the European Union must continue to press. Those of us who are fortunate enough to live in freedom must fight for those who, as in the Congo, live in slavery to fear. Convictions, Commissioner, are necessary, but action and sanctions are even more so.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the old ghosts have resurfaced in Congo, prey to violent internal tensions which are leading to open conflict. On the one hand, the stalemate in the political situation, on the other the clashes in the province of Kasai, with the discovery of numerous mass graves. In the midst of the civilians, the suffering humanity of a people that has never known a peaceful transition of power and that does not enjoy the great riches of the underground. That opening of dialogue with the New Year's Eve agreement has closed. Six months later that agreement is on a dead end and this has produced violence in Kivu and in the North, in Ituri up to the very rich Katanga, in the South, to arrive at the Kasai drama. Absurd violence and trampled human rights that demand truth. This situation is no longer tolerable. I hope that there is an awareness in the European Union and in the international community that it is necessary today, more quickly than ever, to take action to ensure a political transition. Congo needs this.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Mr President, from a feministic point of view, I would like to stress that the sexual violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo remains extremely serious due to its scale and systematic nature. The victims, in the majority women and children, endure rapes often associated with other atrocicities, such as mutilation, forced participation of family members in rape, gang rape and sexual slavery. Conflict—related sexual violence contributes to an increase in the levels of gender—based violence in general, and this lasts for generations if appropriate action is not taken. Therefore, I support the mandate of the UN to protect the population from armed groups and women from rape and other sexual violence. I call on the Congolese Government to end the impunity of the perpetrators of sexual violence. I ask for an end to the violations of human rights in Congo.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, with Kabila forced to remain in power, supported by the controversial decision of the Constitutional Court, the violence has returned to the Democratic Republic of Congo and we are witnessing a deterioration in living conditions and security in the country. Since 2016, more than one million people have been forced to move from their homes. This number is higher than the number of refugees in Syria. All of this instability created a widespread security crisis. At the same time, the Ebola outbreak has returned to Congo, generalizing the terror and fear of contagion of this deadly disease, which has plagued some African countries in the recent past. The international community and, in particular, the European Union must have a leading and firm role in the defense of the São Silvestre Agreement, signed in December 2016 under the aegis of the bishops, allowing to reach November with conditions for a free electoral process to take place , transparent and without incident. We must be vigilant so that we are not complicit in, by default, yet another humanitarian crisis in Africa.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I welcome the fact that the EU has imposed sanctions against many of those responsible for violence in the DRC, but the rest of the world, as we have heard, is standing by while mass grave after mass grave is being uncovered in Kasai. Just three questions. Firstly, three million people are displaced in the DRC, half a million children are at risk of malnutrition, where is the global outrage? The UN is struggling to raise 60 million in emergency funds. How can we ensure that funding targets are met and humanitarian access is secured? Secondly, accountability. We do need to assist in gathering evidence and building cases to bring those responsible for murdering civilians to justice.  Thirdly, addressing the root causes is crucial, not just in Kasai, but the entire DRC is mired in crisis. President Kabila, as we have heard, is part of the problem and we need serious international pressure to kick—start the electoral process. I urge you to put this on the agenda of the Foreign Affairs Council on the 19th and deliver a strategy to tackle the crisis, together with our international partners. Failing this, destabilisation of the entire Central African region will force its way up the agenda in a matter of mere months.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the dispute over control of the country's immense natural resources and ethnic violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo have generated one of the worst humanitarian crises in our recent history that we cannot silence. The balance is dramatic: more than 5 000 000 dead, 3 700 000 internally displaced persons, overcrowded refugee camps and hundreds of thousands of people victims of hunger, disease and epidemics, including, now, the return of the Ebola scourge. Women and children are, as in most conflicts, the main victims of the terror of everyday life in that country. Rape and murder of women have become commonplace. Half a million children under five suffer from acute malnutrition and thousands of other children sacrifice their childhood, becoming child soldiers. President Joseph Kabila's inaction and silence in the face of these atrocities against his own people and the increase in kidnappings and attacks on aid workers and caravans are unacceptable. The European Union must therefore extend the application of sanctions against those responsible for these serious human rights violations, as the Commissioner said, and for sabotaging the democratic process in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and calling on President Kabila to accelerate the fulfillment of its promise and call presidential elections by the end of this year, ensuring the conditions for this electoral act to be free, transparent and credible.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I am gravely concerned about the growing violence and political instability in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It is a situation that is having a terribly bad influence in all the neighbouring countries, and I call on the EU to to take the necessary measures and action for the de-escalation of tensions in that country. The Congolese authorities must work to address the current security and humanitarian crisis, ensuring political stability and full respect for human rights in the Congolese Constitution. A peaceful, transparent, smooth and timely conducting of the next presidential and legislative elections are vital for the security of the Great Lakes region. We must recall the commitments made by the Democratic Republic of Congo under the Cotonou Agreement to respect democracy, the rule of law and human rights. These things are not happening, unfortunately. I strongly believe that respect for democracy, peace and the peaceful transfer of power must now be a priority for all political forces in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the dramatic situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is raising more and more concerns. This is an issue that we have repeatedly discussed here in the European Parliament, and every time we discuss it, the situation gets worse. Human rights violations, persecution of dissidents, killings, arrests, denial of freedom of speech and freedom of assembly, enormous humanitarian implications. We now have three and a half million refugees, one and a half million in Kasai, and child malnutrition. Many children have now been turned into soldiers, which is, of course, a criminal offense. Beyond that, this situation will continue because Kabila is in power, he is violating the Cotonou Agreement, he does not want to hold elections and that is why this situation is being created, which is getting worse, because the mining companies themselves are now a state. in the state, as the wealth in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is enormous. Decisive interventions are needed, Commissioner.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what remains of the DRC now? I can only say geography, given that there is very little left of republic and democratic now in the DRC. This crisis actually has a precise name and surname, that of Joseph Kabila, and his claim to violate the Constitution by postponing the elections, together with his entourage, by any means, to remain in power and continue to exploit the immense resources of a very rich and at the same time very poor country. The agreement of 31 December 2016 must be implemented, but unfortunately the talks are still stalled, as the country sinks into a hell of violence, denial of fundamental rights and freedoms, child soldiers, mass rape, malnutrition , war crimes and crimes against humanity. We ask that the Cotonou Agreement be finally applied, including its Article 96, which often remains an agreement of words and not of deeds. The Union must play its part as mediator and must play its part with all forms of diplomatic pressure to ensure a true political and peaceful transition to elections that are also credible. The cry of pain of the Congolese people cannot and must not be only a distant echo for us.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, we had a very rich exchange and I am very grateful to the honourable Members for their valuable interventions. It bears testimony to the EU attachment to the resolution of the crisis in the DRC.  The European Union’s link with the DRC is a link between citizens, between families and between communities. We care about the situation in this great country at the heart of Africa, so we want to do whatever we can using the tools at our disposal. First, to accompany the Congolese people through the current crisis; secondly, to support them and build accountable institutions that will stand the test of time; and third, to help them deliver good governance and, of course, a sustainable democracy.  From this debate, I conclude that we all share a common interest in engaging with the DRC authorities in order to carry the transition forward until the elections, provided that there is increased respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. If this is not the case, we will draw the consequences. So we will continue following closely the situation in the DRC in every dimension.  I completely agree with you that one of the most important issues is humanitarian access. I know this issue well because of my responsibility in my mandate, my portfolio, and as I discussed with some of you, I will try hard to find ways to reach vulnerable people in all regions of the DRC. This is why I have humanitarian access as a top priority, because it is the only way to provide humanitarian assistance to all people of the DRC. At the same time, I completely agree with you that we must keep up our pressure in every dimension in order to see as soon as possible democratic elections. It is the only pathway in order to see a better future for the Congolese people. At the same time, I greatly appreciate Parliament’s essential role in keeping the DRC on the international agenda. I can assure you that we will continue to use all tools at our disposal to assist in bringing a durable solution to the current crisis, and I engage to keep you fully informed on developments, in particular on humanitarian access. Thank you very much for this very rich exchange.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner.As you noted, it is not often the case that a closing statement is applauded, and this happened today.Congratulations to the Lord.I have received six motions for a resolution tabled in accordance with Art.123 sec.2 of the Regulations.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday 14 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The political and social situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo is seriously worrying.It suffers from political repression and continuous conflicts, which have reiterated over time.In recent years, numerous cases of human rights violations have been reported, mainly concerning freedom of expression, assembly and demonstration, increased trials for political reasons and the use of force, during peaceful demonstrations.It is absolutely necessary that an independent commission of inquiry be established, which sheds light on the terrible events that have taken place in the past and puts pressure on the Congolese government to respect, promote and protect fundamental freedoms as the foundation of democracy.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – I support the call for the EU to ensure free and fair elections by the end of the year. In accordance with the Congolese Constitution, elections should have taken place in 2016, but President Kabila has made every possible effort to postpone these elections. The Constitution states that a president cannot serve for more than two terms; as such President Kabila is not permitted to serve a third term. I express deep concern over the mass graves discovered in the Grand Kasai region and the resurgence of violence in the northern and eastern parts of the DRC. I firmly condemn all acts of violence and human rights abuses in the country, regardless of the perpetrator, and call for the launch of an independent international investigation.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the humanitarian situation in Yemen (2017/2727 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, you know well that for over two years, the war in Yemen has devastated the country’s infrastructure and undermined its social fabric. Yemen was already one of the least developed nations in the world.
