After years of hostilities, we are now facing a daunting catastrophe where millions of lives are at stake, and this is now unfortunately aggravated by a severe cholera outbreak. As you know, the war in Yemen has caused one of the worst humanitarian crises – perhaps the very worst. According to the UN, one child is dying of hunger in Yemen every 10 minutes – a shocking number. Some 20 million people face the grim prospect of famine. The European Union, and now the Member States, recently pledged EUR 430 million in humanitarian aid, out of a total of over EUR 1 billion pledges at the Geneva pledging Conference in April. I was there; I represented the European Union, and I saw the fatigue of the international community regarding the humanitarian crisis across the world, but again the European Union was the biggest donor in this crisis. I agree totally with the UN Secretary-General that it is now time for urgent action. These pledges must be translated immediately into the concrete action that the people of Yemen need and deserve. Humanitarian access remains an issue for the international community. For this reason, we have reached out to the warring parties to push for facilitated access to the populations in need, while requesting an end to all violations of International Humanitarian Law. But the EU cannot act alone; there must be a truly concerted international effort, and we will continue to actively promote it. We have always maintained, and we continue to believe, that there can be no military solution to this crisis. It is an illusion. As clearly stated in the EU Foreign Affairs Council Conclusions on Yemen of April 2017, we aim to continue to work with all parties towards a sustained cessation of hostilities. This is the first step. This should be monitored by the United Nations, and would serve as a first step towards the resumption of peace talks under the leadership of the UN.  We offer, as the European Union, our full support to the efforts to relaunch the political negotiations. We are ready to do all we can to create the conditions that would enable both sides to de-escalate and move towards a solution. The European Union has been involved in sponsoring a number of Track II and peacebuilding initiatives, and will step up its efforts in this regard. But it is essential that all international and regional actors engage constructively and in a coordinated manner. We have been providing considerable humanitarian assistance. Although there is no peace deal yet, the European Union and other development actors are already preparing the ground for early recovery and reconstruction in areas where access is possible. There are people in need who cannot wait until the war is over, as always. To complete this, we need to reactivate our development cooperation and prepare for the necessary future intervention. If we want peace, we must prepare for it. In this manner, we will be ready to effectively contribute to the re-building of Yemen when the moment comes. We will need to focus on sustainable job creation and improved livelihoods.  The war in Yemen is no longer a domestic or even a regional affair. We believe that the gradual destruction of the country’s infrastructure and social fabric is a major destabilising factor for the international community as a whole. Vast areas are already controlled by terrorist groups such as al—Qaeda and Da’esh. Crucial maritime routes are endangered by the hostilities, and there is a real danger that piracy will re-emerge. The nature of the conflict is being exploited to fan the flames of sectarianism. These are all threats to international security that the European Union is determined to tackle, together with likeminded partners. You know very well the new development in the region: the new dispute between Qatar and other regional countries. Federica Mogherini, the High Representative, has involved the whole college – this is something very important in order to evaluate the situation in the new current circumstances.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, thousands of dead and wounded, merciless attacks against civilians, a dire humanitarian situation, with cases of malnutrition, famine, cholera, here is in a few words the sad reality of Yemen today . Yemenis are living a terrifying civil war and witnessing the collapse of their institutions. We all know that this power vacuum is fertile ground for the establishment of terrorist organizations. I am thinking here of the rise of Al-Qaida in Yemen, but also of the Shiite terrorist organizations. Beyond Yemen, the stability of the entire region is in jeopardy, as, as we all know, this is a proxy war between Iran and Saudi Arabia, an increasingly confrontation complicated with recent developments in Qatar. What can we do? The Union's humanitarian aid is essential, but the humanitarian situation cannot improve as long as the conflict remains open. The Union and its Member States should exert more diplomatic influence, in particular by facilitating the peace process under the aegis of the United Nations. We must coordinate our efforts with other actors, and the Gulf countries are inevitable in this context. Then, we must focus, on the other hand, on several axes: an end to the fighting, as well as the reestablishment of the functioning of the airport of Sana'a and the port of Hodeidah, because they are essential access points for allow the passage of humanitarian aid.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, around eighteen million people, two thirds of the country, suffer from hunger in Yemen and require urgent humanitarian aid, because the famine is unprecedented. Two and a half million boys and girls suffer from acute malnutrition. Easily preventable diseases are wiping out the population, cholera is raging and the situation is completely desperate for children. Today Yemen is the country in the world with the most lives in danger, yet Yemen is not talked about. The question is why do not the European news open with news about Yemen. That is why the Socialist Group wanted to bring this debate to this House. Because it was about time we talked about Yemen. A country that is struggling between total catastrophe and tragedy, something that is perfectly avoidable, because catastrophe and tragedy in Yemen are made by the hand of the human being. They do not come from nature. The country is caught up in the interests of regional powers that use Yemen as a game board for their own geopolitical game, which is getting more complicated every day. It is a huge failure of international diplomacy and will be a great disgrace in the history books. If we do not react urgently, it will also be our responsibility. We want the European Union to be more active and influential in finding a solution to this tragedy. And we want intra-Yemeni dialogue to be encouraged, also to rebuild trust between the parties. There are few actors in the world with the capacity of the European Union to be able to try to solve the terrible situation that this country is going through, and we must all commit to act.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the suffering of people in Yemen is unbearable. I had hoped never again to see images of children dying of malnutrition and cholera, especially not in 2017. So much of this war and starvation is man-made, yet women and children suffer disproportionately. The violence that has broken out has devastating consequences and will not likely lead to a clear outcome. Instead, everything must be done to find a negotiated solution, not only in the interest of the Yemeni people, but also to avoid a spillover into an already fragile and explosive region and to avoid a breeding ground for more violent extremism. It is high time – and this is a real appeal to the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the Member States – that the EU develops a common position vis-à-vis Yemen, and at least that Member States stop exporting weapons to Saudi Arabia, which, together with the coalition, continues to indiscriminately bomb civilians and block the ports of Hodeidah, which in turn exacerbates the humanitarian situation. Of course, the Iranian side must also stop fighting a proxy war in Yemen. Last year, this House called for an arms embargo to Saudi Arabia because of its role in Yemen. It is a very important signal that we must repeat, and at least the call of last year is still very valid if we look at the incredible and unnecessary suffering of millions and millions of people. I think the EU must do more, develop a shared position and step up its efforts to end this disgusting war and the humanitarian suffering in Yemen.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Yemen is a powder keg and we currently know that there are 18.8 million people - more than 70% of the population - in need of humanitarian aid; 6.8 million suffer from famine and 10 million children, according to UNICEF, need humanitarian aid. There have been two years of civil war with thousands of dead, wounded or maimed, with two million displaced, attacks against the civilian population and humanitarian aid personnel, rapes, use of child soldiers and a long list of crimes that should be investigated accordingly. independently. The only possible solution is dialogue, a dialogue between the parties that must be sponsored by the United Nations. But double standards are not valid here. And when I say this I am referring mainly to the role of the European Union. These days we condemn the situation in Yemen at the same time that we know that countries like the United Kingdom, Spain - my own country - France, Italy or Germany continue to sell arms to Saudi Arabia. Let alone the United States, which is behind - and we all know it - indiscriminate attacks against the civilian population of Yemen. The end of hostilities will not come with unilateral interventions, with the continuation of arms sales, or with the instrumentalization of religious differences to instigate political crises and sectarian wars that feed rather spurious interests, it must be said. It can only be achieved by strengthening diplomacy and multilateralism.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! Since the armed conflict in Yemen escalated in 2015, the humanitarian disaster has worsened dramatically. Seven million people are at acute risk of famine. More than two million children suffer from malnutrition. A cholera epidemic is spreading. In view of this worsening catastrophe, I very much welcome the fact that the European Union decided at the Yemen donors' conference to provide additional aid measures worth 116 million. The hunger in Yemen is caused by the war. Therefore, humanitarian aid is not enough. The EU must act more decisively to end the armed conflict. In concrete terms, this means that there must be no arms deliveries to the conflicting parties, including Saudi Arabia. The European Parliament voted in favor of an arms embargo against Saudi Arabia in February 2016. Nevertheless, numerous EU states continue to deliver weapons to the Gulf state. That has to be over! Those who deliver weapons to warring parties risk complicity in war crimes. The EU must support a political solution led by the UN. You, Commissioner, have listed many such initiatives. In conclusion, I would like to point out massive repression against civil society: ten journalists have been imprisoned by Houthi fighters for two years, and here, too, the EU must work for their immediate release.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, President Trump closing an arms sales agreement with Saudi Arabia for a total of 320 billion euros. A new cholera epidemic that has affected more than 80,000 people, causing 676 deaths, and the prospect of up to 200,000 people being infected in the coming months. The continuous bombing of a coalition of states, led by Saudi Arabia - 320 those verified by the UN -, indiscriminate bombings, often also on civilian targets, with bombs also bought by the war industries of some member states of the Union, including the Italian one, of which Saudi Arabia is the sixth customer worldwide. The latest of these bombings hit a treatment center for cholera patients on Sunday night, killing and injuring an unknown number of people. A child dies every ten minutes, which is also confirmed by the UN. The figures are appalling: 3 million internal refugees, 10,000 dead and 44,000 injured since the start of hostilities. This is the largest humanitarian crisis of this century, with over 9.6 million children in need of humanitarian assistance. This is what happens in Yemen: a proxy war, a massacre in silence. Perhaps because Russia is not involved, perhaps because refugees, unlike other cases that we know well, are all internal, blocked by the geography of the country, nestled between desert and ocean, and therefore concern us less for some. Yemen is a country in pieces, destroyed. What used to be one of the oldest centers of civilization in the whole world, where the Kingdom of Sheba was born and died, is now only rubble. Civilians suffer from this situation and terrorists take advantage of it, who like a virus take power and spread throughout the country. We have allocated 116 million euros, but more than 2 billion would be needed. Doing more, therefore, but above all this it is not enough.We voted on an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia last year in February.This is the only real strong and necessary signal, one of the few tools we have available to show that we are serious, but even here many want business as usual and then we become accomplices.We are asking for a political solution, the only acceptable although extremely difficult, and the children, on the other hand, continue to die, one every ten minutes.And those bombs are also European bombs.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, two years since the conflict began, Yemen is suffering from an extreme humanitarian crisis. Two million people have been displaced, and over half of the country’s population lacks access to safe drinking water or sufficient food supplies. Last month, as has been mentioned, saw the outbreak of a cholera epidemic which has already affected upwards of 100 000 people and claimed the lives of another 800. With humanitarian assistance already struggling to reach those in need, there is continued concern that the Houthi—held port of Hodeidah may be the target of an attack on the Saudi-led coalition. Given that approximately 75% of Yemen’s food supplies enter the country via this port, the devastating consequences of its destruction cannot be underestimated. The campaign continues to be marked by the disproportionate level of civilian casualties and very poor targeting of Saudi ordinance in their air campaign. The growing footprint of al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) in parts of Yemen is also of grave concern, as are reports that suggest that the Saudi coalition has coordinated its attacks against the Houthis alongside AQAP. This is particularly worrying given the new US Administration’s continued hints that it may seek to play a more decisive role in supporting the Saudi-led coalition.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The truth is that there are no words to describe the situation that is being experienced in Yemen. The figures are terrible: thousands of deaths and, especially, the situation of children. Two million displaced children; five hundred thousand children lacking nutrition, used as child soldiers. It is truly a horrible situation, complicated, in addition, with a cholera pandemic. What can we, as the European Parliament, do in this situation? Well, apart from passing resolutions, I think that - as the Commissioner said - we have to encourage action by the European Union, support the efforts of the United Nations Secretary General's special envoy and alleviate the suffering of the parties. But it is important that we also attend to the causes of the conflict and, above all, urge an end to violence, also monitored by the United Nations, and clearly support those efforts in favor of peace. And, Madam President, we should not forget the impunity for the serious human rights violations that are taking place in Yemen. And I would like to recall the importance of a safe, stable and peaceful Yemen for all of us, precisely to combat violence and to combat extremism in the region.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, the conflict in Yemen has devastated the lives of millions of people and turned into a major humanitarian crisis. The country is slipping into famine, and this can only get worse as the conflict continues. And as you rightly mentioned before, now we have the cholera outbreak – another major tragedy; a blow into the eyes of humanity. The most important thing to emphasise here is that the two sides are starving because of the war; this is a manmade disaster, and it is very brutal on civilians. Both parties are turning starvation into a war instrument – just a war weapon. In addition, I have – and we have – the uncomfortable feeling that the international community and public opinion are turning their eyes from that dramatic conflict, attracted by other major global events.  It is a civilian war that is fuelled and supported by regional actors, a bloody image of a Shia-Sunni conflict in the Middle East. Why it is important today to underline this fact? Because this conflict can be ended with goodwill and with the support of other major regional and global actors, including the European Union, and it’s right to mention that Iran and Saudi Arabia – both being more or less our partners – should pay attention and should assume their regional responsibilities, because the responsibility there is bearing on their shoulders. It’s equally important to mention that they can destroy and they can devastate the whole region if the conflict will only continue.  It is dangerous today to take a side and, at the end of the day, the only thing which we should care about is human life. For that reason, I call first for pressure to be put on the two sides to stop the conflict immediately and to allow the humanitarian and medical aid; secondly, for full funding for the humanitarian response to be assured; and finally, the European Union should have a more important role in the political transition of Yemen.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - The European Commissioner has rightly pointed out the fact that in this war chaos in Yemen, al-Qaeda and ISIS are spreading and expanding.And given the geographic location of Yemen and the long arm of these terrorist organizations, European security interests are also directly involved.I actually missed one point with the European Commissioner, namely that Russia is occupying an increasingly important place on the battlefield.Russia smells its opportunity, acts as a peace broker for all parties, even prints the currency, the currency of the nominal Yemeni government.In other words, what is the perspective for a settlement of the conflict if Russia also comes?I am extremely skeptical, and I also draw the attention of the European Union to this role of Russia, there too, because it only leads - look at Syria - to more destabilization.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, the fact that we are only now having this debate is a shameful indictment of the foreign policy values of this place. Not only is a humanitarian crisis a disaster for the people of Yemen, but also the wider region. The inability to act decisively brings instability to the rest of the world. With the Saleh Houthi regime refusing to negotiate with the UN special envoy, we are no nearer a solution to the crisis; thus, we can expect more bombings and suffering. One ray of hope is the rise of the Southern Movement. It is possible that we can encourage peace and stability in the south by working with them towards a federal solution, even – as I’ve been saying for the past three years – if it threatens the integrity of the Yemeni state, which in my opinion is already a busted flush. We must listen to the south Yemenis’ peaceful call for a say in their future. Surely it is better than sitting back and continuing to let Yemen be a battleground for wider Saudi and Iranian interests.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, Yemen, we see, today crystallizes most of the tensions and rivalries in the Middle East. The humanitarian, food and health situation is dramatic there. The new tensions in the region, as well as the embargo imposed on Qatar by some of its neighbors are not helping. These measures weaken the coalition of Gulf countries that had formed around Yemen and they reinforce the country's fragility. You spoke to us a moment ago about the need to be coordinated. How to coordinate aid when those who must intervene are themselves divided? How can there be help when we can see that an embargo, which still weighs on the most vulnerable, also tends to weaken economic resources? There is an urgent need to lower the tension in this region, because it is friends with all countries. Europe has a vital role to play. So, Commissioner, what measures, what initiatives do you plan to take in the coming days to reduce this tension which directly threatens Yemen, the stability of the region, but also the security and stability of our own region?

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! Today we have already talked a lot about the unimaginably dreary humanitarian situation in Yemen. And this cannot be pointed out often enough, because it is scandalous that the international community is still not raising the necessary funds, because it is scandalous that the Saudi-led military coalition is blocking all attempts to reach the needy population with relief supplies and thwarts. And it is scandalous that the Western community of states - above all the USA, but also many member states - is supplying the Saudi regime with arms deliveries. These deals are immoral and short-sighted because they help prolong the catastrophic situation. Unfortunately, the resolution of the European Parliament of February last year to impose an arms embargo for precisely these reasons has so far only been implemented by a few states. It should be clear to all of us that the best humanitarian aid for Yemen is to forego profits from the arms trade.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as mentioned, Yemen is being torn apart by a civil war, in which national interests have been joined by international ones. As always, the heaviest costs of the conflict are paid for by citizens who are simultaneously involved in a conflict and a migration crisis with the outbreak of a cholera epidemic. In the first months of 2017, the humanitarian crisis involved 27 million people. To increase the dose and further aggravate this crisis, cholera which has claimed almost 800 victims. In March I had the opportunity to meet the Yemeni minister for human rights and, as today, even then I had expressed my deep concern for the country that is going through a difficult crisis. Now we have to speak clearly. The only solution I see is a shared and lasting ceasefire. There is no possibility of mitigating, much less resolving the humanitarian crisis or controlling the spread of the epidemic without a solid and lasting ceasefire, which we absolutely need. The European Union must work to achieve this goal.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - The violations of humanitarian law and war crimes that mark civil war in Yemen, one of the poorest countries in the world, are overwhelming. Hunger, malnutrition, along with indiscriminate air strikes, kill blindly, namely children. Destroyed hospitals where nothing arrives are unable to provide basic services. Violence of all kinds, including sexual, prevails on the streets. The consequences are far from limited to Yemen's borders. While, in the north, rebel forces are fighting, the international community is splitting up in the proxy war between Iran and Saudi Arabia, with the complicity of the United States and some Member States of the European Union, namely the United Kingdom and France. Terrorist organizations, such as AQAP and DAESH, rub their hands together happily, conquering territory in the south of the country and intensifying attacks. The solution to the conflict must be political, not military. The international pressure for a solution in which all the parties involved reach an agreement must exist, it cannot be long. It is our security that is also at stake.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in Yemen 14 million people are starving and 3 million Yemenis are internally displaced as a result of the civil war that, since March 2015, has opposed the loyal forces of the government of President Mansur Hadi to the Huthi rebels. In the poorest nation in the world, Arab, this war caused the rate of child malnutrition to rise by 200% and two thirds of the population depend on external assistance to survive. In addition to the terrible humanitarian crisis, the presence of DAESH and Al-Qaeda branches in the south and southwest of the country is reinforced, which, taking advantage of the chaotic situation, foment terrorism throughout the region. The European Union must continue to support the return of negotiations to Yemen and collaborate with the United Nations, either by supporting the Security Council's decision to extend the current sanctions regime on Yemen, or by maintaining its financial commitments for humanitarian aid at a time where the Refugee Agency received only 1% of the amounts requested from international donors to help vulnerable people during this year. As the European Union Ambassador in Yemen, Antonia Calvo, said, we cannot allow Sana to become another Aleppo.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, the situation in Yemen is extremely worrying. Yemen has been plucked by years of instability, war, poor governance, lack of the rule of law, underdevelopment, environmental decline and widespread poverty. Millions of people are in acute need and urgently require, immediately, life-saving assistance in at least one sector. Moreover, there is a number of serious allegations of violations of international humanitarian law and human rights law committed by all sides. The humanitarian situation is likely to deteriorate further in 2017. Without urgent action including full funding for the humanitarian response plan, steps by parties to end the war and to facilitate the resumption of commercial food and other imports and full access to all people in need, the crisis will worsen. It is absolutely essential that the parties to the conflict respect international humanitarian law, allow the importation of food, medical supplies and other necessary goods into Yemen and guarantee unhindered movement of humanitarian actors to reach those in need of assistance.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, Yemen is a complex case of civil conflict, where Shiite Houthi rebels are fighting the Sunni coalition under Saudi Arabia. The power struggle between the different versions of Islam is targeting the civilian population, and there are indications of crimes against humanity. The effects of the conflict are catastrophic. At least ten thousand people have been killed in clashes and millions have been displaced. Exclusion and civil strife with an international dimension have led to most medical facilities being malfunctioning, two million children out of school and the majority of citizens living in food insecurity, without access to safe drinking water or basic sanitation. I honestly do not believe and do not expect a solution from the international community when Trump, Merkel and May recently visited Saudi Arabia securing billions of dollars in arms sales. The legitimate fight against terrorism, which concerns us directly, does not allow us to turn a blind eye to the impending humanitarian crisis.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, Yemen is one of the poorest Arab countries in the world, and the war that is not subsiding further deepens the already unbearable situation in the country. The direct consequences of an armed conflict are large-scale and, if nothing is done, they are a direct threat to the entire population. Namely, this war-affected population is threatened by an even greater catastrophe in the form of various diseases, especially the appearance of cholera. The appearance and spread of cholera directly threatens millions of people who are already living in desperate conditions. In the last month alone, more than 100,000 people have succumbed to the plague, and reports from numerous humanitarian groups point out that one person dies from cholera every hour in Yemen. It is a frightening fact that sufferers are not at all able to seek the help of medical staff or find refuge in hospitals because hospitals are unable to provide care to cholera victims due to the number of war casualties. Stabilization of this area is no longer just a priority that does not suffer a moratorium, but with the advent of cholera it has gained alarming importance and requires extreme speed of action.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Commissioner, as you have pointed out, due to the humanitarian crisis in Yemen, one child dies every ten minutes. This is indeed a shocking fact. But do you think that the financial assistance provided by the European Union - which is really important - can solve the problem? Moreover, is it able to meet the responsibilities of the European Union itself, which is responsible for this development? What did the European Union do when Saudi Arabia intervened in this civil conflict, supporting government forces? But even now that Saudi Arabia is embroiled in another crisis with Qatar, what is the European Union doing? He is simply observing the events and the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, is simply recording the disasters. Does the European Union have the will and the power to force Saudi Arabia to cease hostilities, since it is also in a strategic position, so that humanitarian aid can go there? If he does not do this, what will happen will be to observe once again, and constantly, the deaths of children and to express, hypocritically, our deterrence.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I have listened very carefully to the whole debate that has taken place here. I have been trying to follow the events in Yemen for a long time, and I must say that what has been said here and what we are probably agreeing on is that we will not solve the civil war in this country if the powers of the region interfere in this country and defend their positions of power. So, Commissioner, I think that there is a great opportunity for the EU's international action to put pressure on countries such as Saudi Arabia, such as Iran, and to try to put the issue of Yemen on the table clearly when negotiating with them. For example, the aforementioned Saudi Arabia is our important trading partner. In the case of Iran, we have reached an agreement, Mrs Mogherini often talks about improving relations with that country, and yet Iran plays, in my opinion, a very negative role in interfering in Yemen. So, please, Commissioner, let us be more internationally active in this and press the countries around Yemen.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, our discussion has been a very useful exchange and I thank my dear colleagues for their constructive speeches. From this debate, I gather first of all that we all share a common sense of urgency, and, at the same time, a strong commitment in the spirit of the Conclusions on Yemen that were adopted by the Foreign Affairs Council, aiming to step up the European Union’s role in assisting the warring parties to find, without delay, an urgent solution to the crisis, and of course to find ways to reach a peaceful agreement – not now, not tomorrow, but yesterday.  I conclude from our debate that EU engagement must be based on a comprehensive approach – this is High Representative Federica Mogherini’s approach, because she knows well all the implications in the region – while at the same time encompassing all our diplomatic tools and political commitment combined with our development assistance and of course continued delivery of the much needed humanitarian relief. I know well, as Commissioner for humanitarian aid, the major problems for humanitarian access. I would like to say here that we try hard to find new ways for humanitarian access to meet vulnerable people, but on the ground I have to admit that sometimes it is very difficult, and sometimes it is impossible.  Likewise, you have been clear in stating that Member States should fully support the EU in this common endeavour through their bilateral actions and initiatives. I would like to give you some details about our humanitarian assistance and development in more detail in terms of funding. My service, ECHO, has allocated EUR 70 million for 2016, for specific humanitarian projects in the humanitarian field alone. The total ECHO allocations since the beginning of the conflict is EUR 120 million. A new pledge of EUR 123 million was announced this year, as I said at the pledge conference in Geneva. Meanwhile, DEVCO has allocated EUR 52 million in 2015, and now we are preparing EUR 200 million for the period 2018-2020, focusing on resilience, stabilisation, health, and food security. I would like to close by signalling once again my appreciation for the role of this political body, Parliament, in keeping this often forgotten crisis on the international agenda. I remember that many times, in many international fora, when we tried to raise awareness about the Yemen crisis, sometimes as the European Union we were alone. So I am sure that your attention in particular to the Yemen crisis, in these conditions, in these circumstances, is quite important to maintain this crisis on the international agenda.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday, 15 June 2017.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- The humanitarian situation in Yemen is catastrophic.The situation is deteriorating, including people suffering from malnutrition and disease.Military activities continue, humanitarian aid cannot be delivered and aid workers are unable to provide assistance.Continued hostilities have destabilized the country and are reassured by terrorist and extremist organizations.A solution can only come through negotiations.The continued support of the EU and the UN is also important for this.In addition, it is important that countries actually allocate their promised humanitarian aid funds to the United Nations.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy: Assessment of the implementation of the EU Guidelines on Freedom of Expression Online and Offline (2017/2728 (RSP)).

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. –Madam President, these last three years since the Council adopted the Human Rights Guidelines on Freedom of Expression Online and Offline have been particularly difficult for journalists and bloggers all around the world. Press freedom and freedom of expression are under attack. In several parts of the world violations and abuses have become more frequent, even in democratic states and societies, including in our own region. The European Union will not accept this situation as the new normal. Over the years we have continued to support the freedom of journalists and bloggers with public statements or, where necessary, with quiet action behind the scenes. In recent weeks we have raised our voice on a number of specific cases, from Turkey to Egypt, from Mexico to Belarus, just to name a few.  Since the adoption of the Guidelines in May 2014, the Council Working Party on Human Rights (COHOM) has organised three discussions on implementation of the Guidelines. These exchanges constituted an opportunity to evaluate with Member States the general state of play of freedom of expression but also the actions taken by the EEAS, the Commission and Member States to implement the Guidelines. In addition to these regular exchanges, COHOM has also engaged with civil society on freedom of expression and media freedom. The latest exchange at COHOM took place last November with Member States and Commission services. It was an opportunity to discuss the state of play of our policies in support of freedom of expression. The European Union’s commitment to freedom of expression online and offline has been renewed in the new EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy (2015-2019), including its regular reporting on implementation. In practical terms, freedom of expression continues to be raised on a regular basis in human rights dialogues and the consultations with partner countries. I can mention Laos, Azerbaijan and Bangladesh as the most recent examples. Let me also emphasise that the EEAS and the Commission organise regular specific training sessions on freedom of expression for EU and Member States’ staff, including EU delegations, with the active participation of representatives of civil society. In addition the EEAS and the Commission have regular contact with relevant civil society organisations active on freedom of expression, in Brussels as well as in the context of human rights dialogues with third countries.  I would like to recall that civil society organisations were associated from the beginning with the drafting of the Guidelines and took part in the 2014 December NGO Human Rights Forum, dedicated to freedom of expression online and offline. This work has changed the lives of many journalists and bloggers. In some cases it has been a true life-saver. The European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, through its emergency support mechanism, provides protection to journalists both professional and non-professional. We counted more than 200 interventions since 2015 to support people threatened for their defence or practice of freedom of expression. Since January 2017, a new technical assistance programme, financed by the Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, assists EU delegations in the implementation of the Guidelines. Our aim is to build on best practices and enhance the capacity of EU delegations to work more intensely and creatively. Looking ahead, the Estonian Presidency of the Council has chosen freedom of expression as one of its human rights priorities. This will give COHOM the opportunity to further evaluate the implementation of the Guidelines, in close cooperation with Estonia. An informal COHOM will take place on 19-20 October 2017, including a discussion on the lessons learned from implementation of the Guidelines. This discussion will include different stakeholders, such as representatives of EU institutions, international organisations and civil society. Press freedom and freedom of expression are central to the European way of life and to whom we are. We Europeans will not get used to the violations. We will continue to act quietly or vocally, depending on the situation, for everyone’s rights to report, to criticise and to speak up.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Commissioner! I would like to thank you for this information, but also to thank the next Presidency for wanting to take up this topic, which is important for many reasons. For, as you rightly pointed out, many elements indicate that in the area of ​​freedom of expression, there has recently been a huge increase in the activities of numerous states, numerous regimes against people of the media, against people who have the right to speak not only on their own behalf, but also also on behalf of society as a whole. The right to express one's opinion publicly is a fundamental human right and nothing can change that. Secondly, it is also the right to human dignity, because a person having the right to express himself is also respected in this respect. Free and diverse media are essential in any society to protect freedom of opinion, the right of expression and other human rights. Following the letter of the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, it should be stated that the European Union reaffirms its determination to promote in its external policy this right that can and should be enjoyed by every individual. We recognize that both political and financial instruments - such as the EIDHR mentioned here - can help to break down violations of these rights in a consistent, timely and consistent manner. I would like to point out that this area can also be supported by other instruments and funds, such as the European Endowment for Democracy, which is a unique tool for increasing freedom of expression online and offline.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, among the general considerations written in the guidelines it is emphasized that the right to freedom of opinion and expression applies equally and to all people and must be protected everywhere and guaranteed to all, regardless of who they are. people and where they live from. Despite the clarity of these statements, awareness remains of a necessary implementation of these guidelines for them to be useful not only within our borders, but can also encourage third countries to take decisive action to ensure a safe environment for those who wish to express their opinion. Whenever an individual is forced to censor himself or is the victim of intimidation and harassment, the entire society to which he belongs weakens and the direct consequence is a narrowing of the civil space. Examples of violations come from all over the world, from neighboring Turkey, where a large group of journalists, professors and philosophers are forced to choose between the expression of their opinions and their safety, or from Russia, where the activist Alexei Navalny on Monday was arrested again. Faced with these scenarios, of which we are sadly witnesses, we must always keep in mind that the European Union is equipped with potentially effective tools, such as trade agreements, to put pressure on these rights to be respected even outside its borders. . While it is also true that these violations exist within the borders of the European Union, we must rise to the role of guarantors of human rights in the world.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, most of the Romanian media and online services belong to controversial businessmen, many accused of corruption, fraud and other serious crimes. Some of them are politically connected or some of them are even politicians. Identifying owners is sometimes difficult, because you get lost in a maze of offshore companies. Reporters Without Borders writes in the 2017 report: "so-called journalists work in the Romanian press who do not write in the interest of the public, but in the interest of the owners". Of course, as a Romanian, I can tell you that in all trusts there are also honest journalists, who resist hard, but resist. Let's give some examples of these employers who have criminal or other problems and dictate editorial policy. The founder and financier of the Antena 3 trust, which includes several televisions, radios and newspapers, was sentenced to ten years in prison and declared a collaborator of the Securitate by the judges. Another example: Romania TV, whose owner was sued for three crimes, in three cases and fled the country. Digi24 television is being investigated for money laundering and tax evasion. Ziua newspaper had a criminal convict as its shareholder and, further, the list can go on. Basically, these people impose their personal agenda as a public agenda. That is why some of the journalists from these institutions attack justice and the fight against corruption every day.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, blocking websites, shutting down the internet and tracking and tracing human rights defenders via surveillance software is intensifying. While hopes were high that democracy could go viral because of the open internet and new technologies, instead it seems that technology amplifies relations of power. Dictators are using sophisticated technologies to repress, while individuals are joining forces to make their voices heard. And the key question for us is how to make sure that the European Union stands with people who are facing repression, and how we can further facilitate the enjoyment of universal human rights – online and offline. It is more important than ever that we, in Europe, take the lead in advancing and defending the right to freedom of expression, access to information and the right to privacy. We can do this by coming to the defence of journalists or bloggers who are intimidated and silenced, by ensuring encryption is used widely to secure information, and by pushing back at the highest political level when websites are blocked or speech is silenced. The 2014 guidelines on freedom of expression online and offline were adopted after a clear push and demand from this House. It was a welcome step, but three years is like a century in light of the rapid technological developments that we see. If we want to continue to do what is needed, we have to stay up—to—date and up—to—speed. We must build on best practices and make key improvements, based on the lessons learned of the use of these guidelines. I have one specific question to the Commissioner: can he reflect on what is the status of the no-disconnect strategy? It was part of the plan to stop the blocking of websites and the silencing of bloggers, and it has been a bit silent. So it would be good to get an update on that as well.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, freedom of expression is bad. The situation is deteriorating in two thirds of the countries listed by Reporters Without Borders (RSF), including in the so-called democratic countries. Europe is even the geographic area that has experienced the greatest deterioration in its overall index. Globally, around 100 journalists lost their lives in 2016, nearly 350 of them are imprisoned, a third for Turkey alone, another third for China, Iran and Egypt , which is particularly symbolic of this deterioration. About fifty journalists are also taken hostage, mainly in the Middle East, the most dangerous area in the world. We can also talk about cuts to the Internet before the elections or during social movements and there, it is the African continent that seems to have the palm of the regression or the repression of bloggers. The adoption by the European Union of its guidelines in 2014 was therefore good news, as long as it served some purpose. However, on this subject as on others, we really have the impression that the European leaders are gargling more than ever with words and that this hardly translates into the reality of the politicians. If I had to take a few examples, I would cite Turkey, Egypt or Tanzania. Saying is good, consulting civil society too, but it is even better when the implementation affects all the partners of the European Union, whoever they are.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! It is good that we are discussing the implementation of the guidelines on freedom of expression in plenary today, and it would also be good if the Council and the EEAS were to deal regularly with the implementation results of all thematic human rights guidelines and also with the guideline on international humanitarian law. The right to freedom of expression is violated in all regions of the world. Especially when criticism of government actions is expressed publicly, there is often defamation, persecution and threats of critics by government agencies. I was able to get a concrete picture of this on my recent trip to Singapore, Bangkok and Cambodia. Paragraph 50 of the guideline states that arbitrary restrictions on freedom of expression and violence against journalists and other media professionals must be assessed when it comes to suspending EU cooperation or suspending financial aid. I now ask: how often and in which countries has this paragraph 50 been applied? And specifically, using a country example, I would like to ask you, Commissioner Hahn: How can it be that in Egypt, where local journalists cannot work freely and independently without being threatened and persecuted, the financial aid was increased and EU cooperation intensified - are in stark contrast to the requirements of the guidelines on freedom of expression?

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, freedom of expression and public discourse has always been, and always will be, the enemy of the status quo of the state – whatever that state may be. We see attempts in repressive regimes to clamp down upon that, but even in free western civilised nations we now start to see efforts by the state to clamp down on freedom. And whilst in the past that freedom of discourse might have been in the pub or in a public area, now, of course, it moves to the internet. The very concept of social media being clamped down on by the state – often using fear as the excuse – is completely against all concept of freedom, and I address this as well to the British Government, who have spoken very much about trying to clamp down on these things, using fear of terror as a reason. The one thing I will say, though, is that the idea of guidelines imposed from the European state upon freedom of expression on social media is in itself something of a contradiction. Free the airwaves, free social media, let’s all speak as we wish.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Madam President! Freedom of expression: This morning, when my friend Horst Mahler was 81 years old in Hungary, he was extradited by the Hungarian authorities to German police officers so that he could be taken back to prison in the Brandenburg penal institution. What was his crime? He was sentenced to 12 years in prison in 2009 for the opinion he expressed. His left foot was amputated in prison in 2015. And he didn't want to die in prison, he wanted to die in freedom - that's why he went to Hungary. Do you actually know, Commissioner, that there are 12,000 investigations into free speech every year in Germany? That there are currently around 400 right-wing citizens on the run and evaded prison just because they expressed their free opinion? Work to ensure that these human rights guidelines on freedom of expression - online and offline - apply to all EU citizens!

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! (The speaker speaks without a microphone.)… Sunday speeches highlight the importance of human rights for European foreign policy. Rightly, because only democracy, the rule of law and human rights create stability. It was therefore positive that the Council adopted guidelines on freedom of expression in May 2014. Even then, reference was made to the importance of online media. The document is still up to date today, which is actually something very rare in this area. It addresses important areas such as hate speech or data protection. It is disappointing that there has not yet been a systematic evaluation as provided for in Article 71 of the guidelines. In the 2015 Human Rights Report I also pointed out the importance of a systematic implementation strategy that was discussed with stakeholders. Last year in particular it became clear that online media not only influence the situation of expressing opinions in individual countries, but are also increasingly becoming a means of international disputes - keyword “fake news”. If the Union takes its guidelines really seriously, it must do everything in its power to carry out this dialogue on a broad basis, consistently and courageously. I put my hope in the Estonian Presidency that something will finally get going.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President!Commissioner!Ladies and gentlemen,We are talking about the whole world, about violations of freedom of speech in the farthest places from Europe, and we do not see that in the heart of our continent, the Union and our countries, in France, the so-called anti-abortion law was passed this year, which allows for imprisonmentfor journalists operating on the Internet, which allows high, destructive media fines, and despite calls for a position on this matter, the authorities of the European Union have been silent so far.We often boast about our soft power, that our opinion is important in the world, that through words, telling the truth, things can be changed.Commissioner!This is a very important occasion for you today - you mentioned other countries - I am asking you to take a stance on what happened in France, because it is not too late, our voice can have its own meaning.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: – Madam President, there has been a lot of talk about limitation of freedom of expression elsewhere, but we also have to look into the European Union and what are we doing here. Many decision makers see the online world as this scary place where no rule applies and it is full of hate speech and an incitement to terrorism. But as much as the internet can do bad, it can also do good. Despite – or maybe thanks to – the scale of the internet, where everything is amplified, freedom of expression matters as much online as it does offline. There is much to be done to educate people as regards to their behaviour online, but one important thing is to understand that if you make it easy to block and take down content, you make it easy to commit censorship. The current discussions are all about how fast a company take down content, how to make it faster. However, I believe that if we are serious about protecting freedom of speech online, we need to take a big step back and ask ourselves if making companies the police, the prosecutor and the judge is the right answer.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union's guidelines on human rights, which we are discussing today, do not, as we know, nor could they, moreover, have a coercive legal character. However, the European Union, having fundamentally in mind its own foundational values, has the moral obligation to strive for its application and create the conditions so that, with its political influence and negotiating capacity, they can be respected and implemented in multiple situations. . We know that this is not always the case. All over the world we see, with unprecedented frequency, attacks on freedom of expression ranging from the least serious to those that can only be considered absolutely unacceptable, such as the murders of journalists that have occurred in Mexico or the arrest and prosecution of dozens of members of the media, which have taken place in a neighboring country like Turkey. It is essential that the European Union continues to use all the instruments at its disposal to combat these and other cases of attacks on freedom of expression, and I believe that in this area, we have a fundamental instrument, which are the trade agreements we have established with several countries in world.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Madam President! As you know, the Working Party on Human Rights considered that there was no need to evaluate the guidelines on freedom of expression online and offline. And this document, as we know, should set the direction of the actions of representatives of the EU and Member States in relations with third countries. However, one may wonder if this restraint in making judgments is not related to the fact that in Europe itself we have great problems with assessing what is freedom of opinion and expression, and what is hate speech, which should be eliminated from the public sphere. As my colleagues said, first of all my colleague Jurek, the problem that we see and are trying to stigmatize in third countries is becoming more and more forceful in the European Union countries. Of course, no one in Europe locks up journalists and tortures them, while the elimination from the public sphere, marginalization and intimidation are also on the agenda and the example given by ... (The President cut off the deputy's floor)

name: Ana GOMES
text: - The European Union needs to do much more to protect journalists and bloggers from around the world and to pressure other countries to close the digital divide and facilitate access to information and communication, including uncontrolled access to the Internet. It is necessary to criticize and denounce at the highest level governments like Turkey, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Ethiopia, Egypt, China, where bloggers and journalists are arrested and online space is censored. For example, the Angolan regime, in addition to repressing and intimidating journalists and bloggers, has just prevented the transmission of Portuguese television channels, SIC and SIC Notícias, for having dared to organize reports and debates on human rights in that country. Many of these repressive regimes import electronic material for mass surveillance of their citizens from European companies. The proliferation of monitoring censorship surveillance and filtering technologies poses a growing threat to activists and defenders of human rights, democracy and the fight against corruption. Our Member States and our companies must be held accountable for what they do and what they let them do.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, the aspect of protecting human dignity is in many cases at odds with freedom of expression.Today, it is difficult to reconcile these principles in offline space as well, but the spread of the online world has completely transformed the nature of human relationships and the medium we perceive as public space.Yet I think we need to try to enforce the original definition of liberal freedom of speech: everyone’s freedom extends as long as they do not restrict anything else in their freedom by their actions, activities, or even by expressing their opinions.In this sense, we must balance freedom of expression in the light of human rights guidelines, because the freedom of everyone is equally important: the one who expresses his opinion, but also the one who violates the dignity, values and way of life of that opinion.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the new technology has now been subjugated to the authorities and the local oligarchs. In Turkey, journalists are silenced. In Arab countries, the same. In Bangladesh, the chicken of European multinationals where they earn millions, press freedom has been abolished. But freedom of expression also means the right of citizens, MEPs and MEPs to have equal treatment and access to the media. I have complained about it again and I say it, in Strasbourg, here, every month Greek journalists come at the expense of the European Parliament, use the studios and facilities of the European Parliament, record shows and systematically exclude the ECR Group and me from these broadcasts, which are made here in the European Parliament. Will there be a reaction to this? Will the European Parliament put its house in order? Will this discriminatory treatment continue against the ECR Group and against the Greek journalists who use the means of the European Parliament itself?

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, as we all know well, human rights are not only one of the founding values of the EU, but they are also among the guiding principles and objectives of its actions on the international arena. In this context, the EU human rights guidelines on freedom of expression online and offline aims to provide legal protection to whistleblowers, citizens’ privacy and freedom of opinion. However, since its adoption back in 2014, the EU human rights guidelines of freedom of expression offline and online have not managed to provide adequate protection for journalists, bloggers or citizens around the world.  To evaluate the current situation of freedom of expression, it is necessary just to mention the case of Sakharov Laureate Raif Badawi, who has been flogged for blogging. Unfortunately, nowadays there is a record number of journalists in jail globally, and internet freedom has been limited in many countries. Working from this perspective, I call on the EU to increase dramatically the funding for internet and human rights protectors.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President, freedom of expression and expression are inseparable from the concept of democracy, because in a democracy, democratic decisions are made in a clash of arguments, counter-arguments, battles and free debates. It is astonishing for us Hungarians, who have lived under socialism or communism for almost fifty years, to see that freedom of expression and expression is being abolished in certain areas in Western Europe. An example is migration. Those who are, so to speak, anti-migration, critical of mass immigration, are oppressed by criminal law. They are prosecuted, imprisoned, enforced by labor sanctions, expelled from their jobs. For fifty years, we Hungarians have experienced a lack of expression and expression of opinion, and thus of democracy. Don’t try to force this on us, they will try, but they won’t be successful, we will preserve our values.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I agree with all my predecessors when it comes to assessing the international situation in the area of freedom of expression, but I think that we should also sweep ourselves in front of our own doorstep.The situation in Europe is deteriorating, and I also agree with my colleague Macovei, who said this.In the Czech Republic, we are witnessing a kind of concentration of economic, political and media power.So not only in the Czech Republic, this has been resolved by the Conflict of Interest Act, which forbids the ownership of these defined instruments, which are important in a democratic society, but concentration in one single hand can indeed be potentially very dangerous.I think that we should also address this in the EU field, because this freedom of expression is the absolute basis of our European values, and we should take care of its good development in the future as well.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this has been a very useful exchange and I would like to thank the honourable Members for the interventions. I wanted to answer Ms Schaake but she is no longer there, so maybe we will have another opportunity to clarify this. Frau Lochbihler, Sie haben mich wegen Ägypten gefragt. Also ich kann Ihnen nur sagen: Ich weiß nicht, woher Sie die Annahme haben, dass Ägypten mehr Geld bekommt. Fakt ist, dass wir mit Ägypten sehr intensive Gespräche wegen der Menschenrechtssituation haben, wegen der Situation der Zivilgesellschaft. Es gibt eine spezielle Budgetlinie, die sich zusätzlich zu den üblichen Zahlungen an Ägypten mit der Unterstützung in Migrationsfragen beschäftigt. Das ist aber etwas, das Teil der generellen finanziellen Unterstützung nordafrikanischer Staaten ist. Umgekehrt kann ich berichten, dass es verschiedene Programme gibt, etwa OPEN Media Hub oder MedMedia-Programme. Das sind Programme, die auch dazu dienen, etwa in Ägypten unabhängigen Journalisten und media outlets zu helfen, ihrer Arbeit nachzukommen und sich auch persönlich professionell zu qualifizieren. Finally, let me stress that COHOM is committed to ensuring the effectiveness of the guidelines and will hence continue its yearly evaluation of guidelines. We remain committed to continuing to engage and work with the European Parliament on the implementation of this guideline. It was not the last, and it will not be the last, discussion on Human Rights guidelines on freedom of expression online and offline; this is something which will stay with us, unfortunately. I think we all should be sensitive and alert on this subject, and should have a regular exchange about the state of play in this area.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I close the debate.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on the report by David McAllister, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the Commission's 2016 report on Serbia.(2016/2311 (INI)) (A8-0063 / 2017)

name: David McALLISTER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, after the United Kingdom decided to leave the European Union, people not only in Europe but throughout the whole world have heard and read a lot about Article 50, which sets out the précis of how a Member State may withdraw from the European Union. I believe that we should scroll back one paragraph and focus on Article 49, which provides the legal basis for any European state to join the European Union. That said, the message of our debate tonight on the European Parliament’s report on Serbia should be clear: Serbia doesn’t only have a European perspective; Serbia has a European future. This country is clearly moving towards the European Union – so far, eight chapters have already been opened in the negotiation process, while two have already been provisionally closed. I strongly welcome that Commissioner Hahn – who I would once again like to thank for his outstanding commitment and engagement in the region – announced this week in Belgrade that two more chapters will be opened this month. There are three points which are of utmost importance on Serbia’s path towards the European Union that I would like to mention.  Firstly, the rule of law: I would like to use this opportunity to recall that Serbia’s progress on the rule of law Chapters 23 and 24 remains essential for the overall pace of the negotiation process. Judicial independence has to be assured in practice, because corruption and organised crime still remain an obstacle – not only to Serbia, but to all western Balkan countries’ democratic, social and economic development. On another point, I agree with the European Commission and the Council that, to guarantee unhindered exercise of the freedom of expression and media, shortcomings in this area should be addressed as a matter of priority.  Secondly, Serbia’s economy. The criteria for membership are intended to help Serbia to stand on its own feet and become fit for our common market and for the global economy in general. Serbia made progress with regards to the budget deficit and restructuring of publicly owned enterprises. The government in Belgrade is implementing an impressive economic and structural reforms agenda which has already yielded results in terms of growth prospects and the reduction of domestic and external imbalances. Moreover, this country has demonstrated its commitment to the EU connectivity agenda, which we aim to enhance further at the Trieste summit in July.  Thirdly, regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations: the government in Belgrade has made very important symbolic, but also substantial, steps to contribute to a better understanding and cooperation in the region. We all know that Serbia’s EU accession process is closely linked to the normalisation of relations with Kosovo. It is not only about concluding agreements; it is more about implementing them. As soon as Serbia has a new prime minister, and as soon as Kosovo has a stable government, both parties should continue to move forward with the full implementation of all the already reached agreements, and that in good faith and in a timely manner. Both sides, Pristina and Belgrade, should now take clear steps to show their commitment and credibility.  A final remark: I am convinced that this resolution is able to find the right balance between praising Serbia for adopting important reforms and pointing out what remains to be done. As we are having our political discourse, we should not forget that we are talking about changes that demand a lot from the Serbian citizens. I am well aware that this process goes far beyond the purely economic transformation – it is a truly social transformation – but I am convinced that this reform process is worth every effort.

name: David McALLISTER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, on behalf of the Presidency it is my great pleasure to address this Parliament to discuss the 2016 report on Serbia. As you know, the Western Balkans featured on the agenda of the European Council in March, where Member States reconfirmed the EU’s engagement with the region, including through deepening political and economic ties. The European Council discussions in March also clearly reaffirmed the unequivocal support for the European perspective on the Western Balkans. In this spirit the Presidency remains committed to advancing the enlargement process in full respect of the basic principles of conditionality and own merits. Serbia has made significant progress in 2016 and the accession negotiations have advanced at a steady pace. The rule of law chapters were opened in July 2016, enabling the EU and Serbia to engage closely on this decisive area. I am particularly happy to say that we have managed to keep the momentum in Serbia’s accession negotiations under the Maltese Presidency with an accession conference at ministerial level held on 27 February. On this occasion we were in a position to open Chapter 20 – Enterprise and Industrial Policy – as well as to open and provisionally close Chapter 26, Education and Culture. These chapters cover important economic and social aspects which are of interest to Serbia’s businesses, youth and citizens in general. Reforms strive to meet the expectations of the Serbian citizens and not only those of the EU. Work on further negotiating chapters is currently being finalised in the Council preparatory bodies. Once all Member States give their agreement, the Presidency stands ready to convene another accession conference next week. Progress in the accession negotiations is an acknowledgment of Serbia’s reform efforts, but it should also serve as an encouragement to the new Serbian Government, once in place, to remain committed to pursuing this reform path. Many areas requiring further reform efforts are rightly spelled out in your draft report. In this regard, let me again underline the particular importance we also attach to key areas such as the rule of law, fundamental rights, public administration reform and economic governance. The rule of law continues to be at the heart of the enlargement process. Serbia needs to continue to make progress under the rule of law chapters opened last July, guided by the respective action plans and interim benchmarks. To this end, Serbia should intensify reform efforts and focus on effective implementation, which can make a significant contribution to the good results produced by Serbia’s economic reforms. In the area of fundamental rights, Serbia needs to address shortcomings in the freedom of expression as a matter of priority and ensure respect and protection of minorities. Likewise, the normalisation of relations with Kosovo will also remain essential for the overall pace of the negotiations, especially the further implementation of agreements reached within the Belgrade-Pristina dialogue. In this context, Serbia’s commitment to remaining constructively engaged in the dialogue and to continuously work on a further normalisation of relations needs to be acknowledged. Important steps in the dialogue, such as Serbia’s implementation of the telecommunications agreement and the resumption of works on the Mitrovica bridge, should serve as an encouragement to take the process forward. We look forward to the continued engagement of all involved and urge Serbia to swiftly implement in good faith its part of all past agreements. In the area of regional cooperation we welcome Serbia’s constructive engagement and encourage it to continue its efforts to strengthen good neighbourly relations as well as to remain committed to preserving peace and stability in the region. Full cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia remains essential. On various occasions the Council has also reiterated its call on Serbia to progressively align with the EU common foreign and security policy, including on restrictive measures in the period up to accession. Let me again underline the growing importance of further deepening cooperation on foreign policy issues. I will conclude by again welcoming the continued progress in Serbia’s EU accession negotiations and the continued good cooperation with the EU and with the region. Let me also recall our appreciation for the constructive contribution of the European Parliament, and in particular of your rapporteur, David McAllister, to advance Serbia’s accession process to the EU. I can assure you that we pay particular attention to the views of the Parliament in this regard.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would first and foremost like to congratulate David McAllister for his resolution on the 2016 report on Serbia. This is a balanced and accurate assessment of Serbia’s focus on its path to the European Union. From our point of view, it is overall in line with the findings of our own report of November 2016 and the Commission’s assessment since then.  I share your view that Serbia has made good progress towards EU membership, which remains Serbia’s strategic objective. This has been repeatedly outlined by the Serbian authorities and President Vučić. Serbia’s ambitious economic and structural reform agenda is already delivering results. Serbia has shown its commitment to peace and stability in the region: good neighbourly relations, regional cooperation and the continuation of the dialogue with Pristina. This is encouraging for the Western Balkans connectivity agenda and the next Trieste summit in July. Serbia has also made progress in the reform of its public administration, and has started implementing its ambitious action plans on the rule of law, and Serbia is indeed to be commended for its efforts to address the refugee and migration crisis, which continued EU support. This hard work has paid off with eight chapters opened now, two provisionally closed, and a number of other chapters being prepared for opening. Serbia should now build on its progress and move decisively ahead with reforms, in particular on the rule of law and the protection of the most vulnerable groups and minorities. It is equally important that Serbia continues playing its part in the normalisation of its relations with Kosovo.  Together with you, I regret that some developments have not been of help in this direction, and I look forward to the resumption of the dialogue. I am also encouraged by President Vučić’s willingness to launch a domestic dialogue on Kosovo. I also share your views that strategic communication to ensure public support and understanding of the benefits and obligations of EU accession is of key importance for EU supporters in Serbia. The EU is Serbia’s number one partner, including on assistance – EUR 2 billion in grants since 2007, and way ahead of any other global partners – and this deserves to be known. From our side, we are making every effort to strengthen our public diplomacy, and I was in Serbia only last weekend with that in mind. I can only encourage you to support our efforts in this direction.  Now that the Serbian presidential elections are behind us, I am confident that all energy in Serbia will be devoted to the implementation of the reform agenda. Whatever the difficulties – and they are real – Serbia should not lose sight of its EU membership goal and should continue to act accordingly, doing its part of the job with continued EU support. I appreciate that the European Parliament is, in that respect, on the same page.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate David McAllister on his report and, in particular, on his personal commitment to helping Serbia in the process of European integration. It is an objective that several members of this Parliament share. We want Serbia to continue reforms that can bring it closer to Europe. We can only rejoice that accession negotiations are progressing and are, in my turn, as David said earlier, glad that I heard Commissioner Hahn say that new chapters will be opened with Serbia in the near future. . It is a positive message for all countries in the region, which are concerned about a potential stagnation in the process of enlarging our Union. Of course, Serbia still has a long way to go, starting with the promotion of serious debates about the Union, its institutions and the implications of accession. It is a very useful thing to avoid tensions before and after accession. Then, Serbia must continue to progressively align its foreign policy with that of the Union, especially with regard to Russia, where there is a lot of work to be done. Accelerating anti-corruption efforts, strengthening the rule of law, coherent enforcement of minority legislation throughout the territory and avoiding discriminatory treatment are other areas where we want significant progress. Finally, I would like to welcome the Serbian authorities' commitment to regional cooperation, but as rapporteur for Bosnia and Herzegovina, I am concerned about the participation of Serbian officials in the celebration of Republika Srpska, as it was an anniversary against the rule of law in Bosnia and Herzegovina. I hope this doesn't happen again.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, first of all, I congratulate rapporteur McAllister for a balanced report and good cooperation. Since the beginning of the negotiations with the European Union, Serbia has certainly achieved good progress. Negotiation chapters are being opened and closed and just yesterday, as we heard, Commissioner Hahn has announced the opening of new chapters later this month. On paper and in the report in front of us, the development in Serbia seems pretty much business as usual. But what I hear when I talk to Serbian citizens shows the contrary. Young Serbs tell me that it is almost impossible to get a job without a party membership card or paying a certain amount of the money to a party official, and NGO reports show continuous decline in the rule of law and unresolved cases such as Savamala prove this in practice. Media representatives are threatened, investigative journalists are turned away and some of them are even physically attacked. I ask myself, and you: is this the Serbia which we want as part of our European family? Is this what we want to achieve with negotiating chapters 23 and 24? I am afraid not.
