Serbia should do much more to reach our European standards of democracy, rule of law and the respect for human rights. I am sure that if we continue to practice constructive criticism and turn a blind eye to the real state of play, we will once again prove that we are doing something wrong. As an important player in the region, I wish for Serbia to develop into a prosperous, economically and socially stable country where democracy is a way of living not a word on paper, where rules, as opposed to the interests of those who hold power in their hands, prevail. This is the Serbia we want to help and support on its path to our European family.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Allow me to express my satisfaction with working with the rapporteur for Serbia, David McAllister, who has put a lot of effort and creativity into this weighty and balanced document. Serbia is well on its way to membership of the European Union, and in order to achieve stability and overall progress, the Union must accept Serbia and open the European and Euro-Atlantic perspective to all the countries of South-Eastern Europe. On the positive side, the report highlights Serbia's solid economic performance and improved standards of democratic governance, greater preparedness but not yet sufficient cooperation with civil society, and a responsible approach to the necessary reforms. On the critical side, the tendency of occasional aggravation - especially verbal - of relations with neighbors in the region, tactics between pro-European and pro-Russian orientation, cannot be overlooked. In doing so, given that the country declares its neutrality, participation in the military maneuvers of Russia and its close allies is questionable. When it comes to the media in Serbia, it is considered that appropriate legislation is not enough if in practice political control and pressure on the media, reduction of the media to the role of propagandists of the ruling parties and personalities are allowed. Policy interference in the judiciary will also need to be eliminated on the way to a credible state of law. Serbia is a key country in the region, which is why it must limit its ambitions in promoting its interests in neighboring countries. Together with other countries in the region, Serbia must work to reconcile and pacify this part of Europe. The European perspective of all countries and peoples in this field is the key to peace, stability and progress.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - The Serbian state has always been a central part of the Balkans. For centuries, Serbs faced attacks from the Turks and efforts to destroy independence. Even Austria-Hungary was not interested in good neighborly relations. Yugoslavia has become an attempt to promote the peaceful coexistence and development of all intertwined nations in the Balkans. The bloody retaliation that the Serbs received in the early 1990s, followed by the secession of parts and, most recently, the unlawful establishment of the State of Kosovo, shows an effort to break up the entire central part of the Balkans into the smallest possible units. The drastic bombing has shown that NATO has not been and will never be a guarantor of peace. The hypocrisy of EU leaders is shown, inter alia, in paragraphs 24 and 30 of this report. How can those who do not see the trampling of minority rights in many EU countries dare to call on Serbia to discuss minority protection legislation thoroughly? Another example is the call for the Serbian authorities to support constitutional reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina. I do not understand why the report does not address a similar challenge to supporters of the Serbian-Croatian Muslim part of the country. The culmination of these demands, incidentally formulated by the same forces that canceled Bulgaria's and Serbia's plan to build the Southstream gas pipeline, is the emphasis on "Serbia needs to develop its gas and electricity interconnections with neighboring countries." It is no wonder that, as a result of these and other steps by the European Commission, which is trying to interfere in Serbia's internal affairs, I consider this report to be one of the highlights of hypocrisy in the Balkans' EU integration process to date. GUE / NGL ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I am speaking on behalf of the Greens/EFA shadow, Mr Igor Šoltes, who is just returning from Kosovo at the moment, as he was the head of the EP delegation to the legislative elections in Kosovo.  First of all, let me say all the positive things we have in the report. I would like also to thank the rapporteur, Mr McAllister, and all the other shadows for their very good cooperation on the topic. There has been continuous progress of Serbia in the EU integration process, which I am very glad to say, and I am also very glad that the Commissioner has announced that new chapters will be opened. This is important to show also that the EU is progressing with Serbia to move ahead. There has also been progress, for example, on the issue of a functioning market economy, especially when it comes to small- and medium-sized enterprises, and I hope this will continue.  Nevertheless, there are several issues of concern, some of which have been raised already by colleagues: the issue of the strong rhetoric used during the presidential campaign by government officials against other presidential candidates, and other issues of irregularities that have been found. One area of strong concern is the Savamala district in Belgrade, where for one year there has not really been an investigation into the demolition of private property which took place there, and that should be done. Another issue that has been raised by Tanja Fajon, Ivo Vajgl and others is the issue of freedom of the media, which really is of concern and is worsening. I hope also that, in the dialogue with Kosovo and Serbia, progress will be made on implementation.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the arrival of a new President in the Republic of Serbia. However, we draw the attention of the European Parliament to the fact that today Serbia is subject by the European Union to the Brezhnev doctrine. A foreign policy doctrine, which aims at three points, unfortunately. First, to make membership of the European Union conditional on membership of NATO: I recall the massacres that NATO perpetrated in Yugoslavia in 1999. Secondly, to condition the membership of Serbia on the renunciation of its minorities - I am thinking in particular of the Serbian Republic of Bosnia and Kosovo -, to condition the membership also on the severing of the close ties that exist between Serbia and Russia. This is why I think we have to realize that Serbia has no interest in wanting to join the European Union, which is a trap set against the interests of the Serbian people.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I also wrote my most important message.We must veto, prevent Serbia's accession to the European Union until it provides self-determination, including full and real, effective autonomy for the nearly three hundred thousand Hungarians in Vojvodina.There are models that work perfectly for this in Europe, South Tyrol or the Basque Country, this is the modern perception of collective human rights, let us demand this from Serbia.These people have the right to live as Hungarians in their homeland.This is not the case now.I would like to ask my fellow Members and members of the Commission whether they have received the documentaries I sent you about ... (The President cut off the floor)

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to acknowledge the work done by the rapporteur, Mr McAllister, in preparing this report, which welcomes Serbia's willingness to join the European Union and, above all, to express this constructive spirit in the negotiating process as a firm manifestation of political will. I believe that the report has two very clear parts. One of them highlights the efforts and progress that Serbia has made in the context of economic policy. We have followed, Commissioner, your speech in Belgrade, just a few days ago, in the field of judicial and police cooperation and also of relations with third countries - in the case of Albania - and also the way that remains to be traveled especially with regard to freedom of expression and the fight against political corruption. I would like to stop, Mr.President, on one point and that is the approach of Serbia to the common foreign and security policy and relations with Russia at a time when the President of Serbia, in his inauguration speech He said that they had three fundamental priorities, one which was clearly to put their country on the path of the European Union, then contribute to regional stability and, above all, strengthen its relations with China and Russia. Today the European Commission approved its document on defense policy and we had the German Defense Minister in the Foreign Affairs Committee. That is why, Mr President, I find particularly relevant, within this report, the call made by the rapporteur, Mr McAllister, to the need not only to advance in the negotiating chapters - and we all congratulate ourselves on this -, but to align its policy with the foreign and security policy of the European Union. I think this is a fundamental piece of information in the dossier. We are talking about politics and, therefore, Mr. President, I would like again to congratulate the rapporteur on the report and draw attention to this important fact of his work.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr McAllister, and our shadow, Tanya Fajon, for the fair and balanced draft report. Today, we in our Group reiterate our commitment to the enlargement process. The accession of the Western Balkan countries and of Serbia remains one of our main priorities. A lot has been achieved in Serbia, notably for the improvement of the overall economic situation, the fight against organised crime and the regional cooperation. This report carefully and fairly acknowledges this. But I also have a lot of concerns about the status of democracy in Serbia, including the way in which in the recent presidential campaign has been fuelled with populist and nationalist rhetoric and the way in which the freedom of media has been repeatedly undermined. Alleged irregularities in the elections are still awaiting an investigation. Now some critical remarks, including one on you, Mr Commissioner. Stability in the Western Balkans is important, but we should not sacrifice our values for stability: both have to go hand in hand when negotiating. In playing with the so-called stabilocracy we might lose what is the most important – Serbian citizens and their commitment towards democracy. We have to pay attention to the way the opposition and the freedom of the media are respected and be certain that the civil society concerns are listened to, because the implementation of the reforms matters for its citizens. In a time of global uncertainty, within the Union and in the Western Balkans in particular, with regional and global actors becoming more and more active in the region, the European Union has to signal its real commitment to enlargement and for the countries in the region, including Serbia, to have unequivocal choices.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I am not satisfied with the progress of Serbia, if it can be called progress at all. Cosmetically things may change, but essentially not. This will eventually lead to an increase in distrust of the European Union in Serbia, but also of the citizens of Serbia in the European Union. I am even more dissatisfied with the position of the Commission, which allows a number of open issues that Serbia has with Croatia, concerning human rights, property rights and respect for international treaties and conventions, to be left out of these negotiations. Of all these issues, only the border dispute is a real bilateral issue in which the Commission should not interfere. Also, I do not see any need to establish a regional commission to establish the facts about war crimes and other serious human rights violations. We have two decades of war crimes trials behind us and the facts are very well known, only Serbia is successfully ignoring them. This commission would make a mess and give Serbia an additional reason for not fulfilling its obligations.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: - Last year, Serbia made significant progress in fully implementing reforms and policies on its path to the European Union. Serbia's success in the integration process is a clear sign of the country's European orientation and its desire to join the Union. However, we cannot help but note with concern that the country continues to pursue a foreign policy that is not fully in line with that of the European Union, given the complex geopolitical situation in the region. Indeed, the lack of synchronicity between Serbia's foreign policy and the European Union is a precondition for destabilizing the Balkans. I therefore call on the Serbian authorities to show the necessary political will and to translate their foreign policy in line with that of the European Union. They also need to show determination to normalize and deepen good neighborly relations, in particular with Kosovo, because only then will the region's security, peace and European perspective be guaranteed.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report is very similar in wording to last year's report, presented by the same rapporteur. It’s not all negative. He recognizes that Serbia has a European vocation. However, at what price do we recognize this dimension? Serbia must deny its history when asked to treat Kosovo as an equal partner when this entity, Islamized and run by organized crime, was torn from it by NATO bombing, in defiance of international law. Serbia must come under the domination of the "open society" of Mr. Soros, who influences this Parliament, and deal with the consequences of the crazy migration policy that this gentleman has prepared and that the German government has taken over. Serbia must give up its natural role as a bridge between Russia and Europe and it must follow a European Union on the brink of the abyss, a Union which is - excuse me for the ridiculous - applauding the entry of Montenegro . In fact, what we are asking Serbia is to relinquish its identity and sovereignty.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, David McCallister, for a well-prepared report. We have before us a text that objectively reflects the development of integration in Serbia over the previous period. Serbia underwent several political changes during this period. I am glad that the presidential elections, which took place in April, were peaceful, and I believe that the new president will continue Serbia's pro-European direction. Serbia is making progress in the integration process. The opening of new chapters is a clear signal that the country is well prepared for accession negotiations. It should be recalled that in key areas such as the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption, Serbia should show greater political will to address pressing issues. These are mainly Chapters 23 and 24, where we expect a clear political signal, reforms and a decisive solution. We are also increasingly receiving information on the persisting problems of media freedom, attacks on journalists, as well as problems relating to civil liberties and the shrinking space for civil society. Although this trend is evident in all the countries of the region, let us not hide it, we should be very sensitive to these issues and draw attention to them clearly. Only in this way can we deepen the confidence of Serbian society in European values. Finally, I would like to encourage Serbian politicians to pursue a responsible and constructive policy in the region. Serbia, as one of the regional leaders, has a responsibility for the stability and development of the whole region. I firmly believe that he will use this new role to stimulate cooperation throughout the region. Thank you very much.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, I congratulate my colleague McAllister on the report on Serbia's progress that it has made in the past year. It is worth mentioning the opening of the first eight chapters, the noticeable economic growth and the improved general legislative framework. However, in many areas this year we are witnessing a lack of progress, even worsening, despite changes in legislation. First of all, the freedom of the media in Serbia is endangered today, the fight against corruption and organized crime is insufficiently effective, the necessary strengthening of the rule of law is not recorded, as well as the implementation of the recently adopted action plan on respect for minority and human rights. in The Hague and better alignment with European Union foreign policy. All this is part of the "to do" list that Serbia should shorten. In addition, it would be incomplete to talk about influential events in Serbia, not to mention the recent protests of mostly young people after the presidential election. The reasons for their dissatisfaction are a cause for concern. They claim that the election results brought only a formal change of functions. Adequate contribution to better relations with neighbors and resolving remaining bilateral issues, such as determining the fate of the missing or succession, is also extremely important in the process of Serbia's progress. For Serbia, progress in the process of normalization with Kosovo, in which there are too many oscillations and stagnation, is of particular importance. There is no doubt that solving the problems of the past would open up space for cooperation on the issues of a common European future.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, Serbia deserves a clear and secure European perspective.Serbia has taken a number of steps that are positive and that should be respected.I support this report, I support what Commissioner Hahn is doing and I believe that it is for the benefit and stability of all countries in the Balkans, because Serbia is a very important factor in all this.But I want to point out that the presidential election brought a new president.He should be congratulated on the election, but the fact should be taken into account that after that there were a series of protests that show above all dissatisfaction in Serbia.Smart government will open a dialogue.Problems of justice, problems of media freedom, problems of minorities, necessary regional cooperation are all elements of what we expect from Serbia.And finally, let's not have illusions, the majority of Serbian citizens are for the European Union, but the vast majority of Serbian citizens are not for NATO.And harmonizing security policy will be very difficult in this context.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Mr President, thank you for the excellent work of the rapporteur, Mr McAllister. The European Union has a key role to play in maintaining and consolidating the peace and stability created by the war in the Balkans following the break-up of the former Yugoslavia. For the countries of the Western Balkans, European integration is the way to unfold and for the future. That is why the Union must not leave them alone in their multifaceted crisis. Aware of this, the European Union must provide these countries with a realistic opportunity to join as soon as possible, but those who have embarked on integration must make a much greater effort to meet the demands placed on them and their own commitments. Serbia appears to be on track to meet these requirements. With regard to the findings and shortcomings in the Serbian country report, this time I will focus exclusively on the issue of ethnic minorities. I miss in the report the explicit wording of minority autonomy and, in this connection, the fact that the adoption of laws on national councils and the rights of national minorities is being postponed. The document also fails to demand the return of minority community-church assets. It is also unsustainable that the provisions of the otherwise laudable legislation on the protection of minorities usually remain on paper, and their implementation is notoriously delayed. As a representative of allied Hungary, I would like to raise my voice separately for the municipal and human rights of the Hungarian community in Serbia.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr Chairman! This year, it will be 22 years since the conclusion of the Dayton Agreement, and 18 years since the end of the Kosovo war. This report, which presents the tasks for Serbia at the time and present in a very good manner, both the progress and what is ahead of Serbia in terms of membership negotiations, builds a certain - so to speak - optimism. President Buzek once said that we managed to prevent the return of conflicts in the Western Balkans in a surprising and simple way, because the countries of the region had lined up to join the European Union. That was an important statement, but at the same time it is not enough: we too have to make a lot of efforts. It is a value that the Union - and we must remember it - has this attraction. Of course, there are many criticizing voices that undermine the value of the Union, but I think it is worth recalling it when talking about Serbia during this debate. The report should not only be an incentive for the Serbian government, but above all it should also be a kind of encouragement for the citizens of Serbia that it is worth continuing the reforms that are sometimes difficult and sometimes even incomprehensible at a given stage. It seems that, for example, the indication by Commissioner Hahn that we have donated more than two billion euros to support these processes is worth noting. There has been a lot of progress in the area of ​​economy and democratization, and new chapters have also been opened - but we also know that there are many changes needed in the field of human rights, media freedom, the judiciary, or recommendations regarding, for example, changes to some constitutional provisions. I would also like to emphasize the important role that ombudsmen can play. Last year, we organized such a conference - a summit of ombudsmen for Eastern Europe and Eastern Partnership countries with the participation of ombudsmen from the Western Balkans. I think it is also worth continuing this work.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the Commissioner. I think it is obvious that Serbia is making progress, even though there are still some problems to deal with. But I think some of the best arguments for proceeding with membership of Serbia to the European Union have come here tonight from those who are arguing against membership, because it is very clear that they would like the old conflicts, the old hostilities, the old tensions, to rule over the future of Serbia. They are demonstrating exactly the reasons why we should proceed. And I think it is important to remember – and I think that is a message to all Serbian citizens from here tonight – that, when we are discussing the problems, we are not raising hindrances or obstacles. We are clarifying what needs to be sorted out in order to be prepared for membership of the European Union. And I would like to say that this development is not a sacrifice, because when we discuss all these chapters, it is a way of making Serbia a better society – rule of law, the fight against corruption, an open economy, prosperity. It is not a sacrifice, it is a step forward anyway. I think we need to understand that when some people talk about the costs of enlargement, the policy of enlargement has been one of the main success stories for the European Union. And we shall never forget the cost of non-enlargement: we saw that in history, and we will avoid it in the future.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, I would like to thank Mr. McAllister for this balanced and objective report. We all agree tonight that Serbia has made some progress in the process of joining the European Union, but for areas such as the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary, it can be said that they have not yet taken root in practice. In any case, the shortcomings are still visible. More efforts are needed to fight corruption and organized crime, which remain an obstacle to economic and social development, but media freedom is also threatened. We keep repeating that it is necessary to normalize relations with Kosovo, where greater involvement of Serbia is expected, and in addition, it is very important that Serbia aligns its foreign and security policy with the policy of the European Union. I am thinking here in particular of their relationship with Russia. As far as good neighborly relations are concerned, bilateral issues related to other countries, especially Croatia, must be resolved as soon as possible. They need to be addressed urgently so that regional co-operation is possible and so that Serbia can continue to build its European future. Serbia simply needs to adjust its foreign policy to European policy, deepen dialogue with Kosovo and step up efforts to resolve all remaining bilateral issues. I agree with Mr. Hökmark that we need to discuss and that it is much better to allow Serbia to open a chapter and thus get closer to the Union, than to prevent it. Of course, we agree with that, aware of what Croatia has gone through on its way, but we are looking for fair criteria and meeting the criteria, as we did.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Mr President, I am very pleased that the well-worded and balanced report by my fellow Member, Mr McAllister, has finally been debated. It is clear from the above that Serbia is on the right track and that Serbia has a key role to play in maintaining stability in the region. Naturally, there is still work to be done in the accession process, including the rule of law in the field of minority rights, national councils, part-time employment or minority education. Serbia has adopted a precise action plan in this regard, and I am confident that Serbia will comply with it. But I also trust that the EU will live up to its own commitments and that it will make concrete gestures that can be felt by Serbian citizens. By this I mean not only the opening of new negotiating chapters, but much more tangible steps than this, which suggest that the EU is sincerely committed to further enlargement.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Mr. President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague David McAllister on a well-balanced report that highlights Serbia's progress towards EU membership and its values ​​as the only way to guarantee peace, stability and security throughout the Western Balkans. In the report, which the rapporteur pointed out, in addition to the mentioned progress, weaknesses were identified that need to be eliminated in order for Serbia to meet the criteria for membership in the European Union. I am thinking here of implementing key reforms in the areas of the rule of law, an independent judiciary and a free media, and the fight against corruption and organized crime. In addition to meeting the criteria important for membership in the European Union, it is necessary to resolve open bilateral disputes with neighboring countries, first of all I mean resolving disputes with the Republic of Croatia. The issue of missing persons during the war, the opening of archives, the resolution of border issues and the issue of Serbia's regional jurisdiction are some of the open issues that need to be resolved. I would especially like to address the issues of education in the mother tongue of the Croatian national minority in Serbia and the provision of textbooks in the Croatian language and content that will be adapted to them. I believe that this is a necessary precondition for preserving the identity and rights of minorities, which is one of the basic conditions for Serbia's entry into the European Union. Resolving open bilateral issues is not there to prevent or block Serbia on its path to the European Union, but resolving them will create a precondition for lasting good neighborly relations and stability in relations between Croatia and Serbia.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Congratulations David to you, your shadow rapporteurs, on an excellent report that gives an objective picture of Serbia's progress over the last year. The enlargement process of the European Union is also one of the greatest successes for me, we also know that those who now speak most from Slovenia, Croatia, who are part of this enlargement process. An orderly democracy needs a political culture, it needs respect for the law, it needs the fight against corruption, it also needs media freedom. This is also being done by countries that are already members of the European Union, and if this is not the case in countries, it is still a problem in countries. Therefore, I think it is right that these warnings contained in the reports have been accepted in good faith and that these errors should be corrected. Certainly, there is a lot of good in the report on Serbia, first of all economic progress, the reforms that are being implemented, because that is the answer to the fact that the demographic picture in Serbia will improve, because what we are recording now is that I don't know births per year, 105,000 dead, speaks to the poor situation in the country. Serbia is also a guarantor of stability in the Balkans, but as we know from history, the Balkans have repeatedly been the cause of many unrest in Europe. That is why I hope and wish that Serbia and its neighbors, first of all, refrain from unnecessary provocations and that they build peace and prosperity in this part of Europe in good neighborly relations.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ladies and gentlemen!That was the last regular speaker.Under Rule 162 (6) of the Rules of Procedure, the President can use a catch-the-eye procedure.We are way past our speaking time and we have too many requests to speak.I will therefore only give the floor to one speaker who could not be there beforehand for logistical reasons: Igor Šoltes has the floor for a minute.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So, as my colleagues have already said, I would like to add that, in fact, some progress has been made in Serbia on the path to integration, including the opening of individual chapters.Above all, of course, it is clear that Serbia is still facing a very difficult period, especially of course the notion of so-called democracy.And I think that some of the observations of the non-governmental sector, the so-called NGOs, which point out that, of course, Serbia is also facing a difficult test of how to actually provide a plural space for freedom of expression, freedom of the media and therefore thatminorities of all kinds are also heard.Therefore, I think that, of course, we must also pay attention to this in future reports, and above all to open up space for discussion.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this very interesting debate, which reflects the importance of the enlargement process and of our relations with Serbia as a driving force in the region. I fully understand the sensitivity of bilateral issues. Clearly further efforts will be needed to overcome the legacy of the past. At the same time, we should ensure that bilateral issues do not hamper the firm prospect of EU membership, which continues to drive transformation and anchor stability and security in Serbia and elsewhere in the region. This is more important than ever at a time when our EU’s commitment to Serbia and the region's EU path are questioned by some people. At the same time, of course, we should focus on good neighbourly relations, democratic values and the respect of the rule of law, protection of national minorities, freedom of expression and of the media, ability to address the legacy of the past and war crimes issues. Those are core European values and are simply not negotiable. This is why they are key conditions on Serbia's EU path and I can reassure you that the Commission is committed to continue monitoring Serbia’s focus in this respect under our Chapter 23 negotiations and to continue supporting Serbia's efforts.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, I wish to thank you for the very useful debate. I have listened carefully to the views expressed and we look forward to continuing this constructive dialogue and engagement. I would like to assure you that when moving ahead on the accession process with Serbia, we will closely monitor its progress, paying particular attention to the areas of the rule of law, the Belgrade-Pristina dialogue and other important issues mentioned here today. In this regard the Presidency hopes to hold an accession conference this coming week on 20 June.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Rapporteur. - President Graf Lambsdorff, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to thank everyone who has spoken in this evening's debate. I think that was a good, thoroughly critical, but at the same time also constructive debate about the political situation in Serbia. The Serbian Ambassador to the European Union, Ms. Ana Hrustonavic, whom I warmly welcome to the stands, has certainly also listened very carefully to all the arguments. My special thanks go to the shadow rapporteurs of the individual groups for the once again good and trusting cooperation. I believe that together we have succeeded in presenting this European Parliament with a report that paints a realistic picture of Serbia. And I think the message of the debate tonight was - despite some differing views on details of Serbia's domestic policy: the vast majority here in Parliament supports Serbia on its way into our community of nations in Europe.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 14 June 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. - Of course, no one forgets that the EU, and especially Germany and Austria with the foreign policy they pursued in the 1990s, have a huge responsibility for the dismemberment of Yugoslavia and the war that then broke out in the region with thousands dead. After a decade of wars and NATO bombings targeting Serbia, the country has been found to have lost significant territories inhabited by Serbs. It lost its access to the sea and the cradle of Serbian culture, namely Kosovo, while important infrastructure was destroyed. In a society that has been in a state of economic insecurity ever since, the EU comes and in the most hypocritical way demands, here and now, full adaptation to the Western European standards of state organization. And as if that were not enough, the EU is calling for de facto recognition of Kosovo by Belgrade, which, among other things, reinforces Albanian nationalism. Finally, after pointing out the positive role of Serbia in the refugee, we should note that the position of Orthodox Serbia is in Europe and the Greek people support the European course of Serbia.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written.- I am glad that this Report calls on Serbia to make additional efforts to resolve the problem of the scope, implementation and effects of the Law on Organization and Competence of State Bodies in War Crimes Proceedings, by which Serbia took on the role of a small Hague.The law poses a danger to Croatian war veterans on Serbia's blacklist, but also to former Kosovo Prime Minister Ramush Haradinaj.However, I am sorry that the repeal of the disputed articles of the law is not set as a condition for Serbia to open negotiations, and therefore I call on the Commission to insist on the repeal of Articles 2 and 3 of this Law during the negotiations on Chapter 23.I once again warn of the systematic discrimination of Croats in Serbia and the challenge to their minority rights, such as the provision of education and media programs in the Croatian language.Also, physical attacks based on ethnicity, as well as public rhetoric in Serbia that contains elements of extremism and hate speech, are contrary to European values.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Ulrike Lunacek, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the Commission's 2016 report on Kosovo (2016/2314 (INI)) (A8-0062 / 2017).

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, colleagues, let me say first of all there has been some progress in Kosovo over the last year on issues that concern the relationship between the European Union and Kosovo. A stabilisation and association agreement finally has come into force, and that has included the European reform agenda and something we voted recently in the plenary: the participation of Kosovo in EU programmes. So various things were re-signalled – and that is supported by this report – strongly signalled to Kosovo, and to Kosovo citizens: your future is in the European Union. Nevertheless, we also have to see that, over the last year, things have not progressed as much as Kosovo citizens and also as we here in the European Parliament would have liked them to go. The extreme polarisation of the political landscape (and I will come to the elections of last Sunday at the end), but also no progress here in the European Union. We still – and I have been rapporteur for Kosovo since 2009 – do not have progress with five EU Member States recognising the independence of the Republic of Kosovo. This is harming progress also. This does not give Kosovo citizens the idea that we really want them and that they are part of Europe – they should be part of the European Union. So this report also regrets that still five Members are not recognising Kosovo, and you know, to those of you who come from those five Member States, sometimes I wonder, when you then criticise corruption – organised crime in Kosovo, yes, which exists, like in other parts of the region and also inside the EU – then why do you not want to allow Kosovo to become part of Europol and Interpol? Because that would help. So there is a contradiction in the position of those five Member States, and I hope we will see progress in the next year. But let me come to some other points. In the normalisation process between Kosovo and Serbia we also have had mostly stalemates. We have had one progress: Kosovo now has a telephone code of its own and not any more the Monaco one or the Slovenian one. It can be still be used, but there is this independent international telephone code. But nevertheless, so many things have been agreed between the two governments of Kosovo and Serbia, but implementation is still lacking on both sides. Also from Serbia we have had signs that were simply not helpful. The Serbian nationalist train from Belgrade to northern Kosovo with signs on it: ‘Kosovo is Serbia’. This simply is not the reality any more, and people in Serbia know that and the Serbian Government knows it. It simply does not help to develop good neighbourly relationships if things like that are supported. And as I said, what is lacking really is implementation. In Kosovo itself, still administration of justice remain slow and inefficient. Lack of progress has been made in regard to the protection of freedom of expression and media freedom, and several other issues. When I talk about gender-based violence, still women’s full rights need to be enjoyed, although there has been some progress as well. Now let me come to the elections on that weekend. Yes, finally, and it is good that these elections were passed peacefully. There have not been any disruptions. But we still have problems there. There are still voting lists that were not been totally accurate; the electoral system still not functioning well sometimes and financing of political parties were problems. So I think it would be very important also because we have had intimidation against Kosovo Serbs who would not want to vote for the Socijalistička. There I would like to end with asking, as it is said in the report as well, that the leaders of the Kosovo Serb community should take full ownership of them being part of Kosovo and not always referring to Belgrade.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, on 9 March 2017, the European Council discussed the situation in the Western Balkans. The heads of state or government stressed the EU’s commitment to the region and reaffirmed their unequivocal support for the European perspective of the Western Balkans, in full respect of the basic principles of conditionality and own merits.  Today we focus on Kosovo’s progress in 2016. However, more generally, I would like to stress the importance of Kosovo’s stability and of its continuous efforts to advance further on the European path. We welcome the entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) with Kosovo and the first Stabilisation and Association Council, which both took place last year. The EU-only agreement, which is without prejudice to Member States’ positions on status, provides the contractual framework for cooperation between the EU and Kosovo.  It is important for Kosovo to implement the comprehensive reforms to meet its obligations under the SAA in order to fully benefit from the opportunities it brings. We welcome the launch of the European Reform Agenda in November 2016. The Kosovo leadership is responsible for ensuring its thorough implementation, with the objective of improving the rule of law, socio-economic development and building a track record of SAA implementation.  It is key that Kosovo further intensifies its efforts to improve the rule of law, including judicial independence. It also needs to further advance its fight against organised crime and corruption. We welcome the steps taken to increase the number of high-level corruption and organised crime cases being investigated and prosecuted. We encourage further progress in strengthening a solid track record of convictions. We also note progress in fighting radicalisation, extremism and terrorism, and we encourage further efforts.  Effective promotion and protection of human rights throughout Kosovo should be pursued, including the full protection of cultural and religious heritage. Furthermore, the Kosovo authorities should address the inclusion and protection of persons belonging to minorities. This includes additional efforts to ensure a safe environment and the safeguarding of their property rights, as well as the strengthening of social cohesion. Progress in the process of normalisation of relations with Serbia is essential and underpins the development of relations and cooperation between the EU and Kosovo. We urge Kosovo to swiftly implement in good faith its part of all past agreements achieved in the EU—facilitated dialogue, in particular the establishment of the Association/Community of Serb—majority Municipalities, and to engage constructively with Serbia in formulating and implementing future agreements. We concur with you in welcoming the recent agreements on the implementation of freedom of movement and telecoms. We look forward to a swift appointment of judicial personnel into the Kosovo system in order to ensure the functioning of an integrated judiciary. We also look forward to the opening of the Mitrovica Bridge, as agreed between the two sides.  The Council will continue to monitor closely Kosovo’s continued engagement towards visible and sustainable progress so that Kosovo and Serbia can continue on their respective European paths. Neither should block the other in these efforts, and both should be able to fully exercise their rights and fulfil their responsibilities. The High Representative played a key role in promoting additional progress in the dialogue. We also welcome the agreement reached over the extension of the EULEX mission until June 2018. We urge Kosovo to continue to cooperate closely and effectively with EULEX, and to contribute actively to the full and unhindered execution by EULEX of its mandate. We welcome the fact that Kosovo met its remaining obligation on the establishment of the Specialist Chambers and Specialist Prosecutor’s Office to investigate allegations of international crimes committed during and after the 1999 conflict. All authorities in Kosovo should comply with their requests for assistance. Kosovo has made significant progress in meeting the requirements of its visa roadmap, which led to a proposal by the Commission, in May 2016, to transfer Kosovo to the Schengen visa-free list. As rightly noted in your resolution, such a decision can only be taken if Kosovo meets the two remaining requirements: the ratification of the border/boundary agreement with Montenegro, and the continuation of the strengthening of its track record in the fight against organised crime and corruption.  We share your concern about the incidents of violence in the Assembly throughout 2016. It is important that, following early general elections, all political parties and local stakeholders show responsibility and ownership and engage in a constructive dialogue with parliament, as the key forum for political debate.  Finally, we very much welcome the signature of the Framework Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Kosovo in Union programmes. It is of utmost importance for Kosovo to take full advantage of these programmes. We are looking forward to the European Parliament’s consent for the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Minister, honourable Members, first of all, I would like to thank the Parliament, in particular the rapporteur Ulrike Lunacek, for the report on Kosovo. We believe that this is a balanced report and is in line with the main findings of our 2016 Commission report. Last Sunday was a crucial day for Kosovo and its democratic development. I would like to thank this House and especially Alojz Peterle for its strong support for the EU election observation mission. This observation mission was deployed in record time. The European Parliament has significantly contributed to making it possible. In most of Kosovo, the election day passed calmly and peacefully. It is a sign of Kosovo’s democratic maturity that people generally were able to cast their ballots freely and without hindrance. However, we do share chief election observer Peterle’s concerns about several aspects of the elections. Any incidents of intimidation and pressure as witnessed during the electoral campaign are unacceptable. It will be essential for Kosovo’s democratic development that the findings of the observation mission are taken seriously and implemented as a matter of priority. Now that elections are over, Kosovo has no time to lose. Based on the democratic will of the people, we expect a new government to be formed and begin work without delay. A new governing coalition will face huge expectations and challenges. The dialogue with Belgrade needs to move ahead. The people of Kosovo expect decisions on visa liberalisation. The rule of law, economic development and education need to be given the highest priority. Broad societal consensus on the EU reforms will be necessary to navigate through these various challenges. One of the most important priorities the government will have to tackle immediately is delivery on the conditions for visa liberalisation. Kosovo has made progress on its track record of high-level corruption and organised crime cases. This must be a continuous process and one in which momentum must be maintained at all times. I can assure you that we know how contentious the border demarcation agreement with Montenegro has become. It will now be for Kosovo’s new government and parliament to deliver on the expectations of its people. We are ready to support Kosovo every step of the way. Once Kosovo has fulfilled these conditions, the Commission will give its green light to the European Parliament and Council. Beside these political challenges, Kosovo’s priorities should remain the rule of law, economic development and education. Kosovo needs to become an attractive place for business, provide citizens with high quality education and reduce the very high unemployment levels, in particular amongst young people. The incoming government will need to show strong commitment to addressing the systemic weaknesses in the rule of law, as we have frequently pointed out in our reports. The Commission is providing strong support for the implementation of these priorities through substantive financial assistance and technical advice. For its part, Kosovo needs to keep pace with the rest of the region, to promote economic growth and foster political stability, which is essential for the security of the Western Balkans as a whole. To achieve this, we have jointly agreed programmes with Kosovo: the European Reform Agenda and the Economic Reform Programme. These should serve as guidelines for concrete deliverables. This is the priority for now and the immediate future.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the Commission progress report is issued at an important time for Kosovo, but also for the whole region. Recent events have shown the need for responsible action by the governments and lawmakers of both Kosovo and Serbia, not only for enabling the normalisation between Belgrade and Pristina, but also to convince this Parliament that there is a genuine will for European integration. We as the European Union indeed welcome the progress that has been made, not least in the fight against corruption. Now we are awaiting convictions and not just indictments of high-level individuals. The EPP hopes that visa liberalisation will become a reality. At the same time, we strongly emphasise that a successful fight against corruption and organised crime is a requirement and that the issue is in the hands of the decision-makers of Kosovo. After the elections last Sunday, we all certainly hope for a new Kosovar government to be formed as soon as possible. We hope that the issues which have been troubling domestic Kosovar politics will be settled through a determined government and a responsible and Europe-oriented political assembly. The resolution we are debating tonight reflects the general view of this Parliament. It is balanced and well drafted by the rapporteur, Ms Lunacek, and I would like to thank you for good cooperation. In order to support the people of Kosovo on their significant path towards the European Union and show that Kosovo belongs in Europe, we will vote ‘yes’ to the resolution tomorrow.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank my colleague Lunacek for her work. This report, in addition to describing the situation of our relations, is above all useful in focusing our attention on the various crucial points that still prevent Kosovo from fully integrating. The result of last Sunday's important elections saw the so-called war wing, as the local media call it, made up of a coalition led by Haradinaj, getting the most votes, which would not seem sufficient to support a government without alliances with others. political forces. Our expectations are naturally those of seeing the birth of a government that guarantees the country the stability necessary to continue the process of political stabilization and integration of Kosovo in the European context. However, we must be aware that Haradinaj's victory will not simplify relations with Serbia, a country which, as we know, has issued an international arrest warrant against the former commander of the Kosovo Liberation Army. The role of the European Union in this context will be important. As rightly pointed out in the report, concern remains high regarding corruption and organized crime, two factors that afflict the country with a certain severity. Furthermore, despite the appreciable economic improvement and the increase in tax revenues, it is essential to promote structural economic and social reforms, especially as regards work and education. Finally, I invite you to reflect on the fact that the lack of recognition of Kosovo by five Member States actually hinders the integration process. A change of course could be useful and would allow the improvement of relations between Kosovo and Serbia. I think that the European Parliament needs to show more courage, because that would help even more the political action of the European Union in Kosovo and the Balkans.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Congratulations first to you, Mrs Lunacek, on the report you have made. This Sunday, I was part of the European Parliament's election observation mission in Kosovo, and I can assure you that democracy in the country, or at least the elections as they were, are probably better and better prepared than some of the our countries. Of course, as in other pre-accession countries, there are problems in the judiciary, high corruption, organized crime, media independence, and the huge issue with Islamic fundamentalists. But I would like to draw your attention to the fact that Kosovo is also facing the interests and influences of neighboring countries, such as Russia and Serbia, which are trying to develop their influence in this territory. Turkey is conquering the country religiously and economically, and thus we are left with only the opportunity to be donors of funds, with no visible political benefit. It is the lack of a visible European Union presence that makes many Kosovars think that the European Union has forgotten them. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, Kosovo has more support than ever before.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. President, colleagues, elections for the Assembly of Kosovo were held last week and I would like to emphasize here the fact that the turnout was only 41%. If we know that unemployment in Kosovo is very high, among young people and higher than 50%, these two facts point to the danger, not only of losing confidence in the domestic political structure, which is certainly not good. Low citizen participation makes quality policies difficult, but so is the danger of losing confidence in the European Union. Whether the election results, which, with all the difficulties mentioned by Ms. Lunacek as rapporteur, were generally conducted correctly, but whether the election results are such as to facilitate the resolution of the problems facing Kosovo within itself and external problems, remains, of course, Question. Therefore, despite all the efforts undertaken by the Government of Kosovo, ie the European Union as well, progress in many areas is very weak or almost non-existent, which again threatens to endanger body, in the European Parliament, also loses support for the accession of Kosovo and other Western Balkan countries to the European Union. So this is a very delicate situation. I plead with the European Commission, with fellow Members not to lose pace, not to lose confidence, and with all these programs developed by the Commission, the program of connections, energy ties, I call on the Commission to develop other programs of joint cooperation of the Western Balkans.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. president. We have not changed our position on the unilateral declaration of independence of Kosovo, an artificial state created under the cover of a military intervention, outside of international law and the United Nations, with the support, in addition, of groups that have seriously violated rights humans. It is not trivial to remember that the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity guaranteed by the Helsinki Act are violated and that there is a Security Council Resolution, 1244, which cannot be enacted by a unilateral act. Today eighty-two countries of the United Nations, five of them from the EU, do not recognize this unilateral declaration of independence. The Union cannot use international law as a tailored suit. Kosovar membership in international organizations and organizations is not the way to a solution. The solution is to accompany the dialogue between the two parties within international legality.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, between 1999 and 2004, 150 churches and monasteries in Kosovo were looted, destroyed or set on fire. Obviously, present-day Kosovar society rejects the history of the land in which it finds itself. We would have known better as a way to show our attachment to the history of Europe. Think about the signal you are sending by reaching out to those who want to erase our history. Unesco, the antechamber of the United Nations, was not mistaken in rejecting Kosovo's membership. She knows very well that it is unthinkable to hand over control of the four sites of the Serbian Orthodox Church today classified as world heritage to those who looted them yesterday. Let us follow his example, let us renounce this integration. In addition to being a danger to European culture, stubbornness in wanting to integrate Kosovo comes at the risk of our security. In the same article, the rapporteur reveals drug trafficking, human trafficking as well as the illegal possession of and trade in weapons, and welcomes the Commission's proposal to liberalize the visa regime. More than indulgence, it is complacency.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, as shown not only by the Commission report, but above all by the knowledge of reality, Kosovo is perhaps the most corrupt country in Europe. There is corruption at all levels of government, organized crime, human rights abuses, hard drug trafficking, organ trafficking, domestic violence, foreign ISIS fighters and political polarization in the country. In addition, Kosovo does not meet the conditions of good neighborliness because it refuses to ratify its border demarcation agreement with Montenegro and wants to join Albania, which has direct expansionist aspirations against all of its neighbors. Greater Albania. It is particularly provocative against Greece. Under these conditions, it is not possible to implement the Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement with the European Union, because when a rule of law has not been established in a country, how can it participate in international organizations?

name: David McALLISTER
text: - President Graf Lambsdorff, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! First of all, I would like to say a warm word of thanks to Ulrike Lunacek for her dedicated work. I think we should recognize that this country has managed to hold the third elections since independence in 2008, once again freely and fairly. However, the result must not lead to a political blockade. And that worries me, given the election result and the composition of Parliament. The formation of a government in Pristina nine months in advance, as was the case after the last parliamentary election, should be avoided. The new government in Pristina should be pro-European in the interests of all Kosovars and have a resilient strategy for the future of the country. In my opinion, particular progress is necessary in three areas. Firstly - it has already been emphasized: Kosovo is the only country in the Western Balkans that still does not enjoy a visa-free regime. This of course leads to frustration among people. The new government in Pristina and parliament should finally meet the criteria for visa-free travel. First and foremost, this includes the ratification of the border agreement with Montenegro. Second, the new government should adopt major economic reforms as well as reforms to strengthen the rule of law. The progress made in the fight against corruption, bribery and organized crime are of course logical and important prerequisites on the way to the European Union, but they are also the basic prerequisite for further investments from other countries, for example from Germany. Third: The dialogue with Serbia should be continued and deepened; agreements already made must be implemented. This also includes the establishment of a Serbian community association in northern Kosovo. Relationships too Serbia plays a key role both in relations with the EU and in stability across the region.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, I congratulate the rapporteur Urlika Lunacek on her dedicated work on this report as well as on the excellent cooperation with the shadow reporters. The adoption of this Resolution was postponed due to the calling of early parliamentary elections, which speaks of the political dynamics in the youngest European country. Kosovo is a clear example of a post-conflict society where key protagonists fail to resolve accumulated points of conflict. Last year, even in important institutions of the democratic order, such as the Parliament, political polarization could have a violent character. The situation in Kosovo is greatly affected by poor social and economic conditions, in particular high youth unemployment, the weakness of the judicial system subject to political pressure, pressure on the media and the insufficiently effective fight against organized crime and corruption. However, all these burdens can be removed over time if the Kosovo authorities actively use the possibilities of the Stabilization and Association Agreement and meet the obligations of the European Reform Agenda. Kosovo's European future will be determined by the attitude of politics, but also of society as a whole, according to the events of the recent past, which will be dealt with by the Hague Office of the Special Investigator for war crimes committed during the aggression on Kosovo. Authorities in Pristina also face the challenge of continuing talks with Belgrade more productively. Both negotiating parties must overcome mutual animosities as well as internal resistance to a process that actually has no alternative. That is, it is better not to think about it. As President of the Joint Parliamentary Delegation with Kosovo, I would like to emphasize that the political divisions have not affected our work. Moreover, all members of the delegation gave their full contribution and we adopted the joint recommendations without much difficulty. On this basis, I allow myself the hope that the conditions for the abolition of visas for the citizens of Kosovo will be met and that we in the European Parliament will finally ratify the decision on their free movement. European Union.Kosovo deserves undivided European support, and its best expression would be the recognition of the remaining members who have not yet done so.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: - Mr President, Mrs Lunacek's report rightly focuses on efforts to democratize Kosovo and resolve the problem with Serbia, making it a condition of securing the Serb minority rights of Kosovo Serbs. Unfortunately, no reference is made to Security Council Resolution 1244. According to the report, there is political instability, corruption, inadequacy of democratic institutions and the judiciary, and dangerous drug trafficking in the region. The Republic of Cyprus, respecting international law and the sovereignty of states, cannot recognize Kosovo as an independent authority or state. Of course, the report ignores the positions of Member States that do not recognize Kosovo and have nothing to do with the enlargement of the European Union in the Western Balkans. We hope for a speedy normalization of Serbia-Kosovo relations on the basis of the principles of the European Union and international law, in order to promote the framework of co-operation provided for in the Stabilization and Association Agreement. We stress that if the European Union does not take seriously the extremist tendencies in the Albanian population and the influence of Albanian rioters, we will face dire consequences that will mainly affect Skopje and open the bag of Aeolus in the Balkans. . Let us not repeat, Mr President, the mistake we made with Turkey.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mrs Lunacek for her excellent work and Mr Šoltes for leading our observation mission. Kosovo’s path to the EU is to be welcomed, but problems need also be mentioned. The reason for the snap elections was said to be governmental inability to make reforms in Kosovo. However, none of the questions that caused stalemate were put to the voters to decide, so there is a risk that we will see a replay of this situation. This deadlock, which is actually Kosovo’s biggest problem, is indeed caused by the difficult government coalitions and the unwillingness of some parties to put Kosovo’s best interests before those of the party, a simple unwillingness to cooperate if that will cost them voters. This is not unusual for young traditional democracies, but I still believe that we have to demand from whoever forms the government speedy reforms, primarily on the fight against corruption. Sensitive questions like the demarcation line, the Association of Serbian Municipalities, etc. should not be used for political games since they are in the interests of Kosovars. Enlargement is needed. We want it to happen, but all of us want to secure the process and demand reforms.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report recognizes that there is no freedom of expression or at least that progress is being made slowly, with threats to journalists, systemic corruption, country of storage and transit for hard drugs, low conviction rates in cases against human trafficking, country of transit and destination for women and minors who are victims of trafficking, presence of armed groups, involvement in organized criminal activities. In short, the description of what is normally called a rogue state. However, the report argues, like Alice in Wonderland, that Kosovo has made efforts to counter extremism to legalization, while admitting that many foreign fighters have already returned to Kosovo and are not being monitored and prosecuted. So it seems to me a strong contradiction. The spokeswoman for the European Union, for her part, continues to promise visa liberalization for a country of this kind, which mainly exports Islamic criminals and terrorists and represents a danger for Europe, a danger for all of us.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, the reality is that the antagonisms between the bourgeoisie in the Western Balkans are intensifying, not only in Kosovo but also in FYROM, Albania, Montenegro, Serbia, in conjunction with the rivalry between NATO-EU-US States and Russia-China for control of energy markets and roads. The European Union, NATO and the United States bombed and dismembered the former Yugoslavia, changing borders and massacring peoples. As in Kosovo, they financed and supported mechanisms, circuits, all kinds of nationalist and reactionary forces, as supposed liberators, to serve their interests, to establish military bases and to serve the interests by controlling the region. The people to oppose the plans of their bourgeoisie and governments and, in conflict with the involvement of the European Union and NATO, to pave the way for their own interests, against nationalism and the interests of monopolies. To demand the closure of foreign military bases, to pave the way for power and the economy to pass into their own hands.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, colleagues! The promise made in Thessaloniki 2003 that the states of the Western Balkans will have access to membership of the European Union still applies with certainty. And at the same time the principle applies that they must meet the conditions. We know that we are considerate in some respects because new influences are coming from the Islamic world, because Russia is active in the Balkans and because geostrategic reasons require a high degree of patience. However, this must not be a reason for not making the necessary progress. I would like to thank Ulrike Lunacek for once again doing her service to Kosovo in this committed way, but we always say: progress must be made - in the fight against corruption, the rule of law and so on and so forth. In other words, there is still corruption, there is still no full rule of law, and so on and so forth. We have got used to a language that, as far as the real circumstances in these countries are concerned, cannot be surpassed in terms of beauty, and then you can understand that some people lose their patience with what is going on. That is why I would also like to emphasize that there are dangers of explosions in the entire region and that there are concerns that we have not had in this way in the past, but that attention should nevertheless be paid to ensuring that certain principles are observed. Visa facilitations can only be granted if the conditions are met. That is why I would like to ask the future government and possible coalition partners of the government of the strongest party to only make coalition agreements in which the border agreement with Montenegro is accepted and otherwise please not to enter into the business of forming a coalition. As a condition for this, I ask that the integration talks with Serbia and the Serbian To lead community, otherwise it won't work.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Mr President, I congratulate Ulrike Lunacek for an extensive and good report on Kosovo. Snap elections have just taken place and we received the reports from the observation mission, and it seems that elections went smoothly. Now I expect the government to be formed as soon as possible. Every day without government means a day lost in facing various challenges: strengthening democracy, rule of law and the institutions and especially creating better living conditions for all citizens of Kosovo, youngsters in the first place. As a rapporteur for a visa—free regime for Kosovo, I wish Kosovar politicians would reach an agreement. The deal on the demarcation agreement with Montenegro and improved track record in fighting organised crime and high-level corruption are in the hands of future politicians in Kosovo, the leaders and the government. And the ball is thus clearly in Kosovo’s court. I will continue to support Kosovo towards the EU and a visa-free regime, but at the same time I would really like to see some more responsibility from Kosovo’s authorities. What we heard about the recognition of Kosovo and the dialogue with Serbia, these are a very crucial questions for a well-functioning state. We certainly want to see Kosovo committed to the European part as a good neighbour and healthy democracy, free of corruption and organised crime, and a place where young people see their future.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Mister President! 60% of Kosovars did not vote in the recent parliamentary elections because they did not trust their democracy, and the few who did vote opted for radical forces - the majority voted for a suspected war criminal. The election winner and designated head of government Haradinaj is said to be responsible for kidnappings, murder, robbery, rape and organ trafficking, among other things. And after nine of the ten witnesses were assassinated, the tenth apparently withdrew his testimony and Haradinaj was acquitted. The report correctly lists the difficult problems facing Kosovo - corruption, money laundering, drug trafficking and unreimbursed rape victims from the war. It is therefore completely incomprehensible to me why Mrs Lunacek recommends visa liberalization in view of the desolate conditions in Kosovo. Haradinaj gave the election promise of a 90-day visa waiver for the Union. For me it is absurd and inconceivable that we should now help to keep this election promise.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, Kosovo’s state is less than ten years old, but its internal situation is still fragile. Joining the EU is the only answer to internal, as well as a regional, conflicts in the Western Balkans. This needs to be clearly understood by all stakeholders, including the EU, and I would like to commend Commissioner Hahn for his dedication and commitment to the Western Balkans. When we say that the Serbian accession progress is linked to good bilateral relations in the region, the same applies to Kosovo. For that, the normalisation of Serbia-Kosovo relations is crucial. For visa liberalisation to be realised, Kosovo has to fulfil all relevant criteria, including ratification of the agreement with Montenegro. The internal political climate and frustration of a great part of the population in the democratic procedure is deeply alarming. Last Sunday, almost 60% of voters abstained from voting. This provides a dangerous playing ground for radical and nationalist forces.  One political development is that reducing corruption and organised crime and making the judiciary more efficient has been assessed as good by the Commission. On the other hand, no improvement on freedom of expression and economic criteria could be noticed, and, after all, as our rapporteur, Ms Lunacek, said, the key to all solutions is implementation. Ten weeks ago, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) entered into force. Kosovo now needs, more than ever, national unity, regional reconciliation and credible implementation of the SAA.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, along with four other Members, I have just returned from the Election Observation Mission in Kosovo, where we heard from many reliable sources about significant interference and provocation from Belgrade, including intimidation of candidates and voters during the campaign period, leading in some cases to violence, including inter-ethnic conflict between different Serbian interests. The organisation of buses and trains from Serbia to Kosovo bearing nationalistic slogans in January and carrying likely bought voters last weekend, is also to be deplored. Outside of the political arena, I witnessed the deep yearning, commitment and action of many Balkan young people who simply want to live side by side in peace, and whose vision shames the old order. Whilst old warlords and vested interests, both Serbs and Albanians, continue to prevaricate, slowing down the accession process, young people of all ethnicities crossed the Mitrovica bridge as part of the Musicians without Borders Rock School.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur Ulrike Lunacek and to congratulate the people of Kosovo for the orderly and peaceful elections conducted last Sunday. Now it is of the essence to move forward on forming a government and starting to address much-needed reforms. We need to see the improvement of both the rule of law and the fight against corruption. It has been over a year since the Stabilisation and Association Agreement entered into force, and more tangible progress on EU approximation needs to be seen. Kosovo cannot afford to lose more time, as seen in the first half of 2016 during the impasse in the Kosovo Assembly. That is why I urge all political parties to participate constructively in the daily political life of the parliament.  Kosovo’s role in the region also remains very important. I hope that the new government will play a positive role in the regional reconciliation. Strong political will and good faith to implement agreements, including the setting up of the Association of Serbian Municipalities, will be a much appreciated gesture from Kosovo to all its neighbours and to its own population. This needs a tough political determination. I hope that the incoming government will possess the political capital to do this.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Mr President, Hungary is interested in the stability of the Western Balkans and the European integration of its countries. That is why we consider the adoption of the national strategy for the implementation of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement, which entered into force last April, to be a major achievement. From a Hungarian point of view, we especially appreciate that, according to the country's laws, ethnic minorities have twenty seats in the 120-member Pristina parliament. This principle is a good practice to follow throughout the Western Balkans. However, the domestic political instability that led to last week's early parliamentary elections is a cause for concern. The sharp political divisions that divide the small country have made Kosovo unable to seize the opportunities offered by its independence, and even destroying its achievements so far. Overcoming partisan strife and a committed political will based on mutual agreement is needed for Kosovo to live up to its democratic commitments and finally get on track with European integration.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr President, I thank Rapporteur Lunacek for this report. The Stabilization and Association Agreement with Kosovo entered into force on April 1st last year and is certainly a positive step in the process of Kosovo's accession to the European Union. It is also the first contractual relationship between the European Union and Kosovo. Although Kosovo has enacted many legislative reforms, the rule of law, concrete and effective implementation remain questionable. In its progress report, the commission highlighted, among other things, a polarized political environment and interruptions in parliamentary activities. The stalemate in parliament has prevented Kosovo from ratifying the delimitation agreement with Montenegro, one of the conditions set by the European Union for visa liberalization. Therefore, further efforts are needed. Kosovo is still at an early stage of preparation in many areas, such as public administration reform, the judiciary, the fight against corruption and the development of a functioning market economy. That is why I believe that this report from the European Parliament can be a good incentive for the new Kosovo Government to continue negotiations with the European Union. I take this opportunity to call on the other members of the European Union that have not recognized Kosovo to recognize Kosovo in order to give impetus to European integration and the European future and perspective of Kosovo.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - I join in congratulating Mrs Lunaček on a balanced report on Kosovo. The rapporteurs are trying to find mainly the good sides that are happening in the country in the last year. In a way, I had the feeling that Ms. Lunaček had quite a bit of trouble with that, because we were facing a blockade in the parliament in Kosovo, we were even facing violence in the parliament and negotiations within Kosovo are very difficult. Negotiations in the region are also difficult, and this appeal, which is made through this report, for better cooperation with Serbia, Montenegro, is certainly in place and gives in some way a future political as well as economic perspective. In the area of ​​the rule of law, corruption, organized crime, even radicalism are still a problem, and last but not least, fighters from Kosovo also left for ISIS.
