I want the new government to find answers to these questions, as well as to economic issues, because the unemployment rate, especially youth unemployment, and the flight of people from Kosovo is a big problem and the answers are very difficult and I really wish them good luck along the way. . With regard to visa liberalization, it will certainly be necessary in Kosovo to meet the conditions that are precisely related to the rule of law, as well as to the conditions in the field of political cooperation and political culture in the region.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, I express my clear support for Kosovo's European path, with the first step being taken with the entry into force of the Stabilization and Association Agreement in April 2016. Kosovo still has a lot of work to do, reforms need to be implemented, and Kosovo needs support along the way. In the first place, they should be supported by Serbia, which is their biggest weight. The Republic of Serbia must refrain from interfering in the internal state affairs of Kosovo and provoking provocative activities as well as the use of extreme and provocative rhetoric. The results of early parliamentary elections two days ago, won by a coalition led by former Prime Minister Ramush Haradinaj, over which Serbia issued an arrest warrant under the Law on the Organization and Competence of State Bodies, clearly show the will of Kosovo's citizens. It is also a message to Serbia to stop abusing the disputed law. Serbia and Kosovo must find a common language and channels for co-operation, and this must be a condition of the European path for both countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Kosovo, according to research and reports, has been turned into a jihadist wasp nest, and that is a given. Therefore, I am particularly impressed by how the European Union will proceed with the abolition of visas, when it is currently proven that there are jihadist terrorists in Kosovo, when there is training. You understand, then, that this will be particularly dangerous for the security of the European Union itself. The second is that Kosovo is being used by the Albanian population, as a whole, to promote the idea of ​​a Greater Albania, an idea of ​​redemption, an idea that even challenges territories within Greek territory. Also, the right to recognize a third state is an uncontrollable right, a right that belongs to every Member State of the Union, and, therefore, states that do not recognize Kosovo retain that right.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - First of all, a sincere thank you to my colleague Ulrika Lunaček for a really excellent report and for her many years of efforts to strengthen Kosovo and, of course, for its establishment in an equal family of countries.In any case, the last elections also showed that, of course, Kosovo will face a difficult period of forming a new government.Of concern is only 41% turnout and, in fact, a large number of so-called blank ballots, which in a way shows a silent protest of the people, because until there is a decisive fight against corruption, until there are demands for and implementation of an independent judiciarythere will be no progress.And I think it is also the task of the European Parliament to actively assist colleagues in the newly elected Parliament of Kosovo as much as possible.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, it is rather strange to maintain the situation where five EU Member States have still not recognized the independence of Kosovo. The Hungarian Democratic Alliance in Romania was the only one in the Romanian parliament that voted in favor of recognizing Kosovo after the declaration of independence, unfortunately the position of the Romanian foreign affairs has not reached this decision since. Recognition would not only be essential for the country's initial steps towards European integration, but would also create an environment conducive to rapprochement between Serbia and Kosovo. Not to mention that the EU's common foreign policy approach would gain credibility and authority. I am convinced that we should reward the integration efforts of the Western Balkan states, as there are international actors that are also active in the region and, in many cases, pursue goals that run counter to lasting peace. There is a long way to go before Kosovo joins the EU, but the goal must clearly be that, because the whole of the Western Balkans has a place in the EU.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, how is the next situation possible?Kosovo has a native, so one hundred and fifty thousand Serb community was born there.For this community, the European Union and, of course, the Serbian mainland have squeezed out, demanded a territorial autonomy in the old sense, full, effective autonomy.In Serbia, discussed earlier, there is a native Hungarian community of three hundred thousand, or nearly three hundred thousand, who have no territorial autonomy, no full and effective autonomy.My question, of course, includes the answer, which I never get anyway, because that is not the case here in this House, but I am asking Mrs Lunacek and asking the Commission.In it is the answer: there the motherland - and I am not talking about party issues here - has been fought for, demanded by the motherland and demanded by the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, Kosovo is in a critical phase of its statehood.The state exists, is recognized by 111 UN member states and must provide all its citizens with all the services expected of the state.On the other hand, there are constant blows to the statehood of Kosovo, primarily from Serbia, and this makes development very difficult for this young state.The European Union's attitude towards Kosovo is deeply unjust, because we promise it a European perspective, and we have not secured it international recognition from all member states of the Union.If some members do not recognize Kosovo as an independent state, how will they accept it into the Union?In that way, we are sending the wrong message to Serbia, which will do its best to become a member of the union without recognizing Kosovo.If we allow that, we will introduce one big problem into this community.I think we have quite enough of them and this one needs to be resolved before these two countries become members.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, Minister, dear Ulrike Lunacek! I hope that the fact that most of the Members of Parliament left the Chamber after they had spoken is not a symbol of the attitude towards Kosovo. It deserves all your attention. On the whole, I would like to thank you for the critical, but mostly positive, comments on the situation in the country. The elections have shown - and this has already been discussed sufficiently today - that the result will probably not lead to the formation of a government quickly. The opposite is to be feared. I hope it won't be nine months again. But the rhetoric in advance has meant that there are now cemented positions again and it will be difficult to find coalitions here. I hope you will learn your lessons from it and understand that democracy also means finding compromises and not thinking and acting in black and white categories. I can only assure you: the European Commission is committed to the European perspective of Kosovo. We are doing everything, and last year too, we delivered, not only the Stabilization and Association Agreement, but also the European reform agenda. It is now really up to the authorities in the country to take advantage of these opportunities. The citizens of Kosovo want that. 75% percent - a whopping three-quarters majority - are in favor of European integration. When it comes to visa liberalization, it is up to those responsible to deliver. It is not up to the European Union or others here to bring about the results, the decisions. It's an internal problem. As I said: we stand by the side of Kosovo and its citizens. You deserve to have that European perspective. But we also expect the new government to make a clear commitment to the European perspective, and I say quite frankly: not just in words but also in deeds.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, I wish to express my sincere gratitude for the excellent work and commitment of the rapporteur of the European Parliament on Kosovo, my friend Ulrike Lunacek. The EU will continue to assist Kosovo, including through its strengthened presence on the ground. However, the primary responsibility for progress lies with Kosovo: its leaders, institutions and civil society. Reforms are crucial and will require the political leaders to live up to their responsibilities for the good of Kosovo and of its citizens. Key EU-related reforms are essential: not to please the EU but because they are in the interest of Kosovo itself.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me first of all thank our colleagues for all the positive remarks and support that I got from so many of them, including from the Council and the Commission. Let me also – before I forget – welcome the Ambassador of Kosovo to the European Union, Bernard Nikaj, up there with Valëza Oruçi. I am glad he is here. Let me also address the few – I think hardly any of them are still here – who have been very critical of Kosovo. These are the non-recognisers and those from the far left and the far right. First of all, there was a verdict from the International Court of Justice in 2010, which said that the unilateral declaration of independence was in accordance with international law, and this was confirmed by the UN General Assembly. So stop saying that this is against international law. Secondly, you will not be able to turn back history. The Republic of Kosovo exists and is recognised by 114 UN Member States. We will all continue to struggle to make Kosovo part of that European Union in a very positive way. Turning back to what now has to be done in Kosovo, a new government has to be formed, and I hope this will happen swiftly. We cannot wait another nine months as happened last time. This is because of Kosovo’s citizens: they will not do it for us. It is not for us here in the Parliament or for the European Union that a government should be formed; it is for delivering on the promises that the candidates have made to the people, and it is for delivering what people expect: for example, visa liberalisation. It is sure that the new Assembly now has to ratify, as swiftly as possible, the border demarcation with Montenegro – there is no way around that – and deliver on the track record of convictions against organised crime and corruption. That has to be done by the government. Without that, progress will not be possible and citizens will not believe that there is a new government that is theirs. That is important. We have the support, and I hope we will have a good vote tomorrow for this report in the interest of Kosovo’s citizens.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: As an explanation to the Commissioner: Most of the MEPs have groups of visitors from the constituencies there, and they expect to see their MEPs in the evening so that they can explain European politics to the citizens.I suspect that is the reason and not the attitude towards Kosovo.The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 14 June 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - First of all, I would like to express my pleasure that the 2016 Country Report on Kosovo has been put on the agenda with the Serbian Country Report. The stability of the Western Balkans is a priority for Hungary, and it therefore supports all initiatives that lead to reconciliation, and seeks to encourage closer economic and political cooperation between the countries of the region, in which the EU should play a leading role. The stability of the region depends to a large extent on the normalization processes between Serbia and Kosovo, the consistent implementation of the so-called Brussels Accord. On the part of Belgrade, we have seen progress on several points in the agreement (energy, telecommunications, etc.), but Pristina has long been unwilling to create the conditions for the establishment of the Community of Serbian Communities. I believe that the EU needs to be more consistent on this issue. With regard to Sunday's early elections, I would like to express my hope that a government committed to European values ​​and reconciliation will emerge, which will prioritize, among other things, the establishment of minority self-government and autonomy. Thank you for listening.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - The whole report is marked by Serbia's legitimate efforts not to recognize Kosovo's unilateral secession. This position logically follows the criticized actions of Serbia in the report. In particular, it is about preventing participation in the work of international organizations and interconnecting energy networks. The report states that 90% of the population fears unemployment, while the government does not pay much attention to supporting small and medium-sized enterprises. With boldness, the author of the report considers, in paragraph 8, that it is important for Kosovo's security policy to be in line with the EU's common foreign and security policy. The experts preparing the background for the report seem to have a patent on reason. Serbia's report criticizes Serbia's efforts to convict war criminals, but also calls for an investigation and condemnation of war crimes. Concerns about the lack of protection of freedom of expression and freedom of the media, as well as deep-rooted corruption, the existence of armed groups involved in organized crime with a cross-border dimension of activities. Practical non-seizure of property, seizure of criminal assets. The lack of an effective strategy for monitoring and prosecuting returned foreign fighters are all other arguments pointing to the practical non-existence of a consolidated state. The report calls for the issue of guaranteeing the return and reintegration of displaced persons to be addressed, including respect for the civil liberties of all communities. As the KLA-joined forces won the last elections in Kosovo, I do not see much hope of improving the situation here.

name: Kati PIRI
text: written. - While Kosovo has just had elections, I would like to draw your attention to the following problem: the possible closure of the International Business College of Mitrovica. On July 31, the International Business College of Mitrovica threatens to be closed. This poses major problems for half of the 174 students. About 80 students come from minority groups and the continuity of their education is at stake. They cannot be transferred to other universities as they are not taught in English or Serbian anywhere else. Donor funding was available until the beginning of this year. Kosovo had invested € 1.5 million and countries such as Sweden, Denmark, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands - as well as the EU - have jointly donated € 13.5 million. It is a shame that the success of this multi-ethnic school is in danger of being diminished by a lack of sense of urgency in the Kosovar government. Hence my request to the European Commission to exert political pressure on the Prime Minister and the Minister of Education to draw up a request for emergency funding for this school as soon as possible and thus create a solution for the continuity of this school.
